column2: United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., attained record sales in the fiscal year ended June 30 but profits declined by $7,754,532 primarily because of sharply lower foreign earnings, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Psychically speaking or moralwise, as the boys in the board room say things were looking up until Newsweek arrived with that long article on "Jim Ling the Merger King." Another
"Hospital costs are one of the more immediate crises facing the American people.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 4 (AP) Governor Rockefeller told reporters today he had said nothing new about Vietnam and did not intend to.
Haryou, the oft-besieged antipoverty agency, has changed its status and become a community corporation to coordinate Harlem antipoverty programs.
Fuqua Industries, Inc., announced yesterday in Atlanta a revision of the terms under which it planned to acquire the McDonough Securities Company, Varco Steel, Inc., and Rome Industries, Inc.

With three or four exceptions, the New York City Opera's performance of "The Magic Flute" last night was a vocally thin business, at times tottering toward the opera-workshop level of competence. And yet, as it is so

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 Osborn Andreas, one of six men under indictment in New York for allegedly rigging the price of Pentron Electronics Corporation stock early in 1966, was found shot to death today in his South Side home here.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 4 The Executive Commission of the European Communities has found that despite efforts to make the British economy operate more effectively "the fundamental situation has scarcely changed."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 A lawyers' civil rights group announced today that it would help the Defense Department recruit and train Negro servicemen for jobs as policemen in civilian life.

The Television Board of the National Association of Broadcasters adopted yesterday a new set of regulations that will limit the number and placement of commercials and other nonprogram material in television shows.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 4--The Labor party called on the Labor Government today to "dissociate itself completely" from United States policy in Vietnam.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 5 (AP) The Saigon Post, an English-language newspaper, said today that Nquyen Van Loc had been chosen for the relatively secondary post of Premier in the new South Vietnamese government.
Reports of record highs in net operating earnings continued to flow from major New York City banks yesterday.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 The United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company, which the union struck on Sept. 6, said today that they would act together to get needed parts to the Government and to another automobile company.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 Tony Conigliaro, ineligible for the World Series but permitted to sit on he Red Sox bench in uniform, spent today's opener "pacing up and down" in the dugout.
Plaintiff, the Board of Education of the City of New York, by order to show cause seeks an order adjudging defendant United Federation of Teachers, Local 2, American Federation of Teachers,

BEIRUT, Oct. 4 The Iraqi Government pushed ahead yesterday with plans to take the search for new oil wealth out of the hands of the Iraqi Petroleum Company, a foreign consortium whose revenues have plummeted this year.

CHATTANOOGA, Oct. 4 (AP) Georgia, charging that Chattanooga's action in seizing the famed civil war locomotive The General was unconstitutional, sought yesterday to recover the engine through a suit filed in United States District Court here.
Joseph, Carl, Juan and Patrick are among the estimated 2,000 ex-priests in the New York City area.
The final tally on the three days of local registration in New York City showed early yesterday that 230,084 individuals in the five boroughs had qualified to vote in the Nov. 7 election.
TAMPICO, Mexico, Oct. 4. (UPI) Hurricane Fern struck 200 miles south of Texas in northeastern Mexico today quickly diminished to tropical storm status and further weakened in the mountains.
Directors of Metro-GoldwynMayer, Inc., voted yesterday to ask stockholders to increase its capitalization by authorizing an additional million shares of common and a million shares of preferred.
The election of Edward Gelsthorpe to the board of the Canada Dry Corporation, a producer and distributor of soft drinks and liquors, has been announced.
George Shirley sang the role of Alfredo in "La Traviata" with his usual refinement and intelligence last night at the Metropolitan Opera. But something was missing.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 4 Warren H. Lowenhaupt, curator of bookplates at the Yale University Library since 1951, died Friday in Brussels.
Bridgeport beat New York University, 3-0, yesterday in a soccer game at Ohio Field.
MILLBROOK, N.Y., Oct. 4 Timothy Leary, the embattled advocate of druginduced mystical experiences, has a new role here in a farce.
NEWARK Oct. 4 Reversing itself for the second time in a month, the Newark City Council rejected by a 7-to-2 vote today the proposed use of dogs by the Police Department on a trial basis.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Oct. 4 Terry Wilcox, who led every round, won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association title today by two strokes. With a morning round of 71 and an afternoon tour of the Nassau Country Club course in 70 strokes, the 29-year-old professional from the Saiwanoy Country Club, Bronxville, N.Y., finished with a 72-hole aggregate of 277.

Delegates to the convention of the New York A.F.L.-C.I.O. reacted bitterly yesterday to the penalties imposed against the United Federation of Teachers and its president, Albert Shanker, because of the recent teachers' walkout.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 4 Dartmouth College will undertake a $51-million fund raising campaign, its president, John Sloan Dickey, announced today. The money will go toward the development of undergraduate and graduate schools with emphasis on faculty salaries and new educational programs.

THE Alaskan malamute calls to mind the frozen North and Jack London's Call of the Wild. Around dog show rings in the metropolitan area, however, fanciers associate the breed with Roy and Elsie Truchon's Roy-El Kennels, not in the polar tundras but on the plains of New Jersey, at Hightstown.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Representative Wayne L. Hays, Democrat of Ohio, said today that Gov. George Romney received part of his briefings in Vietnam in 1965 from the man who now is the Governor's foreign policy adviser.

THE University of Buffalo is listed as a major col lege football team and a member of Division I in the three-division set-up in the East. Temple is one of the Division II teams. But Saturday, when the Bulls and Owls meet at Buffalo, few fans will be surprised if the Divi
The Smithsonian Institution, as part of its new role as a great national art center, is negotiating to lease the palatial, Georgian-style Carnegie mansion on Fifth Avenue.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 4 Governor Rockefeller declared here today that approval of the proposed $2.5-billion transportation bond issue could be compared in importance with the state's decision 150 years ago to build the Erie Canal.
A tobacco executive has called for an increase in scientific research before a casual relationship can be established between cigarette smoking and lung cancer and other diseases.
BOSTON, Oct. 4 When the St. Louis Cardinal chartered bus drew up to Fenway Park this morning, a mounted policeman was patroling the entrance area. "What's he gonna do?" asked one Redbird.

Harris Nagorsky, a former stockbroker, pleaded guilty in Federal court here yesterday to conspiracy to manipulate and commit fraud in connection with trading of the common stock of Hercules Galion Products, Inc., on the American Stock Exchange.
Mayor Lindsay has held exploratory talks with officials of the Cunard Line to discuss acquisition of the liner Queen Elizabeth for use as a high school.
Charles Weidman, who has been a pioneer in modern dance, offered last night a premiere of his new work, "Danse Russe," at the Expression of Two Arts Theater. Curiously

A CLAY stove in the form of a tiger cat or a tiger cat in the form of a clay stove, according to the way you look at things ($37.47); 800 saints of varying and unverified ages, dug up in the Philippines ($7 to $150); and taxi horns from India and Pakistan that make American taxi horns seem like sweet music ($9.88).
Investors churned around again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, pushing volume up close to the six-million-share mark. Prices ended mixed, however.
The 100-year-old Madison Square home of Leonard Jerome, Sir Winston Churchill's grandfather, will be razed to make way for a skyscraper.

The game seems up for secessionist Biafra, but this stark fact does not necessarily mean an end to civil strife in Nigeria. The hour has arrived for responsible Ibo leaders to seek an end to the fighting and for the victorious Federal Government in Lagos to demonstrate a will and capacity for the national reconciliation and reconstruction it has promised.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 4-- In the hot, inhospitable lowland in the north of Rhodesia, from the Mafungabusi plateau down through dusty river beds to the great, roaring Zambezi River, a party of infiltrating black African guerrillas has disappeared-- dead or in jail or lost in the thick, unending bush.

Five Democratic City Councilmen asserted yesterday that continued overnight dumping of debris and garbage on the streets and in vacant lots had created a serious health problem. They filed a bill that would impose stiff fines and prison sentences on violators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded today to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, Santa Monica, Calif., new contracts in the Apollo lunar-landing program totaling $170.5-million.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 4 Enugu, the capital of secessionist Eastern Nigeria and the major target of the Nigerian Army since the civil war began July 6, fell to federal forces today.
Firestone Associates of Philadelphia and New York say they have been running their agency for the last six months without account executives.
GENEVA, Oct. 4 The outline of an international agreement to regulate world trade in cocoa was approved today by experts from 14 leading producing and consuming countries.

AS the public official assigned the politically deli cate and thorny legal task of prosecuting the United Federation of Teachers and the union's leadership for their recent stoppage, Frederic Solis Nathan sought to keep enforcement of the law as far removed as possible

BOSTON, Oct. 4 When Dick Williams announced that Elston Howard would be the Red Sox catcher in tomorrow's second World Series game, the manager mentioned that "maybe he'll give us some hitting." But Howard realized that he would be entrusted with a more significant role.

City College students halted destruction of campus lawns and trees again yesterday in the third day of demonstrations over new construction at the college. One student narrowly missed being crushed when he lay down behind a bulldozer in a successful attempt to stop it.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 4 Miss Betsy Ann Silberstein and Peter Levinson plan to be married this winter.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Oct. 4 Producers of natural rubber announced at a conference here tonight that as a long-term measure they planned to set up a permanent secretariat in an effort to maintain prices "at equitable and remunerative levels."

LINCOLNDALE, N.Y., Oct. 4 Mrs. Nora Kennedy O'Keefe, wife of Paul T. O'Keefe, board chairman of the New York real estate and insurance firm of Charles F. Noyes, Inc., and Deputy Mayor of New York under former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, died at her home here today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (Reuters) Anatoly V. Korobov, a villlage schoolteacher who became an architect of the U.S.S.R.'s new economic reforms, died yesterday at the age of 60, it was announced today in Pravda, the Communist party newspaper.
MANY bridge books are available for beginners, and almost all of them are routine presentations of standard material written by bridge teachers. One of the
A Staten Island man charged with the murder of his girl friend was found guilty of firstdegree manslaughter yesterday.
Jews last night began Rosh ha-Shanah, marking the Jewish New Year 5728. Worshippers filled temples and synagogues for religious services.

CAIRO, Oct. 4 (AP) The three-man Arab mission, which is seeking to bring peace to Yemen, cut short its stay there today and returned here following demonstrations in Sana against the presence of the mission.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Legislation that would permit commercial banks to underwrite the revenue bonds of state and local governments was approved today by a subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee.

David W.T. Patterson, who retired in April as a vice president of Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, died yesterday of a heart attack. He had undergone surgery at Doctors Hospital on Monday. Mr. Patterson, who was 65 years old, lived at 309 West 104th Street.

"Law means nothing unless it means the same law for all. This strike by a powerful union against the public was a rebellion against the government; if permitted to succeed it would eventually destroy government with resultant anarchy and chaos."
A program to train young men in the use of computers and other advanced technology in newspaper production was announced yesterday by the American Newspapper Publishers Association Foundation.
VIENNA, Oct. 2 Austria and the city of Vienna have begun a program to challenge Geneva's position as a leading diplomatic center.

BRECHT, I think, said something about it being a happy country that needs no hero. It is very clearly a happy country that needs no folk dance. It is a curious historical fact that folk dance prospers under two conditions: mountains and a past bloody under foreign domination. (Well, at least the mountains are a plus.)

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 4 John B. Kozlowski, a public school principal here since 1949 and a Democratic leader, died here Monday night, after an illness of several months, in the Alexian Brothers Hospital. His age was 58 and he lived at 615 Monroe Avenue.
The National Maritime Union criticized Representative John M. Murphy yesterday for introducing legislation to eliminate safety disclosure requirements in passenger ship advertising.
Three medium-sized steel companies announced yesterday they were discussing a merger that would create the nation's ninth largest producer and a close rival to members of the so-called Big Eight.

AUSTIN, Tex, Oct. 4 Gov. John B. Connally Jr., made it clear to a group of close advisers at a secret meeting at the Governor's Mansion here that he is serious when he says he does not want to run for a fourth term.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 4 A claim by Sol Wachtler, the Republican candidate for Nassau County Executive, that he could cut county taxes by 20 per cent was based on a misunderstanding, a reliable Republican source said today.

BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 4 Gov. John J. McKeithen of Louisiana and Carlos Marcello, said by the police to be the Mafia chief in New Orleans, are scheduled to testify tomorrow before a New Orleans grand jury investigating organized crime in Louisiana.
Alexander Polett, formerly a vice president of Levitt Sons, Inc., has joined Levitt Properties, Inc., of Philadelphia, as vice president and director.
The Rockefeller Administration said yesterday that the cost of the proposed state constitution could require an 80 per cent increase in state taxes within 10 years.

Former Presidents Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower are the honorary chairmen of a testimonial dinner for David Sarnoff to be held on Oct. 31 at the Waldorf-Astoria. The board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America will receive the International Rescue Committee's Freedom Award.
Interest rates continuing to respond to the decision of House Ways and Means Committee to shelve the Administration's tax bill moved up again yesterday.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 4 The cur rent antipoverty controversy here is shaping up into what may become a classic problem: Just what does "maximum feasible participation of the poor" really mean?

BOSTON, Oct. 4 Louis Clark Brock, a 28-year-old devotee of rare steaks and lemon cream pies, became the only mathematics teacher in the United States today who made four hits, scored two runs and stole two bases in the opening game of the 64th World Series.

The Aluminum Company of America agreed yesterday to sell its Rome Cable Corporation subsidiary to the Cyprus Mines Corporation for about $40-million in cash. The com panies are based in Rome, N.Y., and Los Angeles.

THE sibilant voice of menace is the loudest in the jungle of Harold Pinter. Menace, irrational menace, provides the key tone to "The Homecoming," which is finishing its final two weeks at the Music Box Theater before embarking on a lengthy national tour.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4.(AP) A broad attack on air pollution through research, Federal financial incentives to state and local governments and tax incentives to industry was urged today by the top Republican leadership.
The Fifth Avenue Association has asked Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes to prohibit parking on Madison Avenue north of 51st Street between 5 P.M. and 7 P.M. to ease traffic congestion.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) President Johnson is assembling an 18-member commission to undertake the most comprehensive study yet made the multimillion-dollar traffic in pornography.

VIENNA, Oct. 4 (AP) Erich Rajakovic, a wartime deputy to Adolf Eichmann, said today that he used a 1953 Italian identity card to escape arrest in Yugoslavia for extradition to The Netherlands on warcrimes charges.
AN American youngster, after attending a Moscow school for a few months this year, asked her parents in genuine puzzlement: "Why do I suddenly want to learn so much?"

ANN ARBOR, Oct. 4 Gunnar Myrdal, the Swedish social philosopher, sharply criticized today the American war effort in Vietnam and said, "An American victory in the Vietnam war would be the worst thing that could happen to the United States."
Fifty members of the Metropolitan Cycle Association gathered outside Grace Mansion last night protesting the city's ban on angle parking of motorcycles.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 The Senate stripped from the antipoverty bill today an emergency program that would have provided $2.8-billion for more than 200,000 jobs in the next two years.

The first American performance of "Alzira," an early Verdi opera dating from 1845, will be given by the American Opera Society on Jan. 17 at Carnegie Hall. The performance will be the third of five the society is to give during the 1967-68 season.
BRUNEI, Oct. 4 (AP) The Brunei radio reports that Sir Omar Ali Saifuddin, Sultan of this protectorate in northern Borneo, abdicated today.
Gene D. Wilken was appointed yesterday as group vice president in charge of the cosmetics and toiletries group of the Borden Chemical Company, a subsidiary of the Borden Company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)-- Despite rapid increases in population expected through 1985, the West will still have fewer people than other sections of the country, the Census Bureau said today.

BOSTON, Oct. 4 Half an hour after today's World Series game, several dozen clean-up men with large brown paper bags were furrowing through the litter in the Fenway Park aisles when Carl Yastrzemski suddenly emerged onto the field from the Red Sox dugout.

EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 4 (UPI) A jagged hole was burned into the vertical tail of the X-15 rocket plane yesterday when it streaked to a record 4,534 miles an hour, engineers reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4--United States military authorities said today that American firepower had broken the back of the month-long North Vietnamese artillery siege of the Marine outpost at Conthien and that enemy soldiers were retreating from abandoned gun pits.

YPSILANTI, Mich., Oct. 4 Willis Reed's basket and two free tosses by Fred Crawford in the closing minute enabled the Knicks to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 115-114, tonight and stretch their unbeaten National Basketball Association exhibition victory streak to seven. New York has only lost one pre-season test, the opener to Philadelphia in overtime.

LIGONIER, Pa., Oct. 4 (UPI) Favored Aquitania, with Joe Aitcheson riding, won the Rolling Rock Hunt Cup by 14 lengths today after Richard K. Mellon's War Union II ran off the two-mile, brush-covered course.

LEAFY RIVERS, By Jessamyn West, 310 pages. Harcourt, Brace World $5.95. HERE, for an invigorating change in the contemporary novel's tormented pace, is a breezy tale about earlier young Americans changing the world.

RICHMOND, Oct. 4 AP) A Federal court of appeals took under advisement today the question whether Army Capt. Howard B. Levy should be freed on bail while his courtmartial conviction for disloyalty is under review.

The classroom in a Moscow secondary school was packed with youngsters. A pale and earnest teen-age girl presided, with two other girls perched on the laboratory table acting as recording secretaries. A membership meeting of the Komsomol (the Young Communist League), whose members range in age from 14 to 28, was in progress.

The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, long renowned for operating some of the finest passenger trains in the world, announced yesterday plans for eliminating 33 of its passenger trains, including the Chief and the Grand Canyon. Both are among the best known luxury trains operating between Chicago and Los Angeles.

Governor Rockefeller and Gov. Ronald Reagan of California would defeat President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey by a margin of 57 to 43 per cent if the Presidential election were held today, according to a Gallup poll reported yesterday in The Washing Post.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 95.5 on Tuesday from 95.6 on Monday.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 4 (UPI)-- The Justice Ministry informed the United States Army today that it was taking jurisdiction over an American officer who is accused of an illegal attempt to sell three diamonds.

CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) Three bulls broke out of a slaughterhouse today and got into a china and jewelry shop. They crashed through the store, overturned a jewelry counter, but missed most of the china and left through a rear door into an alleyway.

FOR an uncertain hour last night it seemed as if the Russians had pulled off a trick that might have been conceived only by SMERSH. It looked as if they had turned a hallowed little piece of Manhattan real estate into New Haven.

Those of us whose life stories are bestrewn with deferred projects, neglected chores, and unfinished business in general will look with awe upon Mr. and Mrs. Will Durant, who have just concluded a selfimposed forty-year task of writing a history of civilization.
The Real Estate Board of the Bronx has elected Jerome R. Jakubovitz to serve as its president for the coming year.
FORT BELVOIR, Va., Oct. 4 (AP) The Army demonstrated today its latest riot control tactics and equipment.

John J. Bennett, former New York State Attorney General, City Corporation Counsel and chairman of the City Planning Commission, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home at 9707 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 73.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 New lessons learned about battle casualties are changing surgeons' views on treatment of the severely injured, both civilian and military, doctors who served in Vietnam reported today.
THIS bull market has proved a bloody arena for many a short seller. Consider the experience of this wealthy but headstrong investor who is still losing money in a stock we'll call "Psychedelics."
DETROIT, Oct. 4 Foreign made automobiles accounted for more than 10 per cent of American car sales last month.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of Westchester County, N.Y., said today that the Federal Aviation Administration was responsible for "unnecessary loss of hundreds of lives" by failure to force airplanes to carry crash-locater beacons.

A group of 1,800 New Jersey and Connecticut commuters asked yesterday that a three-judge Federal court be convened here to determine the constitutionality of the state and city nonresident income tax.
LIEGE, Belgium, Oct. 4 (AP) Three passenger trains crashed in a tangle of wrecked coaches near Liege today. Officials reported that 12 persons were killed and 76 were injured.

COLOGNE, Germany, Oct. 4 Curious crowds lining up for fish frankfurters, chili dishes and honey on bread testify that the United States exhibit has become one of the major attractions at this year's international food fair here.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4 Italy urged the United Nations General Assembly today to take the initiative to reconvene the Geneva conference to end the war in Vietnam.

Bowaters Newfoundland, Ltd., announced yesterday that it expected to close its paper mill in Corner Brook, Nfld., for 10 or 12 days before the year-end because of a drop in demand from United States customers.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 4 The poignant choice that Britain has to make so often these days between old values and new is brought home at the Labor party conference.
OTTAWA, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press) Revised estimates of the 1967 wheat crop bring the total to 592.9 million bushels, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 4 The poignant choice that Britain has to make so often these days between old values and new is brought home at the Labor party conference.
OTTAWA, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press) Revised estimates of the 1967 wheat crop bring the total to 592.9 million bushels, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 4 Premier Levi Eshkol said today that Israel had been approached by King Hussein of Jordan through intermediaries.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 (AP) Arsonists, gunmen and vandals challenged reinforced police patrols and National Guardsmen today during the struggle to take trucks hauling steel off the highways.
If you's been waiting to see what J. Walter Thompson's first liquor advertising in decades would look like, here it is.
The waterfront industry's controversial seniority system will be tested in State Supreme Court next week in a suit to be filed by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.
IN seven years of American Football League play, the Oakland Raiders have won only five games in the East.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 4 (UPI) A $1.8-million grant and a gift of 32 acres of land at Lake Placid, N.Y., will be used to build the world's first teaching and research facility devoted solely to cell culture, it was nounced today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 4 The rich Dexter Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on Oct. 14 lost some of its glitter today when Gainesway Farm's Speedy Streak was announced as a nonstarter in the fixture because of tender heels.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Ford's Theater, which went out of business the night Abraham Lincoln was shot there 102 years ago, is going to open its box office again.

The city averted threatened resignations from the Lower West Side antipoverty organization yesterday by allowing its officials to retain partial control of its program rather than submit to the city's reorganizational plan to turn over operational direction to smaller groups.
"It's hard to say, but probably my favorite painters are Soutine and Rouault," said Dr. Harry Bakwin, a professor of clinical pediatrics at New York University's School of Medicine.
WASHINGTON, Ind., Oct. 4 (UPI) Robert C. Graham, one of three brothers who built Graham Paige automobiles more than a generation ago, died last night in his home at the age of 82.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) President Johnson ordered the United States Tariff Commission today to report by Jan. 15 on the economic condition of the nation's textile and apparel industries, with emphasis on the impact of imports.
Four theater companies that depend on subscriptions for their livelihood are doing well this season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Executives of shipyards and common carrier barge lines appeared before the House Transportation and Aeronautics subcommittee, today in support of 12 identical bills designed to change a section of the Interstate Commerce Act. The section forbids the mingling of regulated and unregulated commodities in a single flotilla of barges.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 The United Arab Republic has begun substantial withdrawal of its forces from Yemen and Western diplomatic experts expect all 25,000 troops to be removed by the end of the year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 Between 200 and 300 pacification workers and recruits rebelled today against what they called a corrupt province administration in Quangngai, on the coast northeast of Saigon.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 Harry Roth reported today that he had received 5,764 responses to a full-page advertisement in The New York Times Sept. 26 proposing that President Johnson step aside as the 1968 Democratic Presidential nominee.
DEL MAR, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP) Jockey Fred Robertson was fatally injured today. when thrown from his mount at the Del Mar Race track.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

A 250,000-share secondary offering of Northwestern Steel and Wire Company stock reached the market yesterday through a Blyth Co., Inc., group and the shares, priced at $49, were reported "fairly well received." The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company sold the stock as trustee for members of the family of P.W. Dillon, chairman of the carbon steel maker.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 5 Truong Dinh Dzu, the "peace candidate" who was a surprise runner-up in the presidential elections Sept. 3, was released from jail this morning after being held incommunicado for five days.
A group calling itself the United Federation of Parents was organized last night to seek community control of public schools.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) Despite reverses, setbacks and frustrations, the people know "that we're getting better every day," President Johnson said today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 4 After years of groping for ways to predict great earthquakes, American, Japanese and Soviet scientists have been able to identify observable changes in advance of such events. Some have even begun to make predictions, evoking admiration from their colleagues for their courage.
Interest rates on tax-exempt municipal bends have reached their highest level in 33 years, inching above the peak set in late summer last year.

A subhuman species has been detected in growing numbers on public transportation lately. It is the genus transistor, recognized by its characteristic glassy-eyed stare, slack jaw and one outsized ear. When approached too closely, this biological neuter emits loud squawking noises.
Treasury notes worth $1.7million have been lost while being transferred from one bank to another in the Wall Street area, the New York Stock Exchange revealed yesterday.
SINGAPORE, Friday, Oct. 6 (Reuters) At least six persons were believed to have died today when a United States C-47 military transport crashed while taking off from Singapore's civilian airport.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 5 William Garman Hearing, a former member of the Board of Representatives of Stamford and chief of the Glenbrook Fire Department for 16 years, died today in his home. He was 84 years old and lived at 84 Brookside Drive.

Fabrics of hot pink, orange, red and yellow draped boxes in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom last evening for the 19th annual benefit dinner dance of the Recreation Service for the Children of Bellevue. The theme was "Marco Polo." Committee members made the pink paisley tablecloths on top of which were five branched candelabra.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Bayard Rustin told more than 2,000 of the nation's planners here today that they would be in serious trouble unless they took into consideration the will and advice of those for whom they planned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The Department of Defense ordered deferral of all nonessential military construction projects today, almost simultaneously with a statement by President Johnson that he would not recommend big cuts in Government spending as the price of Congressional consideration of his proposed tax increase.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 5 (UPI) Pinto Colvig, the voice of the Walt Disney cartoon characters Goofy and Pluto, died Tuesday in the Motion Picture Country Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 75 years old and had been ill for some time.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 5 Premier Errol W. Barrow of the tiny state of Barbados said today that he would propose that, in the future, newly independent states be put under United Nations trusteeship until they were competent to carry out their obligations as member states.
Bronx Democrats severed a last close tie with a sometimes great and often controversial past when they moved last Monday to new headquarters at Grand Concourse and Fordham Road.
TOKYO, Oct. 5 (Reuters) Construction of the world's largest tanker for an American company will start Saturday at a huge shipyard near here, the ship's builders announced today.

A group calling itself the United Federation of Parents has been organized to seek "community control" of public schools. The Rev. Milton Galamison, who led a school boycott three years ago, presided at the first meeting, held Wednesday night in Siloam Presbyterian Church, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
The back-to-work movement continued yesterday at the strike-bound American Broadcasting Comany.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 Judge Irwin N. Cohen of the Cook County Circuit Court, who had been chief counsel for the City Council's Emergency Crime Committee, died here today at the age of 60, apparently of complications after surgery.

Directors of the Curtis Publishing Company yesterday approved payment of 1965 interest installments on its 6 per cent subordinated income debentures, due 1986, on the condition that an exchange offer to holders of its preferred stock is approved.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 5 The chairman of this city's $4.4million antipoverty program, the Crusade for Opportunity, charged today that the Office of Economic Opportunity was trying to destroy the partici pation of poor people in poverty efforts when it cut off Federal funds to the local group.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The year extensionof President Johnson's poverty program. The vote was 60 to 21.
Mayor Lindsay plans to take a brief vacation later this month, according to his office.

Few characters in opera can be nudged so easily into parody as Scarpia, the nefarious, lecherous, baritonal police chief of Rome in "Tosca." Puccini's music already draws him in black crayon, so that the least tendency toward eyeball-popping or toothy leering by the singer can have unfortunate results.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., said yesterday it expected third-quarter earnings to decline about 19 per cent from the $90,383,789, or $1.90 a common share, reported for the same span last year.
Nine City College students were arrested early yesterday morning, on the fourth day of demonstrations to halt the destruction of campus trees and lawns to make way for prefabricated classrooms.
Between East Village and West, above the rataplan of jackhammers and the whir of drills, amid old iron and new irony, Joseph Papp is herding another idea through the gap Between dream and reality.

The election of two new directors of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., was announced yesterday by Cecil E. Loomis, chairman and chief executive officer. They are J. Robert Fletcher, a Huntington, W. Va., businessman, and Robert F. Duemler, a senior vice president and director of Columbia's Service Corporation.
The big and effective protectionist lobby in Washington is mustering all its forces for an attack on the liberalizing measures made in the Kennedy Round of trade negotiations.

DAGGETT, Mich., Oct. 5 Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Lickus have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Lickus, to William A. Collins, son of George A. Collins of Port Chester, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Collins. The wedding is planned for Dec. 23.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 5 (AP) Despite the announcement by Nigerian troops that they had captured Enugu, capital of the former Eastern Region, federal military sources indicated today that the battle for the city might be continuing.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 5--One hundred thirty five American soldiers, sailors, marines and airmen and two Women's Army Corps stenographers are learning what American soldiers discovered in World War II--that Sydney loves Americans.

ATHENS, Oct. 5 A prominent member of the National Radical Union party took public issue today with the recent attack made on the Greek military junta by the party's leader, former Premier Panayotis Canellopoulos.
LONDON, Oct. 5 Cass Elliott of the Mamas and the Papas was arrested today and charged with stealing two blankets and two keys worth $29.40 from a South Kensington apartment hotel last winter.

PARIS, Oct. 5 The United States is preparing to modify its historic stand for nondiscrimination in trade, it is reliably reported here. The United States is now ready to take a modest first step toward meeting the clamor of the underdeveloped nations for preference in the markets of the rich ones.

The good news from Conthien will have a salutary effect on the whole Vietnam effort but only if the right conclusions are drawn. The first essential is not to build exaggerated hopes. General Westmoreland has wisely toned down the initial claims of victory and warned that he expects the North Vietnamese regulars to renew their assaults against the Marine positions south of the demilitarized zone.

SEA ISLAND, Ga., Oct. 5 (AP) Curtis Person, a Memphis automobile dealer and winner of nine seniors golf tournaments, advanced today to the final of the Southern seniors golf championship where he will meet Thruston Pettus of Ponte Vedra, Fla.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 5 The search for the slayer of Mrs. Dorothy Beck Palmer, stabbed in her home near here last Friday morning, focused today on a 35-year-old man released from a Connecticut state prison two days before the crime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The State Department denounced today East Germany's jailing of twe American citizens. The department said that the move showed a "blatant disregard" for individual rights and that the United States was "exercizing every effort" to get the two men released.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (UPI) The laws that created Medicare and Medicaid were historic acts of emancipation "of which all citizens of America can truly be proud," the new president of the American College of Surgeons said today.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5--According to those who know this season's crop of 3-year-old trotters best, in tomorrow's 71st edition of the Kentucky Futurity the victorious driver will be either Arthur Hult, 26 years old, the youngest reinsman in the race, or Earle Avery, 73, the oldest.
PORTLAND, Me. Mel Collins, 152 pounds. New York City, outpointed Gene Herrick, 158 pounds, Saco, Me., 10 rounds.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Oct. 5 (UPI) Shenandoah Downs race track will start its fall meeting Saturday, but racing will be held at the Charles Town Turf Club across the street. The 72-day meeting had been held up nine days by a strike of mutuel clerks.

LONDON, Oct. 5 There was an identity of spirit last night between actors and audience at the Old Vic theater, where an all-male cast was playing Shakespeare's "As You Like It." The men playing women's parts on the stage were matched by long-haired boys and short-haired girls among the enthusiastic viewers.

An armed holdup man forced a Western Union branch manager in Brooklyn yesterday to write out a $12,500 money order and kept him captive while a confederate made two trips to a nearby bank to get the cash.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The Senate passed today a bill providing stiff penalties for using force or violence on the Capitol grounds or in the Capitol building to obstruct the work of Congress. The measure now goes to the House.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 The President's Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders has decided to accelerate its work and produce an interim report on Dec. 15 instead of the March 1 target date recommended by President Johnson.

Directors of the Puritan Fashions Corporation declared a distribution yesterday of one share of common stock of Paraphernalia, Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary, to its shareholders for each 11 shares of Puritan Fashions common stock held of record Nov. 20.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 5--The Austin City Council today gave open housing official endorsement, unanimously adopting a statement calling on all business and civic groups to help provide equal opportunity for housing for all citizens.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I.--"I've always felt that summer houses should really be family play houses," said Mrs. David Brockman. She was watching her 5-year-old grandson, Ronald Hammer, sail a bright orange kite in the living room of her summer home and year-round weekend retreat here.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 5 (UPI) Prince Notodom Sihanouk warned today that he would resign as chief of state and Cambodia would then turn to the United States for help if Communist China continued to stir up trouble in his country.

Mrs. Margaret Henry Fitzgerald, a retired night supervisor of nurses at Westchester Square Hospital in the Bronx who was active in Irish-American affairs, died yesterday in her home at 1100 Clarence Avenue, the Bronx. She was 77 years old.

MAYS LANDING, N, J., Oct. 5 (UPI) Barbara Gordon's Cockey Miss romped to a six-length victory in the $16,200 Home Bred Handicap at Atlantic City today and moved a step closer to a sweep of New Jersey's triple crown for its juveniles.

IF the four young experts who won the National Mixed Team Championship at the recent Summer Nationals in Montreal defend their title successfully in Minneapolis next summer, the fact will not be entirely clear in the official records. Two of the winners were Michael Moss and Gail Shane of New York, and they will defend as Mr. and Mrs. Moss.

The Transport Workers Union presented the Transit Authority yesterday with new contract proposals calling for a 30 per cent wage increase, a 30-hour work week and major improvements in retirement benefits.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Senator Charles H. Percy led a bipartisan group of 23 Senators today in support of a resolution calling on President Johnson to make a more determined effort to obtain greater Asian military support for the war in Vietnam. The group included both hawks and doves.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 Not even the shrillest of alarm clocks can wake up the Red Sox and the Red Sox fans in the com pelling fashion of Carl Yastrzemski. Boston's living legend sounded his clarion call in Fenway Park today and the response was electrifying. The Bosox tumbled out of the cataleptic state in which the Cardinals plunged them yesterday and all Boston bubbled over once more in ecstatic delight.
As more than one customer remarked after the running of The Cowdin at Aqueduct yesterday, "Eddie Yowell always comes up with a fit horse."
The publishers of encyclopedias, once considered the "old ladies" of the book business, have recently become real swingers in the publishing industry.
INCIRLIK, Turkey, Oct. 5 If it weren't for the barbedwire fences and the guard house at the main gates, the big American Air Force base here could be in a middle-class New Jersey suburb.
BONN, Oct. 5 Despite an apparent rebuff to its latest overtures, the West German Government still hopes to open a dialogue with East Germany.

OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 5 (AP) Gary Player and Jack Nicklaus finished in a tie in a special Big Three, golf tournament today, played two holes of sudden death and then agreed to split $40,000 in prize money when darkness and a flight schedule halted play.

Puerto Rican antipoverty workers staged a sit-in at the Fifth Avenue offices of the Taconic Foundation yesterday, accusing a foundation executive and city antipoverty official of discriminating against Puerto Ricans.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (Reuters) The contents of Somerset Maugham's villa on the French Riviera will be sold at Sotheby's auction house here Nov. 20, it was announced today.

LONDON, Oct. 5 (Reuters) -- Sir Paul Chambers, head of Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., declared at a press conference today that Britain's biggest industrial complex expected to make bigger profits in the years immediately ahead.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 5--On the day last month when eight new United States delegates and alternate delegates to the current General Assembly were sworn in, Arthur J. Goldberg advised them with mock severity: "Get used to being called Ambassador."
DETROIT, Oct. 5 (UPI) Sev eral hundred students at a sub urban high school staged a brief walkout today to protest a holiday given Jewish students for Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year.
Operations of Eli Lilly Co. and subsidiaries in the first nine months this year resulted in the highest sales and earnings in the concern's 91-year history, according to the report issued yesterday.

The city's economic activity during the summer was better than a year ago in most respects, but there were signs of weakening in foreign trade, the State Department of Commerce and Industries reported yesterday.
Centralized financing is recommended by a New York, State legislative committee as a means of restoring economically blighted school and welfare systems in urban areas.

NORTHFIELD, N.J., Oct. 5 (AP) Mrs. Marge Mason of Englewood, shot a seven-over-par 80 today and increased her lead to three strokes after the second round of the United Sttaes senior women's golf championship at the Atlantic City Country Club.
A suit was brought against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday by the Private Communications Association. It accuses A.T. of monopolistic practices and unfair restraint of trade.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 In the midst of his post-game oration today in the Red Sox clubhouse, Carl Yastrzemski stared at the newsmen surrounding him and laughed.
The First National City Bank, traditionally New York's most profitable bank, reported yesterday record net operating earnings for the third quarter and for the first nine months of 1967.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 5 (AP)--Knut H. Staubo, president of the Norwegian Shipowners' Association, attacked today the shipping policies of the United States, Britain and members of the Latin American Free Trade Association.
Mary Martin sang her way through all but 15 minutes of last night's performance of "I Do, I Do," before she bowed out reluctantly, weary with the flu and medication.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Sept. 30 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

The head of the International Longshoremen's Association asked the Governors of New York and New Jersey yesterday to investigate what he said was an "intrusion" by the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor into collectivebargaining rights in the waterfront industry.
The Whittaker Corporation, Los Angeles diversified industrial producer, is planning to enter the sports equipment field through the proposed acquisition of the Shakespeare Company of Kalamazoo, Mich.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 6 Thich Tri Quang, the anti-Government Buddhist monk, began a hunger strike today, vowing to fast "until death, if necessary," unless the Government meets his demand for the cancellation of a decree that recognizes a moderate pro-Government faction as the official Buddhist church.
SCARBOROUGH, England, Oct. 5 The lingering doubt about Britain's political will to enter the European Economic Community was effectively dispelled here today at the Labor party conference.

At a recent school-wide parentteacher meeting in a Moscow school a bemedaled representative of the City Council tried to impress the parents with the municipal government's generosity toward the schools. Irate mothers interrupted with demands for a traffic light on the busy thoroughfare in front of the school. The politician hedged, contending that the flow of traffic should not be interrupted.
Sid Caesar takes the stage of the Latin Quarter for his first New York club date in five years, and the blue-haired ladies at ringside give a little gasp. "He lost so much weight!"

NEW DELHI, Oct. 5 A major effort to bring down West Bengal's unstable united-front government and replace it with a coalition that would exclude Communist participation appeared tonight to have collapsed after two weeks of intense maneuvering.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 5 Miss Winifred Lion Morris and Clausen Ely Jr. will be married here Nov. 24 in the Episcopal Church of the Ascension.
NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 5 V. Richard Bechtel, retired budget director of the American Cyanamid Company, died in his home here yesterday. He was 72 years old and also had a residence at Naples, Fla.

KATMANDU, Nepal, Oct. 4 King Mahendra is convinced that the system of government he is fostering in Nepal under the name of Panchayat. Democracy has proved itself as the appropriate system for the country.
CAIRO, Oct. 5 (UPI) President Gamal Abdel Nasser has sent New Year greetings to the United Arab Republic's Jewish community, the Middle East News Agency reported today.
Federal Reserve credit policy was on an "even keel" its traditional stance during a period of Treasury financing during the week ended Wednesday, banking statistics released yesterday indicated.
MIAMI, Oct. 5 (AP) The home of the Willis H. du Pont family was built of Ohio sandstone, 35 carloads of the material having been brought in from Ohio quarries. The home reportedly cost $800,000.
LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) Sir Ronald Prain will resign as chief executive officer of Roan Selection Trust, Ltd., early next year. He will continue as chairman of the board, the company said today.

ROLLING HILLS ESTATES, Calif., Oct. 5 (AP) A father who discovered a few months ago that his teen-age daughter associated with marijuana users in this Los Angeles suburb helped form a fathers' "vigilante" committee to sweep narcotics pushers and users out of the area.

Merriment came to the Metropolitan Opera with the return of Verdi's "Falstaff" after an absence of two seasons from the repertory. The lavish production designed by Franco Zeffirelli looked imposing on the stage at Lincoln Center, his direction filled it busily, and a strong cast was on hand to sing its way through the effervescent score under the direction of a promising new conductor, Bruno Amaducci.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 5 Gov. John J. McKeithen, accused by Representative John Rarick of accepting Mafia financial support in political campaigns, testified today before a New Orleans grand jury investigating organized crime in Louisiana.
HALMSTAD, Sweden, Oct. 5 (AP) Mark Spitz, 17-year-old star from Santa Clara, Calif., won two events as the touring United States swimming squad swept all 13 events today in a meet against Sweden.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 5 Nine $2,500 checks were deposited today with John Cashman Jr., the race secretary at Roosevelt Raceway, thereby providing for a nine-horse field for the richest-of-all harness horse races. It will be held here Oct. 14.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 95.6 on Wednesday from 95.5 on Tuesday.
Eward A. Mandel, who in 1910 founded Mandel's Department Store in Bayside, Queens, died Wednesday in New York Hospital after surgery He was 80 years old and lived in Woodstock, N.Y.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 (UPI) Five bandits stole about $150,000 worth of rare coins from the Machinery Management Company this afternoon in a holdup similar to the du Pont robbery.

DETROIT, Oct. 5 Mark Ethridge Jr., editor of The Detroit Free Press, said today that the political platform of the National Liberation Front offered "a basis for negotiation on United States withdrawal" from Vietnam.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 5 (AP) One of the nation's astronauts, Marine Maj. Clifton C. Williams Jr., was killed today when his T-38 jet plane smashed into a wooded area in Florida near the Georgia border and exploded.

Mr. and Mrs. Filiberto de Bourbon of New York and Patterson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maria Elvira de Bourbon, to Ronald Nelson Dubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Dubin of New York.

LAS VEGAS, Oct. 5 (AP)--Archibald Henderson, 55 years old, of Newport Beach, Calif., collected $10,000 yesterday in a payoff on a 100 to 1 shot--the Boston Red Sox to win the American League baseball pennant.

May Davenport Seymour, the founder and curator emeritus of the theater and music collection of the Museum of the City of New York, former actress and member of "one of the royal families of the American theater," died yesterday at her home at 114 East 90th Street. She was 83 years old.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--William M. Roth, the Administration's top official on foreign trade matters, warned today that protectionist sentiment in Congress is building up to the point of "a new crisis" that could seriously harm both American business and labor.

After more than a year of discussions, city and state officials have been unable to agree on a plan to develop Lower Manhattan. They disagree most sharply over the use of 100 acres of new land to be created in the Hudson River south of Canal Street.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 Albertina Rasch, once a noted ballerina and choreographer in New York and Hollywood, was buried in a private service at Forest Lawn Mortuary in Glendale today. Miss Rasch is survived by her husband, Dimitri Tiomkin, the Hollywood composer and producer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) The Commerce Department today relaxed more export restrictions on shipments to eastern Europe.
PARIS, Oct. 5 The joint operation of the liner France and the new Queen Elizabeth II is being considered by their owners, it was announced her today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Mayof Lindsay of New York believes the 1968 Republican Presidential candidate should be a dove on Vietnam to give the voters an alternative to President Johnson's policy.
The 54-year-old Anti-Defamation League won an injunction yesterday prohibiting and American-Italian organization that was founded last year from using the words "antidefamation league" in its name.

TOKYO, Oct. 5 (UPI) Lord Thomson, the British publisher, said today he could have had the New York World Journal Tribune for nothing before it folded, but he refused it because it was, not a profitable venture.

RICHMOND, Oct. 5 (AP) Counsel for H. Rap Brown argued in a Federal appeals court today that enforcement of travel restrictions to keep Mr. Brown from filling college speaking engagements would damage the nation's doctrine of free speech.
CHICAGO, Oct. 5 Medical scientists are making important progress in transplanting human organs, specialists in this new area of life saving said here today.

ALBANY, Oct. 5--The Republican leaders of the Constitutional Convention came out today against the convention's proposed charter for the state and vowed to campaign for its defeat at the polls Nov. 7.
MIAMI, Oct. 5 Five masked gunmen invaded the waterfront estate of Willis Harrington du Pont early today and escaped with cash, jewels and two coin collections that Mr. du Pont valued at $1.5-million.
ROME, Oct. 5 Roman Catholic prelates, speaking in the presence of Pope Paul VI, described today a document on doctrinal problems prepared in Rome as negative, pessimistic and abstract.

LA PAZ, Bolivia Senator Robert Kennedy made a percipient observation when he said of Latin America: "A revolution is coming, a revolution which will be peaceful if we are wise enough; compassionate if we care enough; successful if we are fortunate enough.... We can affect its character, we cannot alter its Inevitability".

Mr. and Mrs. Murray Finkel of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyllis Barbara Finkel, to Lawrence N. Paper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paper of Pittsburgh. The wedding is planned for Nov. 18 in New York.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5 (AP) Reinforced police patrols and the Federal Bureau of Investigation clamped down today on harassment of steel haulers. At the same time an economic vise tightened on steel producers and users in seven states beset by the seven-week strike.

Trading subsided sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, with the advent of the High Holy Days. Investors who did not take the holiday kept prices aloft for the most part but the spread between advances and declines was a narrow one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 Senator Robert F. Kennedy and other Democrats made an unsuccessful attempt today to delay the development of the commercial supersonic jetliner sought by the Johnson Administration.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 5 President Kenneth D. Kaunda repeated today his offer to allow Britain to use Zambia as a base for military operations against Rhodesia.

The Friends of the Children's Blood Foundation, division of pediatric hematology at New York Hospital, will hold an art tour the afternoon of Oct. 21. Mrs. Roy V. Titus is chairman of the event and Mrs. Sam Salz heads the sponsoring memship committee.
MEMPHIS, Oct. 5 The first Negro to seek the Mayor's office of a major Southern city in modern times was soundly defeated today in the municipal elections, the returns showed tonight.

TORONTO, Oct. 5 (AP) A Canadian playwright who has an Off Broadway hit running in New York said yesterday, he has been banned from entering the United States because of a six-month sentence he served in an Ontario reformatory 20 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, said today that the Administration, under increasing pressure from the Pentagon, was seriously considering invading North Vietnam. The Defense Department denied it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (UPI) --A bill to provide more protection against Capitol Hill terrorists and unruly demonstrators is being delayed by disagreement over the right of Congressmen to have guns in their offices.

THERE are some plays that an expert will always get right and that an inexperienced player will almost always get wrong. The rapid departure of a number of high-ranking officials of the city's Human Resources Administration and rumors that others are to resign have added to the problems of the agency, already beset by internal struggles.

MIAMI, Oct. 6 A private detective maintained a 24-hour telephone vigil today, waiting to hear from the five men who invaded the Miami estate of Willis Harrington du Pont and escaped with two valuable coin collections.
GENEVA, Oct. 6 The Maritime Commission of the International Labor Organization called on the agency today to hold a conference in 1970 to deal with the problems of the maritime industry.

The disappearance of more than $4-million of securities in three incidents during the past month has stirred up questions of cause, effect and cure.

Representatives of the American Broadcasting Company and negotiators for the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians will resume talks this afternoon in an effort to end a two-week strike.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (Reuters) Cass Elliott of the Mamas and the Papas was freed today after spending last night in jail as a result of a six-month-old misunderstanding about a hotel bill.
WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 6Coral Ridge was made the 5-2 morning-line choice from the rail today against aged horses in tomorrow night's one-mile $20,000 Duane Hanover Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.

NORTHFIELD, N.J., Oct. 6 (AP) Mrs. Merge Mason of Englewood, N.J., won the sixth annual United States senior women's golf championship at the Atlantic City Country Club today, posting a 236 total that broke the tournament record.

Bernstein, educational director of the Capital Radio Engineering Institute, died on Tuesday of a heart attack at the Georgetown Hill Elementary School in Rockville, Md., where he was attending a ParentTeachers Association meeting. He was 46 years old and lived in Potomac, Md.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Adm. Claude Charles Bloch, a former Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet who was commandant of the 14th Naval District in Pearl Harbor at the time of the Japanese air attack on Dec. 7, 1941, died here today at a convalescent home. He was 89 years old.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 6 -- Nigerian officials said today that federal soldiers were continuing their "mopping-up operations" in Enugu, capital of the secessionist former Eastern Region.

Boston, that bastion of Americana, last week went through several days of that peculiar catharsis provided by playing host to a World Series. In Boston, it is more peculiar than in most places because of baseball and cultural history and the customs of the natives.
Professional basketball, keeping with the expansion trend, opens its 1967-68 season this week with a larger National Basketball Association and a new league, the American Basketball Association.

New York's Democrats, who had been looking for John V. Lindsay's Achilles Heel ever since he got to City Hall 21 months ago, believe they have found it in his handling of municipal labor relations. The Mayor, with the legal smoke of the teachers' strike still swirling around him, is moving into the even hotter fire of contract negotiations covering the city-owned subways and buses.

The stalemate between the White House and Congress over increasing taxes and cutting Government spending erupted into open combat last week. With the battle still raging, two things nevertheless could be seen plainly at the week's end. Second, there was no reasonable prospect for a swift victory by any side.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--The Rev. and Mrs. Bayard Stockton Clark of Washington and Harwichport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Conger Clark, to Tom Forrester Lord. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thurber T. Lord of Dallas.

LAUREL, Miss., Oct. 7 (UPI) --Two striking woodworkers, identified by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as Ku Klux Klan members, were charged with murder today in the sniper slaying of a security guard at the labor-troubled Masonite Corporation plant here last August.
MANHATTAN, Kan. Oct. 7 (AP)--Bill Bomberger's 31-yard field goal with 1 minute 11 seconds left capped a 17-play drive and gave unbeaten Nebraska a 16-14 victory today over Kansas State.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 7 (AP)--Michigan State, bouncing back from two straight nonconference losses, cashed in on the speed of Dwight Lee and Lamarr Thomas today in overpowering Wisconsin, 35-7, in a Big Ten football opener for both teams.
The unbeaten Princeton soccer team scored its fourth consecutive victory yesterday, defeating Columbia, 2-1, at Baker Field.

A MIRROR-LIKE finish that shows no blemishes is the dream of every home furniture finishing enthusiast. In an attempt to achieve this ideal, do-it-yourselfers may buy the finest of brushes and the best quality finishing materials they can find--yet the results are all too often disappointing.

WATERTOWN, Conn., Oct. 7 --Miss Mallory Betts Merriman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heminway Merriman of Watertown and Weekapaug, R.I., was married this evening in Christ Episcopal Church to Richard Wells Constantine of Silver Spring. Md., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wells Wadsworth Constantine of South Orange, N.J., and Weekapaug.
STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 7-- Steve Booth's 9-yard touchdown pass to John Katzenberger with 90 seconds left gave unbeaten Staples of Westport a 14-7 football victory today over Stamford High School.

"Don't drink the water" is no longer the cry among football trainers. Recent research has proved that athletes who replenish the fluids and minerals lost through perspiration have more stamina and react faster in the late stages of football games and other sports.

NAT TURNER may have been the first of the great Negro preacher-reformers, a line that has fanned out since in such different directions as Martin Luther King, Adam Clayton Powell and James Baldwin, the boy-preacher turned, or half-turned, novelist.
Tight money has claimed as one of its biggest victims thus far the sales program of the giant network of Leisure World cooperative complexes designed for people over 52 years old.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 7--Pressure resulting from open housing demonstrations is causing Milwaukee officials to push an unusual plan for a new "village" near the heart of the Negro ghetto.
The roughly 20,000 city income-tax refunds still outstanding will be paid in the "next several weeks" with 6 per cent interest, Roy M. Goodman, City Finance Administrator, said yesterday.
MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Oct. 7--Mountain Lakes upset Glen Ridge, 37-13, today and put an end to a 17-game winning streak.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 7-- With a callous lack of concern for Steve Lindell's ulcer, the Duke football team outfoxed the Army quarterback today and defeated the Cadets by a score of 10-7.

CONCORD, Mass., Oct. 7-- The engagement of Miss Meredith Berry Brenizer to Lieut. Comdr. Kenneth Eugene Cox, U.S.N., has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Marshall Brenizer of Concord and Dr. Addison G. Brenizer Jr. of Charlotte, N.C. Commander Cox is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Cox of Yonkers.
The Federal Maritime Commission has decided that it has the authority to approve merger agreements by competing United States steamship lines.

Mr. and Mrs. F. Cavanagh Jr. of New York and Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nannette Christine Cavanagh, to John Inman Brokaw, son of Mrs. Clifford V. Brokaw of Glen Cove and the late Mr. Brokaw.
WASHINGTON--Events are quietly under way here that could lead to the creation of an effectual Federal fair housing law--not by an act of Congress, but by a de cision of the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7--A playwright was hired a few years ago to produce a movie script for an inarticulate young thing who looked as if she might be marketable on film as a sex goddess. At first meeting he sensed that behind her pout lurked a mind with the voltage of a lima bean.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 7 --St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mary Jane Farnsworth, daughter of Mrs. George Low Farnsworth of Lloyd Harbor, and the late Mr. Farnsworth, to Peter David Walsh. He is the son of Mrs. John Loughran Walsh of Northport, and the late Mr. Walsh.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Oct. 7 (AP)--An alert defense enabled Western Michigan to stop Bowling Green inches short of the goal line in the first quarter and make two interceptions in the fourth quarter today en route to a 10-6 victory over the previously unbeaten Falcons.
Miss Yun Ja Yim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kwang Hak Yim of Seoul, South Korea, has become the fiancee of William Day Lassek, son of Dr. Arthur M. Lassek of Lexington, Mass., and the late Mrs. Lassek.
NEWARK, Oct. 7--The Governor's Select Commission on Civil Disorder has appointed its top staff members in preparation for an inquiry into the causes of the July riots in several New Jersey cities.

THE classic advice of Horace Greeley, "Go West, young man," which led to the present congestion in California, was hardly appropriate for young men born there. Native San Franciscan Robert Frost reversed the dictum, went East and became the great poet of New England. Native Los Angeleno Adlai Stevenson got as far as Illinois, where he became a lifelong disciple of Lincoln.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7 --Carter Lord set a pass-catching yardage record today and Tommy Wynne tied an interception mark as Harvard defeated Boston University's football team, 29-14, before a crowd of 23,000 in Harvard Stadium.
TROY, N.Y., Oct. 7--Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's sixgame winning streak was snapped today by Hamilton, 22-0. Numerous R.P.I. scoring threats were halted by fumbles and interceptions.

"The Dow-Jones industrials are apt to make a run toward the 1,000 mark before the end of this year. The shaky thesis that common stocks are universally good hedges against inflation motivates much of the buying activity."

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 7--Lafayette College's sophomore tailback, Bob Zimmers, ran for 168 yards today to lead the Leopards to victory over Bucknell, 21-6.

Fulbright, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and a leading critic of the policy. Following are excerpts from the exchange:

SAN MATED, Calif., Oct. 7 (UPI)--Albert Sultan's Plimenek, set a Bay Meadows track record of 2:00 3-5 for 1 miles today in winning the San Jose Handicap by a neck. The time beat the previous mark of 2:01 3-5 set on Oct. 25, 1952, by Moonrush.

CANTON, N.Y., Oct. 7 (AP) --A 58-yard touchdown pass from George Penrose to Donnie Martin with slightly more than six minutes remaining to play gained St. Lawrence a 14-14 football tie today with Hobart.

Julian Bond, a member of the Georgia House of Representatives, and David Dellinger, publisher of Liberation magazine, have been named cochairmen of an antiwar demonstration scheduled for Oct. 21 at the Pentagon in Washington it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO--The motion picture showed a large brown and white dog running and wagging her tail. The scene was nothing out of the ordinary, but the dog was. The heart beating inside her chest had been transplanted from another dog more than a year before.

Nelson Briles, a 24-year-old right-hander, pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox in the third game of the World Series yesterday at St. Louis. Briles, with offensive assistance from Mike Shannon and Lou Brock, held the Red Sox to seven hits in a complete-game performance before 54,575 fans at Busch Stadium.

BRUSSELS. GEORGES BIDAULT has turned 68 this month, an age when defeated political figures sometimes like to pass the time with wistful reconstructions of history. In Bidault's recurring fantasy, he is chief of state, and he is reviewing the appeal of General de Gaulle, who has been tried and convicted of political crimes.

ADA, Ohio, Oct. 7 (AP)-- Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, Under Secretary of State, said that to fight crime effectively, "the public must be ready to reject old prejudices, to make difficult choices and to pay for expensive programs."

Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Brandes of the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Brandes, to Arnold Rosenstock, son of Mrs. Philip Rosenstock of Flashing, Queens, and the late Mr. Rosenstock.
OUTSTANDING chess games that sparkle with tactical elan and sophisticated strategy often crop up in unexpected spots.

Neither has the freeze secretly ordered by President Johnson on new contracts for construction, equipment or services between the Federal Government and private industries.

ONE of the dangerous corners Dickens passed in his youth was an audition before a theater manager at which he failed to appear. He was a brilliant dramatic and comic actor, and in love with the stage of his time, tawdry as it was.

LOUDON, N.H., Oct. 7-- The last national championship meeting of the Sports Car Club of America in the Northeast division opened at Bryar Motorsport Park today with 150 cars entered. They participated in a practice session and time trials this afternoon. Nine races are scheduled for tomorrow.

SEATTLE, Oct. 7--Mr. and Mrs. David Edward Stalter have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Graves Stalter, to Robbert Winmill Radsch, son of Mrs. P. Livingston Armstrong of Mill Neck, L.I., and London, and the late Robert Henry Radsch, a lawyer.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 7 (AP)--Florida State recovered a Texas A. and M. fumble on the 27 and scored on the next play to pull out a 19-18 victory tonight and post the Seminoles' first triumph of the season.

DETROIT, Oct. 7 (UPI)-- United Auto Workers delegates will meet in a special national convention tomorrow to pump more than $12-million a month into their strike fund and keep it from being depleted by the strike against the Ford Motor Company.

Skid row residents, including habitues of the Bowery in Manhattan, are rapidly being dispersed by urban renewal and welfare programs to other parts of most cities, according to a study of 29 major skid row areas throughout the country.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Oct. 7 --"Why don't they stick to their business?" Press releases from Gov. Ronald Reagan, Representative Robert B. Mathias and municipal offices in the San Joaquin Valley are asking this question about the California Rural Legal Assistance program, an arm of the Federal antipoverty effort.

TRAVEL agents are planning to offer South America to tourists by bits rather than in bulk. This decision was made at the sixth Inter-American Travel Seminar, which was held recently in Rio de Janeiro. Seminar representatives were from the travel trade.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7-- Plans for construction next March of a $75-million business and financial complex to occupy a square block on Wilshire Boulevard were announced last week by Howard Ahmanson, chairman and president of the Home Savings and Loan Association.

Nearly a fifth of the nation's prime military contracts were awarded to California companies during the fiscal year ended June 30, the Department of Defense announced recently.

PHOENIX, Ariz.--"This town is full of engineers and scientists. They're a funny breed. They work hard and then they want to relax hunting or fishing or boating or picking up rocks. That's why they're all eager to come here to live."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 7-- Don Gault and Jim Thorpe combined on a 72-yard touchdown pass play with a minute and a half left to give unbeaten Hofstra a 33-31 uphill victory over Delaware in a Middle Atlantic Conference football game today.
Dr. Andres C. Uribe, the man in North America for Colombia's coffee growers for 20 years, is about to go into business for himself.
A band of 20 youths smashed into two clothing stores in the garment district early yesterday and looted them of armloads of men's suits, sweaters and shirts.
NUTLEY, N.J., Oct. 7--Mike Welch scored three touchdowns today to lend Nutley to a 38-7 victory over Belleville before 6,000 fans at Park Oval.

Plans are progressing to transform a 200-acre sandbank area into a modern industrial park in Nassau County.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 7 (AP)-- The University of Rochester's bid for a 2-point conversion failed by a yard today and preserved a 13-12 victory for Williams College.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, Oct. 7--Billy Casper, Gay Brewer and 22-year-old Brian Barnes of England led the Alcan golf tournament by two strokes today after three rounds. Each had a total of 212.

FELLING, England, Oct. 6 --In the glass and brick buildings that stretch out here near the River Tyne, a ship rigger is learning to be a barber, a bus driver has taken to carpentry, and a former Royal Air Force corporal is finding out how to fix a television set.
GUADALAJERA, Mexico, Oct. 7 (UPI)--The United States took a 9-6 lead over Canada, the defending champion, in the annual Americas Cup amateur golf tournament today.

The political prophets have wrongly counted Harold Wilson out more than once in his three years as Prime Minister, and they were wrong again last week. A Labor party conference that was widely expected to produce bitter rebellion against Mr. Wilson and his Government turned out quite differently.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 6--On the shore of the Hudson River here is a spanking new marina that boasts an inn with cozy bar and seafood platters, a cabana club and swimming pool, a boutique that sells orange miniskirts and "groovy handbags," and berths for more than 100 pleasure boats with names like Just Lookin and Cee Wee D III.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 7-- Miss Victoria Guy Smith. daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles W.F. Smith, was married here this afternoon to Richard Lloyd Anderson, son of Lawrence M. Anderson of North Westport and Mrs. Elaine Z. Warren of Beverly Hills, Calif.

CINCINNATI--About 80 miles east of here, on State Route 73 near the village of Locust Grove, Ohio, is a sinuous earth embankment nearly a quarter of a mile long. This man-made curiosity represents an enormous serpent in the act of swallowing some food, and it is one of the largest and best-preserved primitive effigy mounds in the United States.

Compensation for top executives working in companies overseas remains below the level of those in the United States but has been rising steadily although not so rapidly in the last few years. This is the conclusion of McKinsey Co., international management consultant, in a survey it has made continuously since 1960.
HOUSTON, Oct. 7--Unde- feated North Carolina State up- set Houston 16-6 tonight.

Percival Goodman is a religious but irreverent architect who will fly almost anywhere to help a congregation planning a new synagogue. A former agnostic who says, "I was converted by Hitler," he has designed many edifices that were rooted deeply in his studies of Biblical history.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 7--Yale beat Connecticut today for the 18th time in 19 games since the intrastate series began in 1948. The score was 14-6 and Yale had to struggle all the way in a game that had more errors than excellence in it.
The National Committee for Responsible patriotism urged yesterday formation throughout the nation of committees to greet servicemen returning from Vietnam on the weekend of Oct. 21-22.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Oct. 7-- Rod Jenkins rode the winners of both open jumper classes at the Gaudeamus Farms horse show today, but his mind was on next Tuesday.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Oct. 7-- The Lawrence High Golden Tornado swept to its second straight victory of the season, 20-13, against Uniondale in Division I of the South Shore League today. The game was televised in the metropolitan area.

GATLINBURG, Tenn.-- Autumn's many forest splashing colors have returned to Great Smoky Mountains National Park. ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 7-- On the wall of the Peace Corps headquarters here there is a large map of Turkey speckled with colored tacks indicating where members of the Corps are stationed.

An attempt to alleviate the shortage of physicians in South Vietnam is being made by the International Rescue Committee, Inc., a voluntary nonsectarian agency, with headquarters at 386 Park Avenue South.

Negotiators for the American Broadcasting Company and the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians resumed contract discussions here yesterday in a meeting arranged by Federal mediators.

LONDON--The Ministry of Transport has this message for British motorists troubled by the new 80milligram drunk-driving law: The legal ration is even less in several other European nations, and some of the penalties are higher.
