CHAMPAIGN, Ill. Oct. 7 (UPI)--Indiana's alert Hoosiers turned two fumble recoveries and a pass interception into touchdowns today in defeating Illinois and winning the Big Ten opener for both teams, 20-7.

RECENTLY, in the course of assembling some notes on a Transvaal tournament golfer, I was reminded of the time Bobby Locke won an international event in this country and the promoters were anxious to enhance the presentation ceremony by displaying the South African flag. They had to abandon the idea. There wasn't one within a thousand miles of the course.

A committee of high-ranking faculty members and some students at Cornell University last week recommended a clean break with the tradition under which the university, like most others, has tried to shelter its students from the law and the police. It proposed that the university confine its disciplinary authority to on-campus misconduct damaging to its educational goals.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 7 (AP)--Purdue's Boilermakers bombed the Northwestern Wildcats with three touchdowns in the final quarter today for a 25-16 victory in the Big Ten football opener for both teams.

Queen of the Stage became the ruler of her realm in winning the $114,475 Frizette Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Ogden Phipps's undefeated filly broke the stakes record of the one-mile event for 2-year-old fillies in beating the Meadow Stable's Gay Matelda by threequarters of a length.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) --Upsala scored a 2-point safety in the closing minutes, tackling Mike Kerwin, a halfback, in the end zone, as the Vikings edged Drexel, 22-20, today.

Herman Lipski, who retired in 1960 as deputy collector of customs here, died Friday night in Phelps Memorial Hospital, Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived at 1701 Old Country Road, Elmsford, N.Y.

THE terrier will have his day at Gwynedd Valley, Pa., today when the 33d annual Montgomery County Kennel Club show will be held on the estate of G. Harrison Frazier Jr., on Swedesford Road. A select committee of the Australian Senate is preparing a report on containerization in all its aspects--the views of Australian and international shipping and transportation agencies, the adequacy of container facilities and the adequacy of present legislation. Housing starts about the same as last year. Agricultural crops better than expected. These were the findings in a pair of Upper Midwest economic surveys last week.

In the little more than six years of the Prime Minister- ship of Clement Richard Attlee from August, 1945, to October, 1951 Britain and the Brit- ish Commonwealth were unalterably changed. Twice as many people now disapprove as approve of President Johnson's way of handling the war in Vietnam, according to a survey by George Gallup reported yesterday in The Washington Post. Mr. Gallup said this was the highest point of disapproval yet registered.

MONTREAL, Oct. 8-One of the rare items of the bel canto revival, Bellini's "I Capuleti e I Montecchi," was La Scala's second entry at Expo 67. The New York Giants beat the New Orleans Saints, 27-21, at Yanke Stadium yesterday. Victory, which should have been easy to achieve, came the hard way. The Giants were tougher on themselves than on the foe as they squandered four ripe scoring chances. They just barely won.

ROME, Oct. 8 (AP) Mother Fortunata Viti, an Italian nun of the Benedictine Order who died 45 years ago, was beatified in St. Peter's Basilica today. Beatification is a step toward sainthood.
Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. said yesterday that so many out-oftowners were dumping truckloads of junk in vacant lots and parks here that he would ask the police to help stop them.

Milva, an exotic, red-haired Italian singer, brought a program of Italian popular music to both Carnegie Hall and Philharmonic Wall this weekend.

Opposing candidates for District Attorney in Queens and the Bronx agreed yesterday that the police have been badly hamstrung by net state law curbing the use of guns in apprehending criminals.

He told of the time, several years ago, when his hospital was deciding whether to purchase physical rehabilitation equipment. Gen.James M. Gavin, considered by many a possible Republican Presidential nominee, has told Newsweek magazine that he regards Governor Rockefeller as "the best candidate."

OSWALD JACOBY of Dallas, one of the greatest figures in the history of bridge, became the first player ever to win 10,000 master points when he won the Open Team Championship in a tournament in Dallas that finished yesterday. If the ace is trumped, the rounders championship of the blinking universe is all over and the Redbirds from St. Loo will have taken it all.

THE critic's life would be greatly simplified if there were only two kinds of play the good and the bad. But in fact plays stubbornly refuse to admit such a categorization, and only people with a "hit-or-miss" mentality are foolish enough to impose on themselves and us what can never be natural. Plays are not to be dismissed as either a hit or miss and producers should possibly ponder over this a little.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 9 There being no greater risk in harness racing than wagering on 2-year-old trotting fillies, the fans on hand for the New York Sire Stakes race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight were unable to bet on any of the 12 juveniles in the one-mile event that was won in 2:11 2-5 by I'm Patty.
A group of Roman Catholic priests has released figures showing that 53.2 per cent of American diocesan priests responding to a poll favor a change in church rules to permit priests to marry.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9--The representatives of seven Governors plan to recommend settlement terms tomorrow in the violent seven-week-old steel hauler strike.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 9 A prominent writer on the Russian Revolution said at a conference today that Marxism was no longer an ideology of consequence in the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the constitutionality of the amendment to the Selective Service Act that makes draft card burning a crime.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 Assemblyman Perry B. Duryea, second vice president of the recent Constitutional Convention, met in the Capitol today with about 40 Republican Assemblymen for what he described as a briefing session on the proposed state constitution.
The election of Philip B. Dalton and Donald L. Sanders as executive vice presidents were among several personnel changes announced here yesterday by the General Aniline and Film Corporation.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 9--Some 750 Yale University students and faculty members conducted a 40-minute "silent vigil" here today against the Vietnam war as Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson had dinner and spoke to the Yale Political Union on "Beautification in America."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 9 King Hussein of Jordan took another step today in the reorganization of his army, defeated by Israeli forces last June.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to review the dismissal of eight antitrust charges against the American Federation of Musicians and its New York branch, Local 802.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 9 (UPI) The space agency reported today, that the first manned launching of the modified Apollo spacecraft was now planned for next July or August.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 When Jim Lonborg strolled to the plate with two out in the seventh inning of today's World Series game, the Cardinal catcher, Tim McCarver, glanced up at the lanky Red Sox pitcher.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (AP)--The St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League traded a left wing, John Brenneman, to the Detroit Red Wings today for a right wing, Craig Cameron, and two amateurs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court turned down today a bid for a new trial by James R. Hoffa, imprisoned president of the Teamsters Union.
ROME, Oct. 9 (AP) A member of the Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops reported today a move to have Pope Paul VI step into the growing controversy over church doctrine.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 (UPI) Jim Lonborg, whose parents from California were in the stands to watch him beat the Cardinals today, prepared for the assignment quietly. He had dinner with his parents last night, talked to them for a while, and then watched television before going to bed.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 9 Home Loan interest rates are unlikely to decline in the foreseeable future and the supply of money available for mortgage lending cannot be expected to increase.

IDEAS are flickering dangerously around the John Golden Theater, where John Bowen's "After the Rain" opened last night, and as ideas may just possibly have been at a premium on Broadway recently they are extraordinarily welcome. Mr. Bowen's play extends the mind-not that far but far enough for us to feel the stretch, and a sensible man will exult in wild moderation.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 9--Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster has renewed his association with the Ossewa-Brandwag, a pro-German wartime organization in which he served.
The city's More Effective Schools program, an issue in the recent contract dispute between the Board of Education and the teachers union, has become involved in a new controversy.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, New York's largest bank, reported yesterday that the three months ended Sept. 30 were the most profitable in its history.

BONN, Oct. 9 Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger today accused Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany of having deliberately blocked East-West German discussion of problems vital to the interests of all German people.
LET the computer spin its tapes and print out the stock market record of American Telephone and Telegraph over the last 25 years or so Growth stock or grandmother of the blue chips?
JERUSALEM, Oct. 9 Plans for the reconstruction of the former Jewish quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem were presented to Mayor Teddy Kollek and the Jerusalem Planning Board today.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 9 (UPI) Gov. Claude B. Kirk Jr. said tonight that President Johnson had overridden the Democratic Site Selection Committee to have the party's 1968 convention in Chicago instead of Miami Beach.

Msgr. John J. O'Donnell, Roman Catholic chaplain of the Port of New York, who was known as the "waterfront priest," died on Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Harrison, N.Y. He would have been 76 years old on Friday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (Reuters) The Democratic National Convention here next summer will be marked by Negro and antiVietnam war protest demonstrations, black power and civil rights leaders predicted today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The United States has refrained so far from bombing the main North Vietnamese air base at Phucyen and the airfield at Gialam, adjacent to Hanoi, to avoid making the North Vietnamese completely dependent on Chinese airfields.

CLEVELAND (AP) Management's slate five directors won re-election without opposition today at the annual meeting of the Pentron Elec tronics Corporation. After the meeting, the board re-elected Harold Ballanoff as president and treasurer as well as other officers of the company.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Oct. 9 Jimmy Turnesa of the Mill River Country Club carded a two-under-par 35, 35 70 today to take a two-stroke lead in the 36-hole Metropolitan Golf Association senior championship at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club.
Is the stock certificate really necessary? The Association of Stock Exchange Firms, a trade group representing 510 broherage firms and members of the New York Stock

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 North Vietnam's leading military strategist says that the vital allied program for winning control of the South Vietnamese countryside has been foiled because the United States has been forced to scatter its troops.
A City Council hearing yesterday on a proposed treatment for narcotics addicts at the Rikers Island Penitentiary turned into a stormy discussion of crime in the streets.
Two men were charged yesterday with murdering a teenaged Connecticut girl and her hippie boy friend during an LSD party in the cellar of an East Village tenement.

PRINCETON scored its third touchdown against Co lumbia last Saturday on a pass from Boo Weber to Mike Garton. The Columbia players failed to see Garton standing alone in a near-sleeper position at the sidelines before the 6-yard pass was thrown. A sleeper play is illegal.
Linda Rea Fitzpatrick, almost everyone who knew her said, was a girl who had everything.
Students at Fordham University demonstrated against naval recruiting officers yesterday, out university officials said the recruiters would be back on the campus today.

Although many youth and neighborhood programs terminated at summer's end, poverty and aimlessness continue on a year-round basis. The heat is over in the streets, but the frustration goes on. Once kindled, hope is a hard emotion to turn off.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 A Senate subcommittee carved out a new Redwoods National Park proposal today. It included a plan to exchange Forest Service land in California for private timberland.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 The Federal Government, after some second thoughts, reaffirmed today its decision to require shoulder harnesses as standard equipment on passenger cars.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 The Washington Senators have given the New York Mets permission to talk to Gil Hodges about managing the Mets next year.

MOSPORT, Ont., Oct. 9 (Canadian Press) Bill Brack of Clarkson, Ont., won the 90-lap Canadian Touring Trophy race in a Mini-Cooper today. He was followed by Dick Brown of Montreal in a Mustang and Gordon Dewar of Ottawa, who drove a Camaro.
Steven Kessler, accused of murdering his mother-in-law, told a jury in Brooklyn yesterday of "deep fears," visions of a roof splitting and days of amnesia after he had used LSD.

Master of a pellucid and colorful prose style, prolific and versatile, Andr Maurois was among the most widely known French writers of his day. He was a jack of almost all genres biography, history, diction, essays and criticism of manners. Biography, however, was his true genius and the basis for his enduring reputation.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 9 The Detroit Pistons scored their second straight exhibition basketball victory over the New York Knicks tonight, 112-99. Dave Bing led the winners with 30 points.
The Marine Midland Trust Company of Western New York, Buffalo, announced yesterday several top management changes.
HONOLULU, Oct. 9 The authorities placed an embargo today on interisland movement of pets in an effort to confine Hawaii's first outbreak of rabies to the heavily populated island of Oahu.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 A Senate Judiciary subcommittee approved today a bill that would attack racial and economic discrimination in the Federal courts by providing for random selection of juries.

"Montgomercy Place," a 162-year-old Federal-style mansion in Annandale-onHudson, N.Y., will be the historical high point of a daylong tour through upper Dutchess County to be held Saturday by the Canadian Women's Club of New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10 The United States command said today that 3,000 more marines had been sent to the area of the demilitarized zone and that a new base was being built beyond the range of North Vietnamese guns.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 9 A trustee of the Farmingdale Public Library who admitted having confiscated a copy of a literary quarterly in the library because he considered an article in it obscene was found guilty of petit larceny today.
ABU SIMBEL, United Arab Republic--The great temples of the Pharaohs that were dismantled and moved to higher ground to escape flooding from the Aswan Dam project are back together again.

A.W. Tarkington, president of the Continental Oil Company, said yesterday that the company was entering into a consent settlement with the Federal Trade Commission in accordance with procedures of the commission concerning the 1964 acquisition of the Thompson Company by Continental and its participation in a joint vinyl chloride plant with the Stauffer Chemical Company.
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company regards strict air pollution laws as "a real opportunity" for growth, John E. Heyke, Jr., president, said yesterday.
The 22d National Hardware Show opened here yesterday at the New York Coliseum, with "more" an apparent byword.

ATLANTA, Oct. 9 Mrs. Ruby Doris Smith Robinson a founder and former executive secretary of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, died Saturday in her home. She was 26 years old and had been ill for 10 months with a rare blood disease.
Hundreds of people from diplomacy, art, finance and society filled the Museum of Modern Art last night to pay tribute to Pablo Picasso the sculptor.
Steel production fell last week, compared with output the week before, but the decline was not so large as the industry had feared in view of two major strikes.

In proposing formulation of a new global strategy for economic development, the Government of the Netherlands has called attention to the inadequacy of aid and assistance in what has been officially and optimistically labeled the Development Decade. This is true despite the fact that the pledges made yesterday at the United Nations Development Program topped the previous record.

LLOYD HARBOR, L.I, Oct. 9 Residents of this secluded, North Shore village have been advised that the Long Island Lighting Company would like to build a nuclear power plant on a prime waterfront tract here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Peter Green, the Michigan state amateur champion, sank a four-foot birdie putt on the first extra hole yesterday to win the 65th Middle Atlantic amateur golf championship at Columbia Country Club.
PARIS, Oct. 9 Andr Maurois, one of France's most celebrated writers and a member of the French Academy, died early this morning at a clinic in suburban Neuilly at the age of 82.

Mayor Lindsay spent an hour and a half yesterday scolding doormen for permitting tenants and guests to park illegally, praising porters and sanitation workers for doing a good job and demanding that a physician remove his doubleparked car from in front of his office.

One section of the waterfront's controversial seniority system the practice under which longshoremen who joined the work force only last year can be hired ahead of older men with higher seniority ratings was temporarily set aside yesterday.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Tuesday, Oct. 10 Hotel bars in New Zealand switched from a 6 P.M. to a 10 P.M. ing time last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9--The Agency for International Development intends to reduce its budget for medical aid to South Vietnam this year despite recommendations to the contrary from a team of prominent American physicians who recently surveyed South Vietnamese medical needs.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Oct. 9 (AP) South Africa's sensation, Bobby Cole, turned in a one-under-par 71 today to lead a dwindling field of young golfers battling for the right to play the rich 1968 Professional Golfers' Association tour.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 9 (AP) Steve Stonebreaker of the Saints said today he expected to get a reprimand and fine from the National Football League Commissioner, Pete Rozelle, because of the fight that followed the New OrleansGiant game in New York yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 9 A few hours before Elizabeth Taylor wiggled into a long pink velvet evening dress and had a million-dollar diamond tiara anchored on the top of her head, she began to brood about buttons: 14 little pearl buttons on the erminetrimmed waist-length cape that matched the dress.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 The World Series came alive today with a brilliantly played ballgame that bubbled with ex citement and suspense. The Red Sox also came alive. The man who restored them to sufficient health to return the tournament to Boston was Jim Lonborg, a quondam premedical student at Stanford.
"Johnny No-Trump" closed after its premiere Sunday night at the Cort. It had given 10 previews.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city might expand its program to control water pollution by as much as $460-million beyond the $600million already proposed to clean up its waterways.

When someone suggests that private aviation really ought to confine its "small pastime" to the rural areas and leave the skies over cities to the airlines, Robert B. Ward is inclined to take tolerant exception.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 9 The creation of an international consortium to distribute school aid to underdeveloped countries should be "seriously considered," a world conference of educators declared today.

Andre Maurois, one of the "forty immortals" of the French Academy, held in his life and writings a special affection for the United States. From his first visit in the 1920's through lectures and books that commented about this country into the 1960's, he never wavered in his friendship and wonder about the essence of America.

The Vienna Symphony Orchestra gave the second of its two local concerts last night in Carnegie Hall and paid New York the honor of a world premiere Alfred Uhl's Concerto a ballo. It was dedicated to the ensemble and its conductor, Wolfgang Sawallisch, and written for performance during their current world tour.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Bernard B. Spindel, a New York er recognized as an expert on wiretapping, was refused today a Supreme Court review of a Massachusetts eavesdropping conviction.

The University of Southern California, after having crushed Stanford, 30-0, for its fourth straight victory, tightened its grip on the No. 1 position yesterday in the weekly Associated Press poll of football writers and broadcasters and the United Press International balloting by coaches.

Joseph H. Pilates, a physical culturist who developed a system of body conditioning he called "contrology," died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 939 Eighth Avenue, where he had operated his gymnasium, or "studio," for 40 years.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct. 9 (UPI) Four Cabinet members resigned today after the government imposed special security measures to combat what was described by officials here as a grave Government crisis.
Time magazine began yesterday a separate weekly television section.

Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Straus of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Susan Straus, to Dr. James Leberman, son of Mrs. Roy H. Peralta of Oakland, Calif., and the late Arthur R. Lieberman.
Negotiations between the American Broadcasting Company and the striking National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians continued here yesterday.

Support for the Johnson Administration's new plan for building up underdeveloped countries to the point where they can feed their own people, rather than depend on give-away programs, was urged yesterday by Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman.

NASHVILLE, Oct. 9 (AP) A three-judge Federal court complimented the Nashville police today on their handling of the April 3-10 riots this year. It refused to declare unconstitutional those state and local laws under which 68 riot arrests were made. The laws concern rioting, disturbing the peace and similar charges.

Longshoremen cannot be penalized for passing up job opportunities under the guaranteed annual 1,600 hours of working time, if other dockworkers fill all the job slots offered by a steamship or stevedoring company, a leading maritime arbitrator ruled yesterday.

Life magazine is expected to publish an editorial next week in which it calls for a temporary halt in the bombing of North Vietnam. According to reports, the editorial, which would be published in the issue dated Oct. 20, will suggest the step in the hope it will lead to peace talks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its June 12 decision upholding a $460,000 libel judgment won by Wallace Butts, former athletic director at the University of Georgia, against the Curtis Publishing Company.

LONDON. Oct. 9 Not long ago a West Indian immigrant here tried to buy a house in a section of London called Croydon. The sale was agreed to and a mortgage arranged when two prospective neighbors stepped in with cash and bought the house before the West Indian could close the deal.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 9 A call for Congress to adopt a goal of two million new housing units annually for 20 years was issued here today by Prederic A. Fay, president of the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 Yields on the new issues of Treasury bills moved in diverse directions at this week's auction, with those on the 91day bills rising slightly and those on the 182-day bills falling.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 9 Rich countries and poor pledged record contributions today to the 1968 United Nations Development Program, which helps the poorer nations attract foreign investment and technology.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 9 Dr. Gordon Willard Allport, the psychologist, died today of lung cancer in the Stillman Infirmary of Harvard University. He was 69 years old and lived in Watertown.
MADRID, Oct. 9--Spain is scheduled to hold tomorrow her first direct parliamentary election since the civil war began 31 years ago. Interparty politics will be ruled out.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AF) Negro soldiers re-enlisted a three times the rate of white soldiers last year, Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor said today.
BISMARCK, N.D. Those who wince when they re flect on dining in what Easterners call the hinterlands might do well to come to Bismarck.

THE chilling possibility of a national data center that would make a permanent recording of every individual's personal and financial record from birth to death was discussed in last night's hour called "The Right of Privacy." The program was produced by National Educational Television and shown at 9 P.M. over Channel 13.

Charles D. Francis, a retired women's garment manufacturer, died Sunday in Kew Gardens General Hospital after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 68-61 Yellowstone Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens.

The president of the University of Notre Dame said yesterday that the Roman Catholic institution would seek to engage Hindu, Jewish, Buddhist and other spiritual leaders throughout the world in "conversations."

The president of City College said yesterday that construction of prefabricated classrooms and offices on a campus site objected to by students would probably halt today for two weeks. He proposed that the time be used to consider alternate sites.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 9 Sinking 10-foot birdie putts at the fifth and 14th holes, Mrs. James Whelan carded a 37, 39 76 today and took a twostroke opening-round lead in the seventh annual Garden State Women's Golf Association 54-hole championship at her home club, Springdale.
BONN, Oct. 9 The West German Defense Ministry unveiled today in Augsburg a prototype of the Main Battle Tank of the nineteen-seventies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The Army Corps of Engineers admitted today that it was helping to pollute Lake Michigan, and said that it would probably have to continue doing so at least through 1970.

A majority of Republican leaders polled by The Associated Press favor Richard M. Nixon for the Presidential nomination in 1968 but feel the "strongest ticket" would be the combination of Governor Rockefeller and Gov. Ronald Reagan of California.
LONDON, Oct. 10 The growing "brain drain" of young scientists and engineers is threatening disastrous consequences in Britain, a special committee reported to the Government today.

LONDON, Oct. 10 Britain bolstered her declining foreign exchange reserves today by accepting an unusual loan from three Swiss banks equivalent to about $104 million. The form of the loan was 450-million Swiss francs, for 12 months at a rate of 5 per cent.
THE TOP PEOPLE at Swift Co. were reported to be tickled as pink as a lamb chop over the massive trade that brought a new and enthusiastic institution into the corporation's family of stockholders.

Something new is being added to the economic forecasts for 1968, now in preparation. Economists are cranking in an allowance for cessation of the war in Vietnam, or at least for a leveling off. Few are willing to base their principal forecast on this assumption. But a number are coming up with alternative forecasts, acknowledging it as a distinct possibility'.

Betty Furness, who has found that the articulate consumer's major gripe is the lack of proper service for his car or appliance, called on the advertising industry yesterday to induce more American youngsters to become repair men.

PARIS, Oct. 10 Even in Saint-Germain-des-Pres, people often stare at Paloma Picasso although her hair is no longer and her skirts no shorter than anyone else's. They do not stare at her because she has a strong, sweet face or because they know that she is the 18-year-old daughter of Pablo Picasso.
SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 10 Mrs. Thomas B. Crawford has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Doreen Joyce Crawford, to James Landale Dun, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Landale Dun.

DUBLIN, Oct. 10--A dramatization of Brendan Behan's recollections of his prison years, "Borstal Boy," had its first performance at the Abbey Theater tonight as part of the Dublin Festival.

MADRID, Oct. 10 Spanlards voted today to choose 19 per cent of the deputies to the Cortes (parliament) from among candidates running on the slate Of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's National Movement.

TWENTY or thirty years ago there flourished in the United States what Virgil Thomson called "the musicappreciation racket." Those behind it felt, doubtless sincerely, that to interest a large public in serious music, they had to make serious music "interesting." What better way to do so than to introduce us to the man behind the music, the composer?
Persuasion, rather than prosecution, is the emphasis of an experimental program the city started yesterday to convince landlords that they should obey the housing code.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10?The chairman of the House Interior Committee announced today that his panel would consider the $768-million water plan for Arizona early next year.

A psychiatrist testified yesterday that Stephen Kessler was insane last year at the time he is charged with murdering his mother-in-law. Mr. Kessler, a 32-year-old former medical student who took LSD, has sworn that he does not remember the crime for which he is now on trial in Brooklyn.
The search for revenge will start tonight as the National Hockey League opens its longest season and its first under expansion.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 10 A Federal judge ordered the Kokomo. Ind., school system today to close a predominantly Negro grade school.
Kennedy International Airport was shrouded by fog early yesterday that caused delays of up to two hours for flights from overseas.

J. William Middendoff 2d looked up nervously from "a dark blue notebook last night and launched the latest innovation at the Metropolitan Museum of Art having the art collector explain his choices to the public.

More than 600 persons attended a rally of the Coalition for a Democratic Alternative last night, billed in advance as a planning session for a "dump Johnson" campaign. The rally was held at the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 United States officials reacted cautiously today to Bolivian reports that Ernesto Che Guevara had been killed in an ambush.

The evidence that, Ernesto Che Guevara was killed in Bolivia suggests to many Latin Americans that Cuba's policy of fomenting guerrilla operations as the road to "anti-imperialist" revolution in the Western Hemisphere has reached a low point.

PARIS, Oct. 10 The Governmenr of Premier Georges Pompideu won a victory in the National Assembly tonight when a motion of censure obtained 207 votes, 37 short of the required majority. The motion had been submitted Jointly by the Communists and the non-Communist Left.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The Peace Corps, cut off from its source of doctors by the new draft law, has begun an intensive nationwide campaign to recruit them on its own to serve two-year overseas hitches caring for the volunteers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration, responding to inquiries it said came from consumers, says there is no scientific evidence to show that widely used artificial sweeteners are a hazard to health.

Gulf and Western Industries, in a surprise move, reached an agreement late yesterday to purchase 1,419,133 shares of Universal American Corporation common stock for a combination of cash, notes and convertible debentures of Gulf and Western.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 President Johnson invited the Soviet Union today to help end the waste of "competitive spacemanship" by cooperating with the United States on at least some aspects of space exploration.
MIAMI, Oct. 10 Two passengets were killed and six others were injured yesterday when a Costa Rican jet airliner was buffeted by severe turbulence during a flight from Costa Rica: to Miami.
A union representing 400 service, clerical and technical employes at Harlem Hospital threatened yesterday to go on strike tomorrow in a contract dispute.
NYACK, N. Y., Oct. 10 The head of the Rockland County chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality was arrested here last night for allegedly threatening the father of an 18year-old girl.

WITH this, the 10th volume in their history of civilization, the Durants (Mr. and Mrs.) complete a labor that has spanned 40 years, involved migrations to all parts of the planet and demanded an inordinate amount of organizing and ordering of material, to say nothing of the writing.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Oct. 10 An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation described in court today the discovery of the bodies of three slain civil rights workers who disappeared near Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964.
Stress ethics in business today, avoid government curbs tomorrow.

Details of plans for a new organization devoted to "amore sensible policy" in Vietnam will be disclosed at the National Press Club, Washington, on Wednesday, Oct. 25, according to former Senator Paul H. Douglas, Democrat of Illinois.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10--Ignoring the general Congressional clamor for budget cuts, the Senate passed today a $4.77-billion public works money bill after refusing to trim... it sharply.
PURCHASE, N. Y., Oct. 10 Not even fog and rain could stop the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association senior championship from completing its appointed round today.

There was a time when President Johnson carried the results of the latest public opinion polls around in his pocket and whipped them out to convince doubters how popular he and his policies were. A White House staff assistant was kept busy almost full time staying in touch with the pollsters and receiving private analyses of their data.

In a sound-drenched Lower Manhattan loft building that was enlivened by revolving painted disks, film projections, floating pillows and miniskirted girls in paper smocks, representatives of industry and labor joined a number of artists and scientists yesterday to proclaim a "working alliance" between art and technology.

Dr. Raymond Mandra, professor emeritus of the classics at Hunter College, died Monday at the Flushing Hospital and Medical Center, in Queens. He was 72 years old and lived at 161-01 32d Avenue, Flushing.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay Contemporary England or Scandinavia might well take a long southwesterly look at Uruguay while murmuring: "There but for the grace of God go I." For Uruguay is the welfare state gone wild, and this fact, at last acknowledged by the Government, brought about today's political crisis and the declaration of a state of emergency.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10 United States Navy pilots today bombed a military area in the suburbs of Haiphong where, a spokesman said, the North Vietnamese assembled and stored helicopters and missiles.
THE legendary Knute Rockne often was credited with having used psychological warfare to whip Notre Dame into the proper frame of mind to beat the opposition.

The Little Orchestra Society opened its 20th season last night in Philharmonic Hall in characteristic fashion by introducing to this country a neglected opera of the past. It was Busoni's "Turandot," which dates back to 1917.
The Metropolitan Opera's casting department works in mysterious ways its occasional wonders to perform.

Detectives searched through taverns, hippie coffeehouses and rooming houses yesterday for a fourth man wanted in the murder of a wealthy Connecticut girl and her drifter boy friend during an LSD party in the East Village.
GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 10 Linda Rae Fitzpatrick was buried today in a ceremony reflecting the discreet affluence that had sheltered her for most of her life.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy's secretary denied a report yesterday that Mrs. Kennedy would soon announce her engagement to Lord Harlech, the former David Ormsby-Gore.
EAST MEADOW, L. I., Oct., 10 Governor Rockefeller criss-crossed Nassau County today, campaigning for the election of Sol Wachtler, the Republican candidate for County Executive.

THE Conrad Marca-Relli retrospective now at the Whitney Museum of American Art is an extremely handsome affair, summarizing this artist's development since 1952. The date means that Mr. Marca-Relli, who was born in 1913 and is an alumnus of Works Progress Administration projects initiated in 1935, is represented by only that sequence of works that has brought him to his present eminence.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 The nation's railroads announced here today their adoption of a new automatic freight-car identification system to be installed along their tracks to monitor the 1.8 million freight cars in their fleet.
MOSCOW, Oct. 10 The Soviet Government announced today a budget for 1968 that promises more guns as well as more butter.
The newest darling of Wall Street's match-makers is the Amphenol Corporation, a producer of electronic components and equipment based in Chicago.

In common with several other parts of the proposed new State Constitution, which we are analyzing in some detail in a series of editorials, Article II on suffrage combines substantial improvements over the existing article with some serious defects. The weaknesses more than counterbalance the merits.

Miss Julienne Barbara Hewett has become affianced to Nathaniel Franklin Emmons. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Jack Hewett of Melbourne, Australia, and Mrs. Gardner Emmons of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Jamestown, R.I., and Mr. Emmons of Boston and Monument Beach, Mass.

THE world of tournament bridge conceals a strange science that has nothing to do with the technique of the game. It deals with the esoteric complexities of organization, which are far and away more difficult than those required in any other game or sport.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 The Democratic National Committee arranged this week to challenge any wayward Democratic doves who refuse to support President Johnson in next year's nominating convention and election, and this has naturally raised questions here about how the challenge would be made.

THE seemingly superfluous extravagance of further enlarging "Gone With the Wind" so that this almost four-hour-long film classic will suitably fit the radical proportions of the contemporary "large" screen should prove to, have been a shrewd maneuver for other benefits than greater image size and magnification of the soundtrack afforded by the 70 mm. prints.
NEWARK, Oct. 10 Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey today drove the first pile into the ground at Newark Airport to signal the start of construction of a new terminal and runway complex.

European shipowners who are seeking a curtailment of the powers of the Federal Maritime Commission want the best of all possible worlds, John Harllee, chairman of the regulatory agency, said yesterday.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell sharply yesterday in active trading. Brokers blamed the decline on profit taking and noted that there was little in the economic news to provoke the sell-off.

ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (AP) The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. says he will go to jail "willingly and in clear conscience" following the Supreme Court's rejection of his appeal from a five-day sentence for a demonstration in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963.

The United Fruit Company recorded a sharp increase in earnings in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, reflecting primarily the higher income from its banana enterprises, according to the report issued yesterday from the company's home office in Boston.

A soldier-archeologist who rather than make history on the battlefield preferred to resurrect it from ancient dust, described highlights of his most telling no military campaign yesterday at the Jewish Museum.
Stock prices fell yesterday in an afternoon sell-off that produced the broadest decline in four months.
Several executive changes designed to streamline its carbonated beverages operation were announced yesterday by the Canada Dry Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 A proposal to cut the Government's planned spending this year by 3 per cent in every agency subject to reversal only upon a Presidential finding of "urgent national interest" was made today by a key Senator.
The Waterfront Commission yesterday obtained an injunction that forbids a recurrence of disorders at its Port Newark hiring center that had halted hiring at the center earlier in the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1967 corn crop at a record 4,717,422,000 bushels, up 15 per cent from the record last year, in a report which also forecast new all-time highs in production of wheat and soybeans.

More than 100 New Yorkers, ranging from nationally prominent business and labor leaders to local figures best known in the slums where they live and work, were organized yesterday into the New York Coalition to combat slum problems.

Loew's Theatres, Inc. is planning to expand its hotel, theatre and real estate operations through the acquisition of another service-oriented business, Laurence A. Tisch, president and chairman, disclosed yesterday.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 10 (AP) Seventeen of the 40 or more men aboard the freighter Panoceanic Faith, which sank swiftly in the frigid North Pacific yesterday, had been accounted for tonight as search and rescue efforts continued. Five were rescued and 12 were found dead.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 10 A State Supreme Court justice saved 10 pinball machines at least temporarily from a policeman's ax today and volunteered to shoot a few games himself to test whether they were gambling instruments under the new state Penal Code.
MONTREAL, Oct. 9 La Scala presented Verdi's "Nabucco" last night, and it was the performance that all admirers of the company had been waiting for. This was grand opera, this was La Scala.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 10 A modest revival in the economic activity of Western Europe is under way, but planners are wondering whether there will be a full-scale recovery.

Four local newsmen who crossed a technicians' union's picket line at the American Broadcasting Company were fined a total of $48,000 yesterday by their own union, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

ROME, Oct. 10 Two speakers regarded as expressing the viewpoint of Pope Paul VI urged the Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops today to defend authority and orthodoxy against undisciplined theological speculation.

The engagement of Miss Elizabeth Starr McClintock to Jacques Andre Istel, son of Mrs. Andre Istel of New York and the late Mr. Istel has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John T. McClintock of New York and Salisbury, Conn.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. ll President-elect Nguyen Van Thieu promised today a broadened search for peace but he said that if it failed, his Govern ment would intensify the war.

TORONTO, Oct. 11--The Canadian Government, concerned that anti-inflation measures to date may be inadequate, is planning to supplement them with an Americanstyle program of guidelines for voluntary wage and price restraint.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 11-- Money flowed like buttermilk tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, where a total of $184,872.59 was disbursed on a nine-race card that included three stakes events. The main attraction was the Belle Acton Pace, which offered $29,922.59.

THE Czech Philharmonic, ever welcome to New York, appeared last night in the Carnegie Hall International Festival of Visiting Orchestras. A good-sized but by no means sold-out house attended.

BOSTON, Oct. 11--A homerun barrage of record dimensions and plenty of other hits brought the Boston Red Sox an 8-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today and sent the World Series into a seventh and deciding game. It will be played at Fenway Park here tomorrow.

Stephen Kessler took LSD a few hours before he allegedly murdered his mother-in-law in Brooklyn last year, according to testimony at his trial yesterday.

The State Health Department, in a random survey, has found general obsolescence an staff shortages in 18 small voluntary hospitals here, but the report said the situation was not so bad as in the municipal hospitals.

BOSTON, Oct. 11--Bob Gibson, who was wearing a red jacket and sipping an orange drink while sitting in the unhappy St. Louis Cardinals' dressing room this afternoon, said: "Rest is something that's not too important at this stage. You'll find a little extra-- somewhere."
Directors of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation proposed here yesterday a 2-for-1 stock split of the common shares.

MIAMI, Oct. 11--Rear Adm. Albert Cushing Read, who in 1919 commanded a lumbering Navy-Curtiss flying boat that made the first successful trans-Atlantic flight, died here yesterday. He was 80 years old and had retired in 1949.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 11--Although Syracuse leads in the race for the Lambert Trophy with three successive football victories, Ben Schwartzwalder is skeptical of his team's prospects of finishing at the top in the East.
A major rift has developed in the ranks of senior management at the Franklin National Bank, which has resulted in the ouster of one of its vice chairmen, John P. De Santis.
The police continued their search yesterday for an unidentified fourth man wanted for questioning in the murder of a Connecticut girl and her hippie boy friend in an East Village tenement basement.

LONDON--This lovely old city seems to swing along nowadays with the sprightly step and saucy air of the miniskirted girls on King's Road. The beat here seems strictly Beatles, although Britannia will still have a go at ruling the waves when the chance appears.

If there was any conspiracy in Lee Harvey Oswald's assassination of President Kennedy, the Bulletin of the New York Academy of Medicine says, it was "Oswald as a conspirator against his own parents, his own family--against himself."
When the subjects are 44 of what the Wally F. Galleries refers to as "the internationl fashionables," and the painter is a suave Spanish-born artist, the answer requires some discretion.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11--The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported today that the world food situation remained critical because output in the developing countries was still lagging behind population increases.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 11-- Dr. William V. Silverberg, a major figure in psychoanalysis and a founder of the Academy of Psychoanalysis, died yesterday at the White Plains Center for Nursing Care after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 190 Hillair Circle.

The New York Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it had "reluctantly" decided to oppose the proposed state constitution, primarily because it would eliminate the present ban on aid to churchsupported schools.
Capturing local color in New York can lead to complications. Consider the adventures in Greenwich Village yesterday of the people filming Sidney Poitier's new picture, "For the Love of Ivy."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11--The bruises have healed and the mosquito bites are forgotten, but 13 diplomats and their families still talk about their 5,000-mile trip by trailer across the United States.
