Despite Marshall McLuhan's bleak predictions about the printed word, more people will be reading "more and better newspapers" in the coming decade than ever before, Lord Thomson of Fleet said yesterday.

The American Broadcasting Company is about to complete a purchase of at least 30 recently released films from Columbia Pictures, including such major productions as "The Cardinal," "Cat Ballou," "Lord Jim" and "Dr. Strangelove."

CHICAGO, Oct. 11--After taking, almost meekly, the best bumps and grinds the Chicago Black Hawks could throw in the opening period tonight, the New York Rangers slashed back with three goals in each of the last two periods and routed the ...
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 12--United States infantrymen, exploring a complex of tunnels and bunkers, have uncovered a major enemy supply cache in a jungle 30 miles east of Saigon.
LONDON, Oct. 11--Sir Cyril Hinshelwood, who shared a Nobel Prize for chemistry in 1956 for his "researches into the mechanism of chemical reaction," died at his home here on Monday. His age was 70.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 11 (AP)--Vice President Humphrey played the role of teacher and pupil today, exhorting 10,000 farm boys to improve their country and then listening to the observations of former President Harry S. Truman.
Thomas C. Campbell, publisher of Iron Age magazine, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 1120 North Avenue in New Rochelle, N.Y.
ALGIERS, Oct. 11--The "third world" conference on trade and development was disrupted today when Algeria barred South Vietnam and South Korea from its meetings.
A program to provide free legal services to the city's poor has been approved by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Oct. 11--Maj. Gen. Thomas H. Lipscomb testified today that he had changed practices related to courts-martial while he was the commanding officer at Fort Leonard Wood, near St. Louis.

The predominant impression conveyed by Secretary McNamara in his testimony before the Senate Preparedness Subcommittee, which has just been released, is his dissatisfaction with the effectiveness of the bombing of North Vietnam. This dissatisfaction evidently reached such proportions last spring that the Secretary of Defense called on the Joint Chiefs of Staff and General Westmoreland to consider limitation of the bombing largely to the southern half of North Vietnam.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 11-- The United States Government will participate through the Commodity Credit Corporation to the extent of $21.8-million in a new company being formed to take over the assets and liabilities of Intra Bank, largest of Lebanese banks, which closed its doors a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11-- The hopes for an early settlement of the seven-week-old steel hauler strike received today what could be a fatal blow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11-- Some Congressional sentiment appeared to be building up today for a comprehensive study of speculation in the securities markets--with emphasis on the role of the big institutional investors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11-- How many school children being driven to distraction this very day about that tiresome old sailor, Columbus, realize that Europe was discovered by Americans before America was discovered by Columbus?

BARBRA STREISAND'S third television special, "The Belle of 14th Street," was an embarrassing outing, a concoction of deranged productions that not even the star and her major colleague of the evening, Jason Robards, could straighten out.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11--Adnan Pachachi of Iraq warned the General Assembly today that a new war in the Middle East would be inevitable if the United Nations failed to act.

Subway and bus fares for almost one million city residents 65 years old or over would be reduced to 10 cents during nonrush hours under a plan Mayor Lindsay is expected to present soon to the Transit Authority.
With unerring musicality, Sophie Sollberger, flutist, and Robert Miller, pianist, carried the listener happily along through a variety of music last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
NEWARK, Oct. 11 (AP)-- Nine students were injured and a dozen others were arrested today in the second consecutive day of fighting at Barringer High School here.

BOSTON, Oct. 10--The Red Sox, a gungho ball club if there ever was one, continue to pile one incredibility atop another. Insuperable obstacles faze them not a whit. Such is their magic touch that they have tossed the World Series into a seventh and deciding game. This was as unexpected as was the glorious sunshine that flooded Fenway Park today.

Brunch of the Tartan Stable won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, to the satisfaction of the favorite-players in the crowd of 21,163 fans. Ridden by Dave Hidalgo and carrying 114 pounds, Brunch took the one-mile race by two ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) --Republicans in the House of Representatives called today for creation of an independent maritime administration to increase the size of the United States merchant fleet, which Republican Minority Leader Gerald R. Ford said "has been sinking fast."
An alleged million-dollar-a-year racket involving kickbacks to welfare supervisors and caseworkers, paid by companies specializing in the moving of Brooklyn relief clients, is under investigation.
A Government-sponsored commission said yesterday it should be a national policy to promote drinking in a family setting to help prevent the development of problem drinkers.
ROME, Oct. 11--The Roman Catholic hierarchy was called upon today to give greater freedom and autonomy--but matching responsibility--to the lay members of the church.

The American Ballet Theater, under the direction of Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith, is interrupting its nationwide tour for a special two-week stand at the New York City Center of Music and Drama, starting Nov. 28.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11--Substantial numbers of Americans may be doomed to lives of mediocrity because of minor and undetectable damage they sustained before they were born, a pioneer in radiation protection research suggested today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11-- The State Department disclosed today that the United States had taken the initiative in seeking Ambassador Goldberg's meeting here with Ambassador Dobrynin on the Arab-Israeli dispute.

The Metropolitan Opera revived "Le Nozze di Figaro" last night after three seasons' absence, virtually recast it, threw in a couple of debuts, gave it a new conductor and came up with one of the most amiable and appealing productions the Mozart work has had here in some time.
The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest office equipment producer, is nearing its fifteenth consecutive year of record profits.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) --Retail sales rose fractionally during September to a record of $26,688,000,000, the Commerce Department reported today.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 11-- Premier Levi Eshkol said today that the Soviet Union had replaced 80 per cent of the planes, tanks and artillery the United Arab Republic lost during the six-day war in June.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11-- Legislation aimed at removing "inequities" remaining in the nation's immigration policies was introduced in Congress today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11 --The Radio Corporation of America showed here today for the first time a new use of television and laser technology that may one day have far-reaching effects in the fields of transmitting and copying images with extremely high resolution.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 11--Military men will hold no more than two or possibly three posts in President-elect Nguyen Van Thieu's Cabinet, high Government sources reported today.
DETROIT, Oct. 11--The Ford Motor Company today promoted two of its top officers to the rank of executive vice president.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 11--An attempt to prepare a new Communist guerrilla front in Central America appears to have been smashed in the northern mountains here.
LONDON, Oct. 11--Prime Minister Wilson won libel damages today for the publication of a sketch suggesting that he was having an affair with his secretary.
PURCHASE, N.Y., Oct. 11-- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club won the 17th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association senior championship today.
GILBERT RAY HODGES, who was signed yester day as the new manager of the Mets, possesses two qualities indispensable to his task --strength and the gift of inspiring players.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 11 --The mystery of who piloted a small plane in its mid-air collision with a jetliner here last July 19, remained unsolved as a three-day safety hearing ended today.
Joseph MacCaulay, for many years an actor on the musical and dramatic stage, collapsed on the street last Friday and was dead on arrival at Bellevue Hospital. He was 76 years old.
MERIDIAN, Miss., Oct. 12-- A former member of the Ku Klux Klan quietly described in Federal court today his role in the slaying of three young civil rights workers near Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964.

MADRID, Oct. 12--Madrid's leading newspaper, A.B.C., accused the Spanish regime today of failure to enforce a "prudent neutrality" by the provincial authorities in the parliamentary election Tuesday. The paper, which is the chief spokesman for the monarchist cause in Spain, said in an editorial that while the elections in Madrid had been free of official pressures, "unfortunately, we cannot say the same of the other Spanish provinces."

VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 12 (AP)--Gary Player advanced to the semi-finals today of the Piccadilly world matchplay golf championship as a penknife was produced by a spectator to dig open the decisive hole.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 12--A movement developed rapidly today to postpone the General Assembly's scheduled debate on the Middle East as hopes rose for decisive action by the Security Council.
The further adventures of Cinderella, as related to youngsters in Boston last night:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12-- The chairman of the House subcommittee that is holding hearings on legislation to reduce mutual-fund charges to investors said today that he was not sure that the fund industry's objections to the legislation were based on sufficiently detailed analysis.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12--The Soviet Union today approved an extension of military service and the training of more citizens, including high school boys, but coupled them with a one-year cut in the term of compulsory service.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12-- Efforts to settle the violent steel hauler strike hit another obstacle today when a major employer group demanded changes in a settlement plan that strike leaders have accepted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) --The Food and Drug Commissioner, James Goddard, said today that much of the research conducted by the nation's drug companies was "poorly executed" and undoubtedly contributed to high prices.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 12 (AP)--Nat Pendleton, a character actor who appeared in 94 motion pictures, died last night in a La Jolla hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 72 years old.

MOSCOW, Oct. 12 (Reuters) --Adm. Ivan S. Isakov, a Czarist naval academy graduate who rose to become Soviet Naval Chief of Staff in World War II, has died here at the age of 73, it was announced today.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Oct. 12 --Bay Shore ran its three-year winning streak to 14 games today by scoring a 20-0 victory over Smithtown. The triumph gave the Maroon sole possession of first place in Suffolk's League 2.

Italian-Americans, IrishAmericans, Polish-Americans, Negroes, Puerto Ricans and at least a few Chinese marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday to honor Christopher Columbus, the Italian who sailed to America under Spanish auspices in 1492.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 12 --Larchmont Yacht Club's traditional Columbus Day regatta today ended the 5 -month summer sailing season for Yacht Racing Association fleets on Long Island Sound. A fleet of 26 sailed in a shifty breeze that constantly varied between northwest and west and between 5 and 10 knots.
DETROIT, Oct. 12--Secret negotiations between the Ford Motor Company and the striking United Automobile Workers continued today, but there were signs the talks might be approaching a critical stage.

WITH Emlyn Williams pretending to be Charles Dickens, Hal Holbrook pretending to be Mark Twain and Micheal Mac Liammoir pretending to be Oscar Wilde, I thought we only needed Barbara Harris pretending to be Harriet Beecher Stowe for a complete set. But I was, as I frequently am, wrong. For now we have, in "By George," Max Adrian pretending to be George Bernard Shaw.

BOSTON, Oct. 12--Somewhere in old Fenway Park, the champagne that had been on ice for the Red Sox was forgotten. Instead, the players sipped beer, and munched on cold cuts and potato chips amid a mood of frustration rather than despair.
VIENNA, Oct. 9--Reliable Communist informants say that many Eastern European officials are complaining bitterly about the behavior of the Government of Communist East Germany.
ASWAN, United Arab Republic, Oct. 9--Two immense calendars--one Russian, one Arabic --at the workers' entrance to the Aswan High Dam grounds announce the number of days left until Oct. 15.

Forming a new chamber-music group is something like putting money in a subway candy machine. There is no guarantee that anything is going to come out of it. Nevertheless, it is heartening to see musicians still taking the chance, knowing the odds are high.
A 39-year-old Queens housewife, who reportedly used church social gatherings to meet potential victims, has been charged with swindling 42 elderly persons of $600,000 in life savings.
Karel Ancerl drew out of the Czech Philharmonic the most beautifully dressed sounds imaginable last night in the visiting orchestra's second and final concerts at Carnegie Hall.
The American Broadcasting Company plans to televise an adaption of Truman Capote's short story "Among the Paths to Eden" on Sunday, Dec. 17, at 8 P.M.

Decry complacency." Or maybe; "Gladden a child's heart." These and 25 other slogans have been shining out from large lighted signs atop the new Transit Authority buses and alternately baffling and encouraging New Yorkers.
The Board of Education will set up a "walk-in" examination next week to give prospective substitute teachers on-the-spot tests and possibly instant jobs.
MONTREAL,, Oct. 12--Puccini's "La Boheme" is only 71 years old but, because it established itself early as one of the most popular of all operas, it has gone through countless productions.

Brooklyn Tech, hoping to regain Public School Athletic League football supremacy, scored its third straight Division II victory yesterday by defeating Jefferson, 25-14, at Midwood Field. It was Jefferson's second loss in three games.

YESTERDAY (Oct. 12, 1967) THE PRESIDENT Met with Commission on Consumer Interests headed by Betty Furness; saw Marshall Green, Ambassador to Indonesia; saw Representative Celler; saw Price Daniel, director of the Office of Emergency Planning.
The sentiment and nostalgia that brought a rush of buyers seeking mementos of the old Metropolitan Opera House appear to have vanished along with the landmark.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--Opponents of President Johnson's Vietnam policy are working to capture the presidency of the Young Democratic Clubs of America at the organization's biennial convention next month in Miami.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--The Administration and its Congressional critics today joined the basic issue in the Vietnam debate: whether the national security of the United States is at stake in the war.

The General Electric Company, the nation's largest electronic and electrical manufacturer, posted new records in sales for the third quarter and first nine months of this year, but earnings declined from the corresponding periods a year ago, a company report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) --The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that over-the-counter trading in the common stock of the Dyna Ray Corporation of New York City would be permitted next Monday.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 12--A number of residents of this Hudson River village called today for more involvement by elected officials in the problems of the Negro community to forestall further racial violence.
LONDON, Oct. 12--It is not libelous to call someone a witch, if she acts like a witch.
CLEMENTON, N.J., Oct. 12 --Curt Person of Memphis won the international senior golf championship and the Founders Cup by scoring a six-over-par 38, 38--76 today at the Pine Valley Golf Club.
Woodmere turned back Fieldston, 21-19, yesterday for its first victory of the year at Van Cortlandt Park.

More than a year has passed since the City Opera unveiled its extraordinary version of Handel's "Giulio Cesare," but last night, in its first performance of the season, the production seemed to have lost nothing of its dazzling good looks and high style.
It was more of the same in the stock market yesterday as prices went through another broad setback, their third consecutive one this week.
AS a young child in Omaha, he was so sickly his mother "never thought he'd pull through." He had rickets, hay fever, asthma, pneumonia and a rheumatic heart.
A 70-year-old dentist, bound hand and foot, was found dead in his ransacked 37th-floor office at 1400 Broadway in the garment district yesterday by a patient who arrived to have two teeth pulled.
EVERY time a tender offer comes down the pike there are expressions of anguish among stockholders who cannot decide whether they have a bonanza or a bomb.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Harris of 535 Park Avenue and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laurie Harris, to Sheldon Ellsworth Prentice, son of Mrs. James W. Paul of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Lieut. Comdr. Sheldon Prentice, U.S.N.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 12--The settlement yesterday of the year-old Intra Bank problem--with the participation of the United States Government and the technical guidance of a major New York financial house--marks the return of United States influence in this country after the low ebb of last June during the ArabIsraeli war.

Joseph Diehl Fackenthal, retired chairman of the New York Trap Rock Corporation and former vice president of the Board of Education, died yesterday at his home, 35 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. He was 88 years old.

BOSTON, Oct. 12--On the strength of record performances by Bob Gibson and Lou Brock, the St. Louis Cardinals emerged today as champions of the baseball cosmos by winning the seventh and deciding game of the 64th World Series, 7-2.
Three persons were killed and four others critically injured last night when a car pursued by the police smashed broadside into another auto at 138th Street and Seventh Avenue.
BUSINESS executives are turning from the "Fore!" of the golf links to the foreand-aft of a pleasure boat as a method of entertaining favorite clients.
The Port of New York Authority has asked the Rand Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., to help it devise ways to increase the capacity of its four airports.
The Kerr-McGee Corporation will spend $25-million to build a uranium conversion plant on 1,500 acres near Sallisaw in Eastern Oklahoma, the company announced yesterday.

HOUSTON, Oct. 12--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration added three more space experts today to its manned space program, which has been charged with putting an American on the moon by 1970.
The latest report of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization points up once more the desperate need for greater effort to spur food production in the developing nations.
News of the deterioration of Britain's trade balance in September overshadowed the London Stock Exchange yesterday and drove government bonds lower along a broad front.
Sales and earnings of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation reached new records in the third quarter, according to the report yesterday of the nation's second largest electrical manufacturer.

ATHENS, Oct. 12--A British European Airways four-jet Comet airliner with 66 people aboard crashed off the southwest coast of Turkey early today. There were no survivors. Most of the bodies have been recovered from the sea.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 12--In straggling bands, the unmarried girls of the villages around New Delhi made their way to the banks of the holy river Jumna today to perform a rite meant to assure them good husbands and large families.
ROME, Oct. 12--Prelates of the synod of Roman Catholic Bishops elected a predominantly liberal eight-man slate today to synthesize their views on doctrinal problems for the guidance of Pope Paul VI.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)--House Republicans served notice today that they would try again next week to impose a $5-billion spending cut on President Johnson.

"IT is an amazing fact that in spite of the tremen dous popularity of the Gilbert and Sullivan operettas throughout the English-speaking world there are only two permanent professional companies performing these works, the American Savoyards in the United States and the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company in England."
THE Ivy League, having completed successfully, for the most part, its outside skirmishes, opens full-scale warfare tomorrow for the 1967 championship.

Two member firms of the New York Stock Exchange-- Putnam, Coffin Burr of Hartford and Doolittle Co. of Buffalo--disclosed plans yesterday to merge under an unusual arrangement in which both firms may retain their local characteristics while becoming part of an expanded organization.
Following is the 1Oth of a series of articles by reporters of The New York Times on a half-century of Soviet rule in Russia, to be observed on Nov. 7.
Anthony J. Travia, Speaker of the Assembly, said yesterday that he had asked Senator Robert F. Kennedy not to recommend him to President Johnson "at this time" for appointment to the Federal bench.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 12 (AP)--Go Go Windy captured the $24,225 Mermaid Stakes, the closing-day feature, today at the Atlantic City race track.

James B. Gray, a vice president and general counsel of the New York Central System, died Wednesday of a heart attack in his office at 230 Park Avenue. He was 54 years old and lived at 36 Sherman Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.
PARIS, Oct. 12--France announced today its final preparations for the first panoramic survey of Russian art to be shown outside Russia.

Life magazine, in a shift in editorial policy, will call next week for a pause in the bombing of North Vietnam to create better conditions for a new peace initiative and improve national and international confidence in the Johnson Administration's policy.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 12-- Federal troops have crossed the Niger River and entered Onitsha, a major market center in the secessionist Eastern Region.
Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the most sacred event on the Hebrew religious calendar, begins at sundown today.

BOSTON, Oct. 12--Elston Howard, the 38-year-old catcher obtained by the Red Sox from the New York Yankees in August, said today that he would not make a decision on retirement until sometime this winter.

News editors were told yesterday that their "judgments on the coverage of racial news can affect the course of the Negro revolution" and may even cause "unwitting fragmentation of the real Negro leadership."

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 12 (AP)--The du Pont Company, saying that it was speaking for several other manufacturers as well as itself, issued a warning today that death could result from sniffing a glass-chilling product.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 --Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Oct. 7 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 12--The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr., the chaplain of Yale University, is urging undergraduates to consider turning in their draft cards as a protest against the war in Vietnam.

HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 12-- Bob Calandruccio, the quarterback, ran for both touchdowns today as unbeaten Harrison High downed a Southern WestChester Interscholastic Athletic Conference rival, Eastchester High, 14-0.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12-- Hundreds of employes of the Office of Economic Opportunity spent their lunch period today at a sidewalk meeting called to protest their exclusion from a pay raise bill for Government workers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12-- The United Steelworkers of America is considering the possibility of proposing voluntary arbitration of unresolved issues in 1968 steel negotiations.
A suspended Housing Authority patrolman called his former sergeant last night, and according to the sergeant, said:

BOSTON, Oct. 12--The beautiful dream vanished in the face of cruel reality today and Destiny's Darlings fell one step short of their supposed date with destiny. The Red Sox, sentimental pets of an entire nation, ran dry of heroics and miracles on a gray day whose funereal setting fit the mood of the Boston citizenry.
The food broker, an increasingly powerful force in the marketplace, is anxious to offer advice to the ad agencies, whose creative product he must also sell.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12-- The celebrated "new town" of Reston, Va., a planned community of 2,700 residents 18 miles from Washington, is due for significant financial, administrative and architectural changes under its new manager, the Gulf Oil Company.
McKinsey Co., management consultants, announced here yesterday the election by its 30 directors of Gilbert H. Clee as managing director.
LONDON, Oct. 12--Stanley Morison, a scholar of the press and a noted typographer, died at his home here last night. He was 78 years old.

PRO football has the ability to produce "the big game" Sunday after Sunday --that special occasion that Sonny Werblin salutes as this sport's distinction over baseball. The special occasions this Sunday will be at Baltimore where the Los Angeles Rams take on the undefeated Colts and at San Diego where the Kansas City Chiefs oppose the Chargers, also unbeaten.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (UPI)--A wildly cheering crowd of 15,000 greeted the world champion St. Louis Cardinals tonight as they stepped off a chartered plane from Boston.

The Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference will extend into 1969 its experiment in ofering intermediate-season fares. This was decided Wednesday at the meting in Hamilton, Bermuda, of representatives of 17 lines operat ing 42 major pasenger liners.

Arthur Rosenblatt, the architect who has played a major role in changing the design of city parks and recreational centers, was appointed yesterday as administrator for archietecture and planning at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum.

IT looked like a minidress for a hip daughter of the American Revolution. Its blue velvet bodice was splashed with silver stars and its accordion-pleated satin skirt was red and white striped--like an American flag.

LONDON, Oct. 12--Britain turned in her worst trading performance in 15 months in Sep tember, when her imports exceeded her exports by 52million, or about $145.6-million, the Board of Trade announced today. Dock strikes affected the figures.
The following is the statement by Governor Rockefeller explaining his endorsement of the proposed new state constitution:
City Controller Mario A. Procaccino certified yesterday that $476.2-million in new funds would be available for the capital budget next year.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--Following is a transcript of the news conference held by Secretary of State Dean Rusk today:

In St. Thomas Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Mabel Martha Groves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Groves of Armonk, N.Y., became the bride of Joseph Warren Downs 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Warren Downs of Nashua and Wolfeboro, N.H.

FORT LEE, N.J., Oct. 12-- Fort Lee rallied for two touchdowns within five minutes today as it gained a 13-6 victory over previously undefeated New Milford. The once-beaten Bridgemen are 3-0 in the Bergen County Scholastic League and New Milford is 3-1.

Miss Bambi Barbara Bernhard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Bernhard of Toms River, N.J., was married here yesterday afternoon to Edward Loomis Schieffelin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Schieffelin of Short Hills, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the home of Robert Fiore at 36 West 26th Street by Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--A bipartisan group of 30 members of the House appealed to President Johnson today to halt the bombing of North Vietnam.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 12 --Passaic County authorities said tonight that Mrs. Judith Kavanaugh, the Clifton housewife whose body was found last year near the Garden State Parkway, and Gabriel (Johnny the Walk) DeFranco, a smalltime hoodlum here, were murdered "to keep them from talking to the police."
The investigation of an alleged million-dollar-a-year racket involving the moving of slum tenants has been extended to asserted kickbacks by landlords to welfare workers.

The Wells Fargo Bank, San Francisco, one of California's largest banks, announced yesterday that Ernest C. Arbuckle, 55 years old, dean of the graduate business school at Stanford University and head of the Stanford Research Institute, had been elected a director.

The New Jersey Home Builders Association has dropped the word "home" from its name. Originally composed mainly of one-family house builders, the 19-year-old organization of 1,700 members will extend its services to builders of multifamily dwellings and has become the New Jersey Builders Association.

The settlement reached in the Intra Bank case does not appear to have any direct effect on New York State efforts to pay off an estimated $2.1-million in deposits at Intra's branch here, a state official said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--To the Johnson Administration's growing alarm, a wave of trade protectionist sentiment gained momentum today in Congress with the drafting of legislation to curtail steel imports.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--Scientists have reported producing what are believed to be the first durable hybrids between the cells of man and another species.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 13--United States Navy pilots bombed two shipyards near the center of Haiphong yesterday for the first time, a military spokesman announced this morning.
The Red Sox and the American League bowed out of the World Series yesterday. So did the American Stock Exchange and the investors who attempt to keep it going.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Oct. 12 --Brian Chiles scored 13 points and led Lawrence to a 26-20 victory over Massapequa today in a Division 1 game of the South Shore Athletic League. It was the third straight triumph for Lawrence, second half.

Federal Judge Dudley B. Bonsal reserved decision yesterday on a bid by European shipowners to block a new Brazil-United States freight agreement that they say would freeze them out of Brazilian coffee and cocoa shipments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12-- Princess Alexandra of Britain, first cousin to Queen Elizabeth II, spent a light-hearted evening at the White House tonight with a half-dozen members of Lynda Johnson's wedding party and two greatgrandchildren of President Theodore Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)--Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that a massive antiwar rally planned for Washington Oct. 21 was designed to test how much the Government would resist such demonstrations.
Miss Alice Louise Brady and Dennis Earl Yancy were married here yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Robert Moher. A reception was given at the Pierre.
Gov. Richard J. Hughes of New Jersey intervened yesterday as a wildcat strike of 2,500 Port Newark longshoremen went into its second day.
Six armed men and a woman held up a midtown cafe yesterday morning, taking $3,150 and then escaping after spraying four customers and seven employes with an incapacitating gas.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--The Federal Government proposed 10 new auto safety standards today for possible imposition by Jan. 1, 1969, and 37 others for longer-range study.

Willie Shoemaker, Braulio Baeza and Angel Cordero, three of the leading riders in the nation, were involved in contretemps of varying degrees at Aqueduct yesterday, with Shoemaker's involvement the most dramatic. He slid from his mount in the sixth race when the animal, in full flight, suffered a broken right leg.
The International Rescue Committee will benefit from a dinner dance to be held on Monday evening at the Rainbow Grill. Mrs. Andrew Goodman is chairman of the event.
DETROIT, Oct. 12--Sales of new cars fell sharply in the first 10 days of October from last year, but differences in new-model introduction dates, plus the Ford strike, were blamed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)--The General Services Administration said today it would sell only less refined silver from the Government stockpile, starting Oct. 20.
PARIS, Oct. 12--France paid a final tribute to Andre Mau rois this morning in an open courtyard of the Institute de France.
Oct. 10--Coat-hanger dowsers, or divining rods, are being used by Marine Corps engineers here and in Vietnam to detect tunnels, mines and booby traps.

A dark-haired, bright-eyed little girl at Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland is baffling doctors and scientists. She is the only known living person lacking an entire nonsex chromosome, a medical team reported yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 10-- Premier Suleyman Demirel said today that his recent visit to the Soviet Union had eliminated "the last traces of hostility" from Soviet-Turkish relations.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Oct. 12 --Maj. Gen. Thomas H. Lipscomb, who is accused of exercising undue influence on courts-martial while he was commanding officer at Fort Leonard Wood, Mo., received a legal lesson today.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 12--Generally picked to finish fourth or fifth in the Ivy League football race, Cornell has the capacity to win the championship, said Coach Jack Musick today. He is looking forward to a victory here Saturday over Princeton, though he is surprised that the Big Red is quoted a slight favorite over the Tiger.
Cotton futures rose slightly yesterday despite the Government's announcement of a big increase in production goals for the next crop.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay --One of South America's riddles focuses on the Rio de la Plata, or Silver River, where Argentina and Uruguay, the continent's most puzzling failures, meet. These are highly endowed lands with minimal race problems and immensely civilized traditions. Both possess the infrastructure of modernity: good communications, splendid cities, fine universities, hospitals, resorts. Yet each in its own way seems intent on messing up its prospects.

HONOLULU, Oct. 12--Delegates to the American merchant marine conference meeting in a three-day session here heard a warning yesterday that the United States and other trading nations of the world might soon be at the mercy of the Soviet Union because of "woeful deficiencies" in shipping capabilities.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 12-- The Israeli police announced today the arrest of 24 El Fatah members and the breaking of a ring of Arab terrorists operating in the Jerusalem area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--President Johnson issued another of his almost daily appeals for a tax increase today, but there is growing doubt at the White House that he can thus rally sufficient public or Congressional support.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 (AP) --Victor Bono and Florencio Mationg, charged with murdering two United States border patrolmen, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder charges today.

After much soul searching, Governor Rockefeller has concluded that the good features of the proposed new Constitution outweigh the bad ones. Architects who design stateaided housing projects have received some good news about fees from the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk, replying forcefully to Congresssional critics, warned today that for the United States to abandon its treaty pledges to South Vietnam and the rest of Southeast Asia would "subject this country to mortal danger."

An off-duty patrolman moonlighting as a cabdriver overpowered and arrested a suspect last night moments after a fatal stabbing outside the Port Authority bus terminal.
The Bank of America, San Francisco, the nation's largest bank, reported yesterday record earnings for the third quarter and for the first nine months of 1967.

The West German central bank, the Deutsche Bundesbank, last week purchased $125-million in United States Treasury bonds denominated in marks, Treasury officials said yesterday. The major American film companies apparently no longer fear having their films condemned by the National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures, formerly known as the National Legion of Decency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12--Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the controversial advocate of naval nuclear power, has once again thwarted efforts to retire him by winning a fourth two-year extension of active duty.

LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP)-- "Sweet Charity," the Broadway musical, won raves from London's theater critics today and established Juliet Prowse as a star in the city where she last worked as a chorus girl 11 years ago.

IT takes Sam Scali and his family an hour and a half to move from the mid-19th century to today.

From stars to cars to credit cards, the ubiquitous computer was a major component in three new products introduced here yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 17 Bill Steinkraus, a 14-year rider for the United States team, set a high-jumping record for the Pennsylvania National Horse Show when he and his gray gelding. Bold Minstrel, cleared the wall at 6 feet 10 inches tonight.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Oct. 17 An all-white jury heard the final testimony today in the Federal District Court trial of 18 men charged with conspiracy in the lynching of three young civil rights workers near Philadelphia, Miss., in 1964.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--The United States is planning to make available to Latin America military aircraft capable of flying at supersonic speeds.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 17--Lee Byung Chull, reputed to be South Korea's richest businessman, donated 51 per cent of the stock of his $62-million fertilizer company to the Government today putting an end to a 13-month-old controversy over a smuggling scandal.

TRENTON, Oct. 17 Gov. Richard J. Hughes today assailed a Republican demand that Dr. Carl L. Marburger, the new State Commissioner of Education, resin for suggesting a merger of urban and suburb ban schools to achieve racial integration.
CHESTER, Pa., Oct. 17--Speed was of the essence at the launching today of the 26-knot, roll-on, roll-off freighter Adm. Wm. M. Callaghan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--A new way of figuring the Federal budget, aimed at ending the present confusing system in which three different sets of figures are used, was proposed today by a special Presidential commission.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17--A top Administration official warned today that critics of the Government's Vietnam policy were "rousing" a new isolationist spirit in the United States running counter to American foreign policy since World War II.
The chairman and the president of the Allied Artists Pictures Corporation lost their posts yesterday.

The extraordinarily high interest rates the highest in a generation that New York City has to pay on its latest borrowings may make it appear that the Lindsay administration is still losing ground in its battle to improve the city's financial standing. But this is not really the case.

THE 50th anniversary of the Russian Revolution began with one of Mos cow's loveliest springs. Hedges of lilacs faced the Bolshoi Theater, tulips were fluorescent in the Alexander Gardens, and parks turned jungle green. Even the brusque earnestness of rushing Musco- vites was touched by the pleasure of warm sun and clear skies.

Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's largest cigarette company and the first in the industry to announce financial results, achieved new records in sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30. More than 3,000 women volunteers are taking part in the United Hospital Fund's campaign on behalf of 78 voluntary nonprofit hospitals in New York City. EASTON, Md., Oct. 18 This is the time of year when Eastern Shore rockfish enthusiats start hoping in terms of lunkers. They know the striped bass have started to migrate down Chesapeake Bay and that the larger ones probably are particularly susceptible to delicacies.

The extraordinary counterattack launched by the Johnson Administration yesterday against proposals to limit much of the country's imports by quotas testifies to the strength behind the current protectionist drive. Some of the nation's most powerful economic lobbies are pressing them to act, including oil, steel, textile, meat, dairy, lead, zinc and footwear interests.

PETER SHAFFER'S double bill "Black Comedy" at the Ethel Barrymore Theater is machine-made but skillful. Its aim appears to be the amiable one of providing simple entertainment, and in this it succeeds. Certainly it is far more successful than Mr. Shaffer's grandiose "The Royal Hunt of the Sun," that Verdi opera without Verdi music of a couple of seasons back.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Johnson Administration counter-attacked in force today against a concerted drive for legislation to curb imports of a dozen products ranging from steel to strawberries. OSSINING, N.Y., Oct. 18 Murray Lewis, a former newspaperman and Marine Corps combat correspondent, and a vice president of Carl Byoir and Associates, Inc., died here today after a long illness. He was 55 years old and lived on Pines Bridge Road here.

TORONTO, Oct. 18 (AP) Norm Ullman's fourth goal of the season in the first two minutes of the second period carried the Detroit Red Wings to a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) Army doctors reported today that former President Dwight D. Eisenhower had a "benign noncancerous enlargement of the prostate gland" but that surgery was not indicated at this time.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 18--Gratified by Army's performance in its 24-6 victory over Southern Methodist, which he termed its best in his two years as the head coach, Tom Cahill threw reservations to the wind today and said that the cadets were a better football team than the 1966 "Cinderella" eleven.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 18 Dr. Dwight S. Bishop, a general practitioner at 93 East Main Street, died today at Community Hospital, Glen Cove. His age was 70. He had been on the hospital's staff for 40 years.

MIDDLETOWN, Pa., Oct. 18 (AP)--severe wind storm skipped through an area near this Dauphin County town today, blowing in windows at a school and causing other damage.

ROME, Oct. 18 Count Giuseppe Dalla Torre del Tempio, director of the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano from 1919 to 1960, died in his Vatican apartment last night. He was 82 years old.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 18 Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Roth of Larchmont and Westhampton Beach, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Patricia Roth, to Robert Saffa. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. George Saffa of Lincroft, N.J.
Woodland Farm, the Middletown, N.J., estate of Mrs. Amory L. Haskell, will be the setting on Saturday for the 37th Monmouth County Hunt Race Meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The portion of their total capacity that manufacturers had in actual use in the third quarter of this year dropped significantly for the second straight quarter, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 A Soviet capsule that was parachuted from a 2,427-pound space vehicle to the surface of Venus today has reported that atmospheric conditions there were inhospitable to human life, it was announced here.

Seventeen years ago the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (U.N.R.W.A.) was established as a "temporary" nonpolitical organ of the General Assembly to care for approximately 700,000 Palestinian Arabs who fled their homes during the 1948-49 Arab-Israeli war. It was to be supported by voluntary contributions from governments, private organizations and individuals.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 18 Roosevelt Raceway, where the Nassau County portion of the harness racing year opened last March 4, called it a year tonight. Abbe Gene Volo, a 7to-10 choice, captured the closing main event.
YONKERS, Oct. 18 Yonkers Raceway reopens for harness racing tomorrow night with the addition of a 10th race and the introduction of four exactas nightly.

Brazil surprised world sugar futures traders yesterday when the news came that that nation had sold 30,000 tons to dealers for about 2.67 cents a pound. The delivery dates range from March through June, 1968.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18 Ron Whitney and Ed Burke, American schoolteachers who lead the world in their track and field specialties this year, had mixed fortunes in the Third International Sports Competition.

Gustav H. Niemeyer, who started his career peddling newspapers at the age of 10 and rose to become an internationally known leader of the jewelry industry, died yesterday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Owenoke Park, Westport, Conn.

SOUSSE, Tunisia, Oct. 18 The United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer of New York, adjourned his third-round encounter in the Interzonal Qualifying Chess Tournament with Lajos Portisch of Hungary here last night and retained the lead with a 2-0 score and one adjourned.

MINEOLA, Oct. 18 The Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority warned today that it might have to institute "a sharp increase in fares" on the Long Island Rail Road if Nassau County persisted in its refusal to pay its bill for station maintenance.
LONDON, Oct. 18 Gen. Sir Richard Loudon McCreery, who commanded the British Eighth Army in Italy in the closing months of the war in Europe, died at his home here today. He was 69 years old.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 18 Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty bowed today to the requests of Pope Paul VI that he remain for the time being in the sanctuary of the United States Embassy here instead of leaving it as he had planned.
Under a 10-year lease involving an aggregate rental of more than $750,000, the executive offices of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are being moved to larger quarters.

Earnings of Trans World Airlines, Inc., rose sharply and those of American Airlines declined in the third quarter, the companies announced yesterday.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday with major market indicators moving in narrow ranges throughout the session.

RIDGEFIELD, N.J., Oct. 18 The 12,000 residents of this community paid their respects tonight to five volunteer firemen who were killed last Sunday morning while fighting a fire in adjacent Cliffside Park.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 18 Two Americans and a Swede, all authorities on how the eye passes its images to the brain, were selected here today as joint winners of the 1967 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Two commercial mildew preventatives have been withdrawn from the market nationally because of a series of mysterious accidental poisonings and two deaths earlier this year in St. Louis.

HARRISON, N.Y., Oct. 18 Assen Jordanoff, a pioneer aviator who flew 180 missions with the Bulgarian Air Force and later came here to be a stunt pilot, flight instructor and author of many books and articles on flying, died here today.

It's not a bad job, it pays about $25,000 a season, and, says Berra, there are no headaches.
A shaft of light came into the bond market yesterday. For the first time since last August, an issue of corporate bonds was sold at competitive bidding and investors snapped it up.
Organizers of parties and benefits that begin in one place and end at another are finding ways to beat the perennial midtown taxi shortage.
Arthur R. Murphy Jr. resigned yesterday as chairman of the McCall Corporation's executive committee, a position he had held for two weeks, or exactly eight work days.

A lawyer who says he represents one of the two men charged with the East Village murder of Linda Fitzpatrick and James R. (Groovy) Hutchinson obtained a show-cause order in Supreme Court yesterday in an attempt to see the complaint against his purported client.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18--A thorough review of the entire Army system of development and production of new weapons was unanimously recommended today by the House Armed Services subcommittee investigating the M-16 rifle.

The American Cancer Society directors recommended yesterday that all cigarette advertising be terminated. "Advertising is too persuasive, too valid and too vital a part of our American life to be used in the sale of such a lethal product as the cigarette," the directors said in a resolution voted for by three-quarters of its board of 104. The resolution added:
Australia fresh from a sound thumping for the America's Cup last month, bounded back yesterday with another challenge for the world's foremost sailing prize.

The Staten Island and Manhattan parks and playgrounds will be visited in two bus tours to be conducted this month by the Council for Parks and Playgrounds as part of its fifth anniversary celebration.

HOUSTON, Oct. 18 Consumers of oil who have thus far been asked to pay only part of the increased transportation costs for crude oil as a result of the Suez Canal closing face further increased prices, a leading oil company executive indicated today.

Vice President Humphrey said last night that the United States policy in Asia was not to "contain" Communist China, but to contain "certain aggressive patterns of conduct" of China until "prudence and good judgment can set in."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Leading business executives from fourteen member nations of the Organization of American States wound up a three-day meeting here today with a plea for tariff concessions from the United States and other "more developed" nations.

The House hearings on the Securities and Exchange Commission's request for reform of the mutual fund industry have raised an entirely new problem involving the stock market. Several Congressmen think that the S.E.C. should consider curbs on funds engaging in speculation of such dimensions that it could cause big swings up or down in stock prices.
PARIS, Oct. 18 A prominent French diplomat, peering over an elegant table in the dim, natural light favored in European offices, spread his hands in resignation.
Chet Huntley charged last night that actors and announcers would be competing for newsmen's jobs if all were brought under the jurisdiction of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

The appointment of John David Farley as executive director of the new Urban Design Council of the City of New York has been announced by William S. Paley, chairman of the council and board chairman of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Two features marked trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday the strength of Australian mining shares and the weakness of British bonds. The Australian securities advanced on the very encouraging report of nickel assays in the Mount Martin project.
ANKHE, South Vietnam, Oct. 18--The ambulances begin moving rapidly across the runway as the plane swoops down and comes to a bumpy halt.
