A national organization of Democrats was formed yesterday to oppose President Johnson for renomination unless he reverses his policy in Vietnam in an effort to reach a negotiated peace.

The path of Robert B. Braswell from his boyhood home in Buford, Ga., to a corner office on the 25th floor of the R.C.A. Building was winding and difficult. But the Negro financial analyst for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) finds the trek was worthwhile.

Allegheny Airlines said yeserday that it would start an experiment on Nov. 15 to see if it could provide better service to a small city, without subsidy, by farming out the operation to a local air-taxi operator.

FROM Milan, by way of Montreal, came the Or chestra and Chorus of La Scala to Carnegie Hall for a single performance of Verdi's Requiem. This had been one of the more eagerly awaited events of the young music season, and the auditorium was filled with notables, including more singers, from Renata Tebaldi down, than have been assembled in one place since the gala farewell to the old Metropolitan Opera.

Under crafty guidance by Braulio Baeza, Ogden Phipps's Successor was the popular winner of the $54,800 Lawrence Realization at Aqueduct yesterday. The race, for 3-year-olds at 1 5/8 miles, attracted a halfdozen starters and the crowd of 20,775 bet Successor into odds-on favoritism.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 Premier Levi Eshkol publicly rebuked his Minister of Defense, Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, today for making critical statements about him at a recent political meeting.

THE slender legs with the navy blue stockings and Lucite-heeled patent pumps were never still. When the doorbell chimed, they swung off the high window seat that affords a panoramic view of southwest Manhattan and made their way to the foyer, past a permanent Christ mas tree laden with miniature birds, flowers and fruit and twinkling with scores of tiny lights.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 18 In wood cottages, crowded six to the room, a small colony of Western hippies pass the hot, airless afternoons in a dreamy reverie haloed by marijuana smoke.

The soft landing on Venus, Earth's nearest planetary neighbor, and the resultant evidence that its atmosphere consists almost entirely of carbon dioxide and that its temperature ranges from about 100 to over 500 degrees Fahrenheit, mark a historic advance in man's exploration of the solar system. Soviet scientists and technicians so long plagued by bad luck in their numerous earlier shots at Venus and Mars fully deserve the worldwide congratulations evoked by their remarkable feat.
Duplicating its record performance of previous periods, the Xerox Corporation reported yesterday the highest revenues and earnings in its history for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.
SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 18 Pablo Casals, the cellist, is about to discover Central America, and this little capital is hoping others will follow.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The House ordered President Johnson tonight to reduce nonmilitary spending by at least $5-billion to $7-billion in the current fiscal year and suggested ways to do it.

Protestant groups are organizing speaker bureaus, distributing pamphlets and bumper stickers, drafting newspaper advertisements and forming telephone brigades in a campaign to defeat the proposed state constitution on Election Day.

Nationwide demonstrations against the war in Vietnam have resulted in hundreds of inquiries to a group here that is coordinating events across the country this weekend in support of American troops in Vietnam.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 A goodly number of Philadelphians dressed themselves in their elegant best last night and came out to the Academy of Music for the opening of the 1967-68 season of the Philadelphia Lyric Opera and the first American performance of Renzo Rossellini's "Uno Sguardo dal Ponte."
The capacity crowd of 15,925 at Madison Square Garden last night suffered through a crackling hockey game the Rangers appeared to have lost.
Last Friday Pamela Rae Koeppel painted a blue flower on her right cheek. The next day the 14-year-old schoolgirl left home. Last night she was found in a hotel on the edge of Greenwich Village.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 18 (AP) An aviation expert called today for Government authority to ground private planes during poor weather.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Three major Wall Street firms have challenged the findings of another prestigious Wall Street house, the managements of the Norfolk Western and Chesapeake Ohio railways and the stockholders of both carriers on the fairness of proposed merger terms for the N. W. and the C. O.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 18 The police used tear gas and nightsticks to break up an antiwar demonstration today by hundreds of students on the University of Wisconsin campus.

The USLIFE Holding Corporation announced yesterday plans to acquire the Distributors Group, Inc., an investment adviser and distributor of Group Securities, Inc., an investment company consisting of three mutual funds.
One of the sure signs that Christmas is high is the outpouring of new liquor ad campaigns and exciting announcements on packaging plans.

More than 80 Negro workers for the city's Human Resources Administration signed a statement yesterday criticizing charges by "certain Puerto Rican circles" that Negroes have been "consistently and deliberately favored to the exclusion of Puerto Rican groups."
Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, began last night at sundown.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 18 Secretary General Thant warned the 122 members today that the financial situation of the United Nations continues to be "precarious." He said that between $36.5-million and $38.5-million was the minimum needed in voluntary gifts to restore solvency.

MOSCOW, Oct. 18 The New York Times was accused here today of "malicious concotions, lies and slander" in its series of articles analyzing Soviet society on the eve of the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.
BOSTON, Oct. 18 "You'd think they'd raise hell, especially in Boston, but they haven't," Sam Hunter, director of New York's Jewish Museum, said.

Motion picture rights to "The Confession of Nat Turner," the highly acclaimed novel by William Styron published two weeks ago by Random House, have been acquired by Wolper Pictures, Ltd., for more than $600,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 House and Senate conferees broke a three-month deadlock today and agreed that no state would have to redistrict until after the 1970 census.

HOUSTON, Oct. 18 Closecropped Texas fairways have altered the strategy of the United States team of golf professionals that will oppose the British for the Ryder Cup beginning here Friday. The Americans will use the smaller British ball usually taboo in this country. However, in international competition, the choice of the ball is optional.

The Amoco Chemicals Corporation, a subsidiary of Standard Oil Company (Indiana), has agreed to purchase the Avisun Corporation, New Castle, Del., a subsidiary of the Sun Oil Company for $80-million, it was announced yesterday.

SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 17--In office less than four months, President Fidel Sanchez Hernandez, a mild-mannered little army colonel, has had to face some severe strains on his abillity to maintain a moderate democratic course.
The American Stock Exchange rebounded yesterday after two days of weakness in active trading.

THE British theater once had something called the drawing-room comedy, and on occasion these became so intense that you could scarcely hear the actors for the rattle of the teacups. But then people began to realize that hardly anyone in England had drawing rooms. Indeed, hardly anyone knew how to draw anymore. So they transferred the action from the drawing room to the bedroom and the rattles changed their sonorities.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Richard M. Nixon made an unannounced visit to Congress today and looked very much like a Presidential candidate collecting IOU's for next year's election.

A dispute has broken out in the Episcopal church over the omission of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. from a list of 10 ecumenical leaders to receive honorary degrees from the General Theological Seminary.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 18 Lieut. Col. Terry de la Mesa Allen Jr., 38 years old, son of the swashbuckling general who commanded the First Infantry Division during World War II, was killed yesterday in the bitter action 40 miles from Saigon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 The American League voted tonight to allow Charles O. Finley to move his Kansas City Athletics to Oakland, and to expand the league to 12 teams, "as soon as practicable, but not later than the 1971 season," with the new franchises to be situated in Kansas City and Seattle.

By agreeing to hear arguments on whether taxpayers can sue to test the constitutionality of Federal aid to church schools under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, the Supreme Court is at last opening the door to the possibility of judicial review of this politically explosive question at the highest level.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 19--United States fighter-bomber pilots shot down a MIG interceptor north of Hanoi yesterday and raided a shipyard and military barracks in the port city of Haiphong. The details were reported in a communique issued here this morning.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 18 The General Electric Company's, experimental electric car has a top speed of 55 miles an hour on level ground, and a range of 100-to-120 miles at speeds of 30 to 35 miles an hour, Dr. Arthur M. Bueche, vice president of the G.E. Research and Development Center at Schenectady, N.Y., said here.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 18 More than 2,500 chanting, singing antiwar demonstrators picketed the Northern California Draft Induction Center here today, the third day of a locally organized stop-the-draft week. The police arrested 73 protesters who attempted to keep 250 inductees from entering the building, bringing the number of arrests since Monday to 218.

Nine experts have concluded that state and Federal lawmakers will need to know a great deal more than they now do before realistic legislation controlling the mind-warping drug LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) is possible.

In Sheep Meadow in Central Park, where hundreds might have gathered for the moon show yesterday morning, four skywatchers stood fruitless vigil at 4:45 A.M., scanning the sky for a hint of a lunar total eclipse.
The spokesman for the port's stevedoring industry warned last night that a "container rebellion" would dominate the next round of negotiations in the industry.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 18 The Florida Education Association and Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. came to an agreement today on a special session of the Legislature on education, and plans for a statewide walkout of teachers were canceled.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore told American officials and Congressmen today that any hasty American withdrawal from Vietnam would mean the loss of the entire region.
The identities of the chiefs of the two top British intelligence services are revealed publicly in an article in the Nov. 4 issue of The Saturday Evening Post.

THE Philadelphia Amateur Chess Tournament, spon sored by the Franklin Mercantile Chess Club, was won by John Yehl of Medina, Pa., who made a clean sweep of the opposition, scoring 5-0 in a five-round "Swiss."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, of Montana, proposed a compromise today in a deadlock over continuing the Subversive Activitie Control Board.

HONG KONG, Oct. 19 Detectives today arrested a man alleged to have been a key figure in anti-British border incidents. He was seized when he crossed into Hong Kong territory from the village in China where he lives.
Marshall McLuhan, the Canadian communications theorist, who currently holds a $100,000 professorship at Fordham University, has been awarded two prizes this week whose total value is $15,750.

Perhaps "La Traviata" is too much with us these days. A very respectable performance of the Verdi opera was given by the Metropolitan Opera last night, yet it did not develop much emotional steam on either side of the footlights.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 19 Military spokesmen said today that about a thousand federal soldiers went ashore yesterday at Calabar, the major port in southeastern Nigeria, and were engaged in "heavy fighting" with secessionist troops for control of the city.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 19 William H. Stanley, a yachting enthusiast and retired food broker, died this morning, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in the Chatsworth Garden Apartments. He was 87 years old.
Picketing by a small group of pier supervisors seeking union recognition from stevedore companies yesterday shut down the entire Brooklyn waterfront.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 19 Crystine Jones, a pretty, 20year-old blonde riding for the United States Equestrian Team for the second year, gained a midnight victory in the internation jumping that was a highlight of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight. The victory was achieved with Ksaina, a gray mare, and carried the First Cavalry Squadron trophy.

Yellow and orange will be the colors of the decor for the Yorkville Ball to be held in the New York Hilton's Trianon Ballroom next Friday. Proceeds of the evening will go to the Yorkville Youth Council.

APPLAUDED for many years as a major writer in Latin America and in Europe, Miguel Angel Asturias, who was selected yesterday for the Nobel Prize in Literature, is virtually unknown in the United States. Of his 10 novels only two "El Senor Presidente" (The ...
LONDON, Oct. 19 (Reuters)--Britain faced the threat of a nationwide railroad strike tonight, which would add to the economic damage caused by the strike of 15,000 longshoremen.

WITH three of the finest songs cycles in the litera ture on his program, Bernard Kruysen had won this listener before the concert started. Ravels "Histoires Naturelles," Mussorgsky's "Songs and Dances of Death," the Schumann "Dichterliebe" what a treat! But these are examples of the French, Russian and German literature, all different, all posing vocal and interpretive problems. Would Mr. Kruysen be able to handle them?

The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation announced yesterday the resignation of John Carter, its chair man. It also reported a sharp decline in third-quarter profits and predicted that earnings in 1967 would be "well below last year."
Third-quarter earnings of the International Paper Company fell 35 per cent while the company's nine-month profits were down 17 per cent from the periods a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Industries seeking protection from foreign imports pressed their case for statutory import quotas today before a largely sympathetic Senate Finance Committee.

MIKHAIL BULGAKOV died in 1940 at the age of 48, unsung and virtually unknown. As was the case with so many of the brightest stars of early Soviet art and literature, his works short stories, the novel "The White Guard" (1925), several plays had been suppressed under the tightenting Ctalinist regime as not conforming to the ideals and strictures of Soviet realism.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The White House said today that President Johnson had at no time solicited the Governors for a resolution of support on Vietnam.

YONKERS, Oct. 19 There is no way of telling at this time to what heights Fulla Napoleon, the easiest of winners of tonight's $25,000 Star Pointer Pace, will ascend as Yonkers Raceway opened its third and final home stand of 1967. Most experts agree that there is not a 2-year-old pacer around to challenge the supremacy of the son of Dale Frost and Sarah Napoleon.
American space scientists were puzzled yesterday by two observations reported to earth by the Soviet spacecraft, Venus 4, and the capsule that it dropped to the surface of the planet.

RIO DE JANEIRO The number of military regimes in South America seems constant even if their locales vary. Thus today one or another type of government is headed by an officer in Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Bolivia; even Uruguay's President is a retired general and the army lurks behind the political scene in Peru, Venezuela and Chile.
LONDON, Oct. 19 Rising interest rates in the United States forced the Bank of England today into a defensive increase in the British bank rate to 6 per cent from 5 per cent.

HOUSTON, Oct. 19 The British Ryder Cup team of golf professionals will open its bid against the United States tomorrow with a diversified offense. Three of the four foursome pairs elected to play the small golf ball, official on their home course, but the other will use the American standard.
For at least two ad men this week the future looked very rosy for their respective media.

A four-engine jetliner rose from Kennedy International Airport's longest runway shortly after noon one day this week and went into a steep climb as it headed toward Inwood, about three-quarters of a mile away on the other side of Jamaica Bay's eastern-most finger.
Italian-Americans filled Madison Square Garden last night to protest against ethnic slurs and to cheer Frank Sinatra in his new role as their standard bearer.
Bishop Industries, Inc., formerly Hazel Bishop, Inc., is negotiating with Cartier's, New York, to acquire the famous jewelry and silversmithing establishment on Fifth Avenue

Mitzi Gaynor, standing on a platform between the Public Library's granite lions, reached into a fishbowl yesterday noon and drew out a ticket that made five metropolitan area residents $100,000 winners in the monthly state lottery.

The National Maritime Union lost its suit yesterday to block the city's licensed ferryboat officers from voting Monday on what union will represent them. The three-page ruling by State Supreme Court Justice Charles G. Tierney dismissing the N.M.U. suit apparently wrote an end at least on legal issues to an often bitter labor dispute that has been argued in the state courts for almost three years.

The 16-story and penthouse apartment building at 19 East 80th Street, northwest corner of Madison Avenue and 80th Street, has been purchased by David W. Frankel, investor. The property, on a plot 120 by 62 feet, was held at $2.2-million. The building has 66 apartments and four stores.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Johnson Administration, shaken by a Congressional economy move, pleaded today with the Senate to reverse a House action that could force Federal spending cutbacks of up to $8-billion.
A group of teen-agers lecttured hundreds of social work ers and members of Planned Parenthood-World Population yesterday on the sex attitudes of adults.
Two major companies announced yesterday that they had called off merger agreements with other companies.

Thayer Hobson, who was president of William Morrow Co., book publishers, for 27 years until he became chairman of the board in 1958, died yesterday at Nix Memorial Hospital, San Antonio, Tex., after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at the Deer Ledge Ranch, Comfort, Tex.

In another "scientific spectacular" in anticipation of the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution next month, the Soviet Union has begun operating an atom smasher more than twice as powerful as any other in existence.

Dr. James M. Hester, president of New York University, told the Fifth Avenue Association yesterday that "this city will not possess the variety of universities it has today and should have in the future unless radical action is taken to assist its private institutions solve their financial problems."
A large faculty group at Long Island University's Brooklyn Center asked the State Board of Regents yesterday to suspend the university's board of trustees.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 19 Conservatives at their party conference today criticized economic sanctions against Rhodesia and called for a settlement with the rebel white regime there.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Pentagon turned a deaf ear today to a report accusing the Army of "unbelievable" mismanagement of the M-16 rifle program.
BERLIN, Oct. 19 Klaus Schutz, a close associate of Willy Brandt, the West German Social Democratic leader and Foreign Minister, was elected Mayor of West Berlin by the city Parliament today.
IN a nationwide preseason poll of football writers, the consensus was that Cornell would finish no better than fifth in this year's Ivy League race.

THE GHOST of Holly Sugar was given up yesterday by the International Systems and Controls Corporation. The company which as the Houston Oil Field Material Company posed a takeover threat to Holly last February sold its 280,200 shares of Holly's common stock to institutional investors.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 19 The struggle against Communist insurgencies and Communist influence in Southeast Asia seems to be doing well despite painfully slow progress and some setbacks in South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Amid speeches warning of increased violence and civil disorder, Congress gave final approval today to a bill to increase the police security of the Capitol and its grounds.

City College suspended seven student demonstrators yesterday for having obstructed construction of temporary buildings at the college two weeks ago, in an effort to save campus trees and lawns. Each of the students was sentenced to write a 5,000-word composition justifying his actions.

THE Soviet way of life is as much a product of its revolutionary build ing technology as of its social and political systems. The development of that technology has taken place with stunning speed, stunning advances and stunning disasters in the last decade.
THE oldest sectional tournament in the country be gins this afternoon at the New York Hilton. It is the Metropolitan Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association, and the schedule is:
ROSEBUD, S.D., Vietnam, the antipoverty program and crime in the streets are among the issues as campaign oratory breaches the autumn silence in the land of the Rosebud Sioux.

The minority leader of the State Senate, Joseph Zaretzki, said yesterday that the penalties of the new Taylor Law, which bars strikes by public employes, should not apply to last month's 14-day work stoppage by the United Federation of Teachers.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 19 The Texas Railroad Commission got kind words but gloomy testimony today, on market demand for Texas oil in November, and cut production for the month by 63,860 barrels a day.

Dean Chance of the Minnesota Twins, who rebounded from his worst big league season in 1966 to win 20 games including a no-hitter, was named the American League's comeback player of the year for 1967 yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 Chicago State College reversed today an earlier rulling and hired Staughton C. Lynd as an associate professor of history.

HARLEM has its soul music and soul food, inspired by the slave days of the Deep South. And now Bergdorf Goodman has soul jewelry--but its inspiration goes all the way back to the days of ancient Greece. The jewelry --250 pieces--was designed by Elias Lalaounis, director ...

SOUSSE, Tunisia, Oct. 19 The United States chess champion, Bobby Fischer of New York, entered into a four-way tie for first place in the Interzonal Qualifying Tournament after completion of the third round here last night.

A program note written for this week's New York Philharmonic concert suggests that a new composition by Aaron Copland is now "automatically a major event" for both the music profession and the public. This is probably true.
The Dow Chemical Company attained record sales and earnings for the third quarter and first nine months of this year, the Midland, Mich.-based company reported yesterday.

MIAMI, Oct. 19 Two speeches by Premier Fidel Castro one last Sunday and one at a Havana memorial rally last night appeared to indicate that a difference of opinion about guerrilla-warfare tactics existed between him and Ernesto Che Guevara.
WHEN Don Aronow was younger, he used to cele brate a victory in a bone-jarring ocean powerboat race by going out on the town. Now he goes to sleep.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 19 Students boycotted classes at the University of Wisconsin today after a riot yesterday when policemen attempted to break up a demonstration over job recruiting by the Dow Chemical Company, manufacturers of napalm used in Vietnam.

Laurance S. Rockefeller is the leading candidate to become president of a nonprofit corporation being formed by Mayor Lindsay to develop Welfare Island, according to high officials in the city administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Government today issued a permit for the planned antiwar protest demonstration here this weekend and began flying paratroop units of the Army's crack 82d Airborne Division into Washington to enforce the permit's terms.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 19 Argentine meat packers expressed concern today about proposals that would cut Argentina's beef exports to the United States as such as 50 per cent.
The Board of Education authorized the city's 30 local school boards yesterday to assume far-reaching new powers in the selection of district superintendents and principals.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--The National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy is split by a dispute over whether to cooperate with extreme left-wing groups in its campaign against the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--A divided Administration gave lukewarm endorsement today to a proposal by former President Dwight D. Eisenhower that the United States sponsor an international effort to use nuclear energy to provide water for the Middle East.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 20 (AP) Former Premier Shigeru Yoshida, who shepherded Japan through the post-World War II era in cooperation with the late General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, died today at his seaside estate in Oiso, 35 miles west of Tokyo. He was 89 years old.

Time Inc., the publisher of Time, Life, Fortune and Sports Illustrated magazines, reported yesterday that its sales and earnings in the third quarter of 1967 declined from the results in the comparable period of 1966.
A five-day art show in Greenwich Village by 280 artists from the metropolitan area raised almost $8,000 in its first day to help pay the costs of the antiwar demonstration this weekend in Washington.

One important advance offered by the proposed new constitution is the opportunity to reorganize the sprawling executive branch of the state government. In the forty years since Alfred E. Smith gave effect to the last thorough reorganization more than a hundred independent agencies have been created outside the twenty departments fixed by the present Constitution.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19 The state's Hudson River Valley Commission today rejected a plan to string a 345,000-volt electric transmission line across the river south of Albany.
The upward push of industrial prices picked up momentum yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 19 Miguel Angel Asturias, a Guatemalan poet and novelist whose works scathingly criticize Latin-American dictatorship and "Yankee imperialism," has won the 1967 Nobel Prize for Literature.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff introduced today a bill to create a Federal office to help the local police track down missing persons.
BOWIE, Tex., Oct. 19 (UPI) An F-111A, the Air Force version of the controversial fighterbomber, exploded and crashed tonight in North Texas. The two crew members ejected safely.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 19 (AP) Paul Silas scored 5 points in the closing minutes tonight as the St. Louis Hawks broke an 89-89 tie and defeated the Los Angeles Lakers, 100-95, in a National Basketball Association game.

Three organizations got a helping hand last night as more than 1,700 people turned out for different benefit parties the Ski Ball, the Legal Aid Society's party and the Boys Club of New York Autumn Ball.

MADRID, Oct. 19 The Duchess of Medina-Sidonia, Spain's crusading noblewoman, was sentenced to one year in prison and a fine of $166 today for having organized a farmers' protest last year in the wake of the loss of four United States hydrogen bombs in the Palomares area.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19 A United Nations report said today that only "a small fraction" of the refugees applying to return to the west bank of the Jordan River had been permitted to do so.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (Reuters) The telephone number given in the Nov. 4 issue of The Saturday Evening Post as that of MI-6 the overseas branch of the British Secret Service was changed today.

During the next six months consumers will increase their spending for new automobiles by 10 per cent and for major household durables by 4 per cent. At the same time, they will step up the number of single-family housing starts by 14 per cent.

Frank J. Sampson, a former leader of Tammany Hall and a retired vice president of the Slide-O-Chrome Corporation, died in an ambulance on the way to St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday after suffering a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 200 West 16th Street.
A QUAINT, pretty, picture postcard called "Life With Father" was unveiled at the New York City Center last night. However, it's no ordinary picture postcard no matter how familiar it seems.
LONDON, Oct. 19--British analysts have concluded that President Abdullah al-Salal of Yemen has decided to try to negotiate a settlement with the Yemeni royalists.
The stately grace of 17 schooners will fill New York Harbor tomorrow in the first sailing of the Mayor's Cup race.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19 Federal heart disease investigators reported today what was believed to be the first large sample of evidence linking the thickness of a person's blood with clots that cause strokes.
The Federal Reserve moved in the latest statement week to supply liberal amounts of credit to the nation's banking system, according to figures released yesterday.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, Oct. 19 On Sept. 3, Roman Catholics of Bienhoa province, who number 30,000 in an electorate of 180,000, dutifully followed the recommendations of their priests in the national elections.

In the parliaments of mankind and literature authors far outnumber peacemakers. That is essentially why the award of the Nobel Prize for Literature, unlike the one for Peace, so often points up geographical diversity and is always controversial.

A huge diamond, turned up in a "pick-and-shovel operation" on a tiny mining stake in the African kingdom of Lesotho last May and now ranked as the seventh largest gem diamond known, has been acquired by Harry Winston, Inc., of Fifth Avenue.

The grim coup scored by the French aircraft industry with its $20-million sale of Mirage V fighterbombers to Peru the first supersonic jets to go to Latin America has had its dismally predictable effect in Washington. The effort to keep competition among the Latin military at the subsonic level at least until the turn of the decade has now broken down.

THE "big game" here Sunday between the Giants and Green Bay has brought about a small revival of a phenomenon of the 1960's the motel TV exodus. When the Giants were flying high from 1961 through 1963, thousands of fans who lacked tickets drove to Connecticut ...
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to decide if lower Federal courts can bar large housing developers from refusing to sell homes to Negroes.

Alger Hiss said last night that while the New Deal did not achieve its goal of ending the Depression, it did create a framework without which the rapid mobilization for World War II would have been impossible.
Sales of new cars in 1968 may have been seriously underestimated by the automotive industry, a senior executive of the Chrysler Corporation said here yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 19 A Government agency rejected today a proposed price increase of a penny by The Daily Mirror, Britain's largest daily newspaper, with a circulation of 5.2 million.

The chairman of a Senate subcommittee yesterday toured a ward of sane, relatively ablebodied elderly patients at Bronx State Hospital, a mental institution. Its director told him that 25 per cent of the hospital's 448 elderly patients could be discharged if there were homes to receive them.

There have been 10 homicides in the Ninth Precinct in the East Village this year, and each one has swelled the number of calls and letters coming into an old red brick building several miles downtown--the headquarters of the Police Missing Persons Bureau.

Like so many Clarence Darrows, a handful of hippies charmed, delighted and seemingly convinced a hall full of psychiatrists Wednesday night that their life-style was not only beautiful but good, orderly and sturdy.

Jean Tinguely, the Franco-Swiss creator of philosophical machines, held an international communications congress spellbound yesterday while he put together a towering contrivance that finally delivered a message on how to cope with surplus production. It smashed a case of beer bottles.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Oct. 19 A deadlocked Federal Court jury was ordered today to continue its deliberattions in the trial of 18 men charged with a conspiracy in 1964 to "eliminate" three young civil rights workers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19--North Vietnam has rejected the proposals for ending the Vietnam war that Secretary of State Dean Rusk enunciated at a news conference last Thursday.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, V.I., Oct. 19 Redfaced Democratic Governors, their confidential tie-line to the White House made public, re- asserted today their intention to press their Republican colleagues for a vote of confidence in the Vietnamese policy of President Johnson.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Within a year scientists may have nearly conclusive proof of the guilt or the innocence of a group of common viruses as causes of human cancer.
The 11 Negro delegates to the Constitutional Convention declared yesterday that the constitution it adopted contained the strongest bill of rights in the country.

The National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam is rallying students and antiwar organizations from all over the country to "confront the warmakers" in a huge demonstration in Washington tomorrow.
LONDON, Oct. 19 The Cunard Shipping Company is going to sell three more liners and dismiss 2,000 staff members to stave off disaster after a loss of 2-million ($5.6-million) in six months.
DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP) Negotiators for the Ford Motor Company and the striking United Automobile Workers got together again today, but only in subcommittees.
For career women, this is a special week National Business Week. Each year the Business and Professional Women of New York City, Inc., names two outstanding women.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 19 Continental bankers were hopefull today that a new interest rate war could be avoided in Europe despite the increase in the British bank rate to 6 per cent.

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 19 The American Venus probe, Mariner 5, swept past the planet today and returned clear scientific data that, on preliminary analysis, apparently contradict some findings by the Soviet capsule that landed on Venus yesterday.
Stock prices rallied in brisk trading yesterday morning but the advance fell apart in the afternoon.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19 Igor Ter-Ovanesyan of the Soviet Union equaled the world record and gave history's best long-jumping exhibition today in the third International Sports Competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Control of community action policies under the antipoverty program will be vested largely in Governors and local political leaders if the House adopts amendments approved last night by its Education and Labor Committee.
Al Jackson took a figurative elevator ride yesterday from baseball's glittering penthouse to its murky basement. But the basement at least was home.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, professor of psychology at City College, has asked Superintendent of Schools Dr. Bernard E. Donovan to remove the principal of a Manhattan high school because of the principal's "authoritarian threat" to expel a "troubled child."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 19 The latest compilation of American casualties in Vietnam shows a sharp climb reflecting an increase in fighting in all areas except the Mekong Delta, a United States spokesman announced today.

Fifteen tons of ground ice, spread over the sidewalk front ing on the New York Coliseum's Columbus Circle entrance, gave the opening of the annual International Ski and Winter Sports Show a wintry touch yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Senator Henry M. Jackson deplored today the "negative" turn taken in the Senate Vietnam debate and expressed concern that debasing criticism of Administration policies could lead to loss of the war.

A pushing, dragging, punch- ing, club-swinging clash between students and the police erupted on the Brooklyn College campus yesterday during a demonstration to protest the appearance of two Navy re- cruiting officers.

PARIS, Oct. 19 A French historian has written in a new book that Gen. Charles de Gaulle believes the police in the United States knew that President Kennedy would be assassinated, and that they wanted Lee Harvey Oswald to be killed.

The anniversary of the Battle of White Plains, during the Revolutionary War, will be marked by the Sons of the Revolution at their annual tea dance next Friday in the Starlight Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The dance is always held on the Friday nearest the battle date, which was Oct. 28, 1776.

IF the World Series did nothing else, it earned for Carl Yastrzemski a nationwide recognition as an exceptional ballplayer and a new respect from even the most critical lodge brothers in the baseball business. His heroics on the field were so obvious that the recognition sprung forth full-panoplied, like Athena springing from the brow of Zeus.

PARIS Iranians do not refer to Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson as Claudia Taylor, which she once was. So it puzzles them when Americans and other foreigners refer to Her Imperial Majesty Farah Pahlavi, Empress of Iran, by her maiden name. She was Farah Diba before her marriage on Dec. 21, 1959.
Prices of stocks on the London market were practically unaffected yesterday by the half-point rise to 6 per cent in the British bank rate. Most dealers had apparently anticipated the increase.

A girl and two young men who had run away from uppermiddle-class Westchester families to live in the East Village received prison sentences yesterday in Federal court for conspiring to possess and sell LSD.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 19 The United for Peace party will have nine candidates on the Nassau County ballot Nov. 7 as a result of a unanimous ruling by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, Second Department.

The Pennsylvania and the New York Central railroads were told yesterday by a threejudge court to go ahead and merge. If anyone is unhappy with the decision the court gave him 15 days to appeal to the United States Supreme Court.
BONN, Oct. 19 An official of the miners' union said today that the extreme rightwing National Democratic party in West Germany was trying to enlist the support of Ruhr coal miners.

The League of New York Theaters, a group of producers and theater owners, has urged its members to stop reporting their weekly box-office receipts to newspapers and to Variety, the weekly trade publication of the amusement would.
A heavy selloff in the last half-hour of trading snuffed out an early rally on the American Stock Exchange and the list ended with prices mixed in very active trading.
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 19--Nassau County motorists are losing at least $100,000 a year in overcharges on the state's gasoline sales tax, County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said today.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19--Helmeted policemen clashed with about 100 chanting antiwar demonstrators today at Chicago's induction center.

Hedevar, the sacrificial rabbit of the Woodward Stakes, was a formidable race horse on his own yesterday in the feature event at Aqueduct. The 5-year-old campaigner, owned by Mrs. Edith Bancroft, beat Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Understanding by a neck in a onemile test, running in front all the way.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Oct. 14 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

IT is a sad commentary on life but optimism is gen erally misplaced. When people originally suggested the possibility that this year's New York theater season would be above average, that seemed no great aspiration. After all everyone was saying with a kind of manic intensity: "Well, it can't be worse than last season, ...

The National League unhappy at the American League's decision to move the Kansas City Athletics to Oakland next season and to take in Seattle and a new Kansas City club to form a 12-team league in 1969, criticized the move yesterday and suggested indirectly that the American League reconsider.
Sugar dealers were talking yesterday about a buying plan proposed a well-known dealer with New York and British connections to Brazil.

The bond market, from almost everyone's point of view, continued to brighten yesterday. Bond prices rose, pleasing traders. Interest rates declined, to the satisfaction of borrowers. And the second new corporate issue in two days was sold quickly after it was offered, making underwriters happy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) Maryland and Texas brought to the Supreme Court today an important test suit challenging the extension of Federal minimum wage and hour standards to about 1.7 million state employes.

THE mod movement in the furniture industry "has already failed," said Milo Baughman, the American furniture designer who is credited with bringing bold patterns, psychedelic colors, lighting and pop accessories to the fore a year ago. He said that consumer resistance to many aspects of the style was too strong for it to last.
The Citizens Union announced yesterday it was backing the incumbents in the Nov. 7 elections for district attorneys in the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 19--The United States Ambassador to the Organization of American States. Sol M. Linowitz, said today that reports of "an alleged arms race in Latin America" were exaggerated.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 20--The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Ann Pulaski to Mark Stewart Mertens took place this evening in the Congregational Church of Manhasset. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Charles A.Pulaski of Port Washington and Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mertens of Manhasset.

BOSTON is famous--inter alia I suppose--for tea parties, beans and a symphony orchestra. No one, however, talks about its coffee. No one, for that matter, talks too much about its ballet company, but I suspect that this is one of Boston's developing assets.

About a year ago the eminent cyclist and cardiologist Dr. Paul Dudley White looked straight at me from the TV screen and said, "Whenever anybody asks me if he's going stale or losing his creative ability, I feel the muscles of his legs."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20--A compromise was reached in the Senate today on a bill to provide a new method for exposing Communists within the United States. The accord assured passage of the measure Monday.

The historic accomplishments of the three new Nobel laureates in physiology--Drs. George Wald, Haldan K. Hartline, and Ragnar Granit--can be stated simply:taken together, their research has gone far to explain the miracle of vision, that incredibly complex process by which light striking the eye becomes a picture of the external world perceived in the brain.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct 20 -- The first vehicular bridge has been thrown across the Jordan River since the war in June between the Arabs and Israelis, in which all the bridges connecting eastern Jordan with the west bank of the river now occupied by Israel were destroyed.
ALBANY, Oct. 20--The main speaker at the 31st convention of the state N.A.A.C.P. urged tonight that the proposed state constitution be defeated at the polls Nov. 7.

YONKERS, Oct. 20--The $25,000 La Paloma Pace for 2-year-old fillies at Yonkers Raceway tonight was won by Lawrence B. Sheppard's homebred, Berinda Hanover, a Tar Heel bay with limited racing experience on a half-mile track.
LONDON --Licking tax stamps to paste on thousands of brokerage house contracts has been a daily chore of London clerks for 56 years.
Unions whose membership depends on a strong United States merchant fleet have found a sort of captive audience for their plea: the Governors' Conference on board the Independence in Caribbean waters.
A COMPANY whose spec tacular ups and downs have startled traders this year, Liquidonics Industries, Inc., is startling annual-report readers as well.

ST. PAUL, OCt. 20 (AP)-- The Minnesota Supreme Court reversed today a $20,000 libel award won by Arnold Rose, a University of Minnesota profes, sor and former legislator who had been accused by a right wing organization of collaborat ing with Communists.

Gratified by a first-day's attendance of 14,700, which surpassed last year's opening turnout by 20 per cent, the producers of the International Ski an Winter Sports show last night were expecting a record of 100,000 visitors for their four-day session at the New York Coliseum.

HOUSTON, Oct. 20 -- The United States Ryder Cup team of golf professionals tossed aside tradition and adopted the British ball on home soil today and they led the visitors from Britain, 5 to 2 , as the international series opened.

The five days of Open hearings held by Senator Edward Kennedy's Judiciary Subcommittee on Refugees have painted a graphic picture of what it means to be a Vietnamese peasant caught in the crossfire of the war in South Vietnam.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 --On a warm summer evening four months ago Dr. Irvine Page was about to retire for the night at his home in Cleveland. He had spent a busy day examining heart patients and overseeing cardiac research, as he had for the last 40 years.
LONDON, Oct. 20--Britain's labor strife intensified today with a growing rail strike that crippled travel in many parts of the country.

HARRISBURG, Pa, Oct. 20 --Bill Steinkraus of Noroton, Conn., the captain of the United States Equestrian Team, rode two horses not quite perfectly to win today's international jumping competition of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 20 (AP)-- Judge Robert E. Myers ended his search today for someone researching the existence of a human soul.
ST. CROIX, Virgin Islands, Oct. 20--Republican Governors blocked today a Democratic effort to win a bipartisan endorsement for President Johnson's policies in Vietnam.
Investors closed out an active week on the American Stock Exchange yesterday by doing more selling than buying. Prices declined fairly steadily throughout the day.

The leadership of the Northern California Regional Office of the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, resigned yesterday in a dispute with the parent group over alleged cooperation with extreme leftwing antiwar organizations.

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 20-- Mariner 5 began early this morning to radio to earth the full recorded account of what it learned during its successful two-hour flight yesterday by the planet Venus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)--The American Newspaper Publishers Association endorsed today the Administration's proposed 23 per cent rate increase, spread over three years, for newspapers and second class mail.
W.R. Grace Co. announced yesterday a sharp decline in profits during the third quarter and first nine months, despite an increase in sales.

THE Metropolitan Champi onships continue at the New York Hilton today, with the Open Pairs scheduled at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M. There is also a Limited Pairs, restricted to players with less than 100 master points.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 (UPI) --Leaders of 20,000 striking steel haulers agreed today to submit a settlement proposal to the rank and file for a vote. 'The decision came after a four-hour meeting of 20 leaders from eight states. In a brief statement, they said:
"A landmark decision. This reflects the changes that have occurred in the South."

The Man o'War weight-forage stakes, which in its short history has become a race that ranks with the Wood Memoral in its appeal to the New York thoroughbred fan, will have its ninth running today at Aqueduct.

The auditorium of St. Bartholomew's Church will be the setting for a Flea Market on Nov. 9 from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Arts objects, china, silver, bric-a-brac and jewelry will be among the articles to be sold for the benefit of charities of the women's division of the church.

A dream of ecumenical cooperation is coming into being at the model community of Columbia, Md., midway between Washington and Baltimore, where 13 Protestant denominations are temporarily sharing a common place of workship.
DETROIT, Oct. 20--A new economic agreement between the Ford Motor Company and the striking United Automobile Workers is nearly complete, union negotiators said today.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 20-- American industry, particularly exporters, was urged here today by a leading container shipping expert to take advantage of the efficiencies offered by containerization.

The Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) reported yesterday that thirdquarter investment income offset net operating losses. The company said it wound up the period with net income of $809,831, equal to 8 cents a share.

The stock market ended the trading week on a downward note yesterday. Price declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances for the fifth consecutive session.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20-- The United Steelworkers of America joined the industry's management today in a drive for legislation to curtail steel imports.
A strike by thousands of Brooklyn College students angered by police action on their campus virtually closed the school yesterday.

THE Green Bay Packers will perform in Yankee Stadium for the first time since the 1962 National Football League championship game when they oppose the Giants tomorrow. Despite their upset by Minnesota last week, the Packers are favored by nearly two touchdowns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20--A New York safety engineer, who has recorded more than 400 observations of the sun and stars to check his calculations, was granted a patent this week on a navigation comnuter for astronauts.

Negotiations between the American Broadcasting Company and the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians broke down early yesterday morning after an allnight session. No agreement could be reached to end the union's strike against the network that began Sept. 22.

CAMIRI, Bolivia, Oct. 18--The shuddering DC-3, its stripped down interior full of cargo and poultry, circles Once over the baked landscape of low adobe houses and drops like a stone to the dirt runway.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP)-- Tartan Stable's Dr. Fager, expected to be a 1-5 favorite, drew the No.1 post position today against six rivals for the $121,360 Hawthorne Gold Cup at 1 miles tomorrow. The winner will earn $72,360.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20--The left wing of Vietnamese politics, which has been ostracized for almost a decade, is expected to stage a modest comeback in the lower house elections Sunday.
DECATUR, Miss., Oct. 20 (AP)--State officials blamed the Justice Department today for the fact that no state charges had been filed in the 1964 slaying of three civil rights workers.

ROME, Oct. 20--Two leaders of the recently concluded World Congress of Roman Catholic laymen insisted today that the gathering had asked for a lifting of the church ban on birth control despite conservatives' efforts to deny it.

TOKYO, Oct. 20--Former Pre mier Shigeru Yoshida, who guided postwar Japan to re covery and prosperity and al lied her firmly with the United States, died today at his sea side estate in Oisi. He was 89 years old. Death was attrib uted to a heart attack that followed a gall bladder infec tion.

MOSCOW--No draft cards are being burned in the Soviet Union to protest the new draft law enacted last week. But it compensates by reducing the term of actual service by one year.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 21--Secretary General Thant proposed today that the United Nations Secretariat be reorganized. It is expected that the General Assembly's Committee on Budget and Administration will accept the proposals without serious objection.

A new international bank has been formed by the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia, the Wachovia Bank and Trust Company in North Carolina and Zilkha Sons, Inc., a private financial house in New York.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it was making "a thorough review" of all automation programs in order to set up priorities for handling the increase in share volume.
Prices closed very firm on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as investors shrugged off the recent rise in the bank rate and developments in the Middle East.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 23-- Albert (Kid Blast) Gallo, who has been identified as a member of the Mafia in Brooklyn, and another man were arrested by the Nassau County district attorney's office today on charges relating to a ticketcashing scheme at Roosevelt Raceway.

On a worktable in a l4thcentury Florentine palace filled with Italian Renaissance paintings and Flemish tapestries, restorers repairing works of art damaged in last year's flooding of Florence have made an important art discovery.
The sinking of the Israeli destroyer Elath by Egyptian missiles off Sinai makes more difficult and more urgent the United Nations' task of finding a formula for peace in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23--The Supreme Court declined today to review a test case concerning the right of the Amish to refuse, on religious grounds, to send their children to stateaccredited schools.

Giving an exhibition of riding worthy of a top grade stakes performance, which--of course--should always be the case, Braulio Baeza guided Thomas Nichols's 3-year-old colt, Jean-Pierre, to victory in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday.

Green Bay found itself at long last and now heads forcefully in the direction of the Super Bowl. Richard Nixon is starting back on the political trail this week after a period of mourning for the death of his mother, and he talks about his past and future now quite objectively-- almost as if he were discussing the prospects of some other Presidential candidate.

ROME, Oct. 24--The spokesman for the United States Roman Catholic hierarchy asked today for clear instructions from Rome to check "abuses" in experimental new forms of church liturgy.

The Republic Steel Corporation reported sharply reduced profits yesterday for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.
Orthodox, Conservative and Reform rabbis will teach a course together this fall at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced yesterday it would increase its price for industrial and refined grades of sulphur by 25 cents a hundredweight, effec tive Nov. 1, for spot accounts and Jan. 1 for contract business.

SATELLTTE BEACH, Fla. Oct. 24 (UPI)--Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. waded through a sea of yelling children today and put Billy Churchill's frozen-pop stand back in business by buying a drink of Florida orange juice.
LONDON, Oct. 24--Prime Minister Wilson said today that the French position on Britain's application to join the European Common Market was unwarranted and inadmissible.
The Norfolk Western Railway reported yesterday its net income in the third quarter slid to $18,998,000, or $2.07 a share, from $24,774,000, or $2.67 a share, in the same period of 1966.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24-- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee narrowly approved today a bill to close the main sales outlets for the lagging New York State lottery.

An all-black student group agreed yesterday to stop opposing a white group that has been trying to block the construction of a building at City College.
Three of the nation's major utilities, the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., the New York Telephone Company and the American Electric Power Company, yesterday announced higher earnings.

CAIRO, Oct. 24--Travelers returning here tonight reported that fires were spreading over a 10-square-mile area at Suez, where two big oil refineries were set ablaze this afternoon by Israeli guns.
Citizens for Clean Air will hold its annual awards dinner on Nov.6 in the WaldorfAstoria's Grand Ballroom. James F. Oates Jr. heads the dinner committee.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24-- Senator Albert Gore proposed today that the United States "honorably extricate" itself from Vietnam by accepting neutralization of Southeast Asia, including Vietnam.

GENEVA, Oct 24--There has been a sharp increase in the number of smallpox cases this year, the year in which the World Health Organization officially started its campaign to eradicate the disease from the world within a decade.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24-- Since diving was introduced to the Olympic Games in 1904, the United States has won 36 of 47 springboard and platform titles, sometimes sweeping the medals. Now, the honeymoon appears over.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 24 --Hundreds of stately, shade trees have been felled, scenic vistas have been bulldozed and old stone bridges have been razed in the modernization of an original stretch here of the Bronx River Parkway, the first automobile parkway in the world.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24-- Francis R. Smith won a legal battle today to retain his leadership of Philadelphia's Democratic organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to impose penalties on railroads that detain freight cars belonging to other railroads--a situation blamed to some extent for creating severe shortages of boxcars.
CORCORAN, Calif., Oct. 25 --An outbreak of Type C botulism has killed 20,000 to 25,000 migratory birds, mostly pintail ducks, in a six-squaremile area of marshy farmland 25 miles southwest of here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--Social pressures to discover the "inner self" are almost irresistible nowadays. Everyone fearless enough to jangle his ganglia with chemicals has already made the expedition and returned to report wondrous discoveries.

LONDON, Oct. 25--Britain's decision to phase out her aircraft carriers is criticized in the 1967-68 edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, which was published today. The standard naval reference contends in its 70th edition that air power will remain an indispensable naval weapon.
DETROIT, Oct. 25--Eighteen Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish leaders pledged today to risk fine or imprisonment to assist those who resist the military draft on the ground of conscience.

Thieves struck at Kennedy International Airport again yesterday, taking two packages of diamonds valued at $50,295 from a truck shortly after the gems arrived here on a Northwest Airlines flight from Tokyo.
Joseph M. Proskauer, who has been a sort of one-man ecumenical movement for several decades, was cited by Fordham University yesterday as "one of God's own gentlemen."

Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, one of the big, quiet, conservative agencies, yesterday unveiled an "in" group, a "now" group, a "turned on" group that is dedicated to bringing the sound of today to Dancer advertising.
There was only polite applause for the Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night when their muscle-aching game with the Chicago Black Hawks ended.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 (AP)--More United States servicemen in Vietnam--524 so far this year--are arrested in marijuana charges than for any other major offense, the Army provost marshal for the Pacific area said today. The figure represents a sharp increase over last year's rate.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 25 --Although he is approaching his 76th birthday, Dr. Gordon Barrett, a local osteopath, believes in keeping on the go when it involves hunting.
Stock prices in London reached new peaks yesterday as buying continued.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee disclosed plans today for a sweeping investigation of organizations of the New Left, including militant civil rights and antiwar groups.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--American consumers continued to save an unusually high proportion of their after-tax incomes in the third quarter of this year, the Council of Economic Advisers disclosed.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday called the ultra-right Minutemen a potential threat to the state and urged legislation to make paramilitary activity in such organizations a felony punishable by up to 15 years in jail.
The feeling in this country that the United States made a mistake in sending troops to fight in Vietnam has almost doubled since August, 1965, according to a survey by the Gallup Poll.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 25--The Security Council unanimously adopted today a resolution condemning violations of the cease-fire in the Middle East and demanding that Israel and the United Arab Republic "cease immediately" all military activity and cooperate with the United Nations Truce Supervision Oreanization.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25(AP) --The Pennsylvania Railroad reported today that profits fell 41 per cent in the first nine months from the 1966 period and 6 per cent for the third quarter.

A reluctant Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to permit Columbia University to go ahead with its plan to put up a gymnasium building in Morningside Park.

A 32-year-old medical student last night was found not guilty by reason of insanity in the murder of his mother-in-law.

ROME, Oct. 25--Prelates of the first Roman Catholic synod of bishops will vote Friday on a proposal to establish a permanent commission of theo logians in Rome to solve doctrinal problems presented by "a crisis of civilization and culture."

THE Harmonic Club, 4 East 60th Street, which was founded in 1852 and ranks as the second-oldest of New York's social clubs, has a firmly established bridge tradition. Last Monday saw the climax of its regular schedule of rubber and duplicate games when 34 tables were in a play in a special tournament under the supervision of Bill Root.
Earnings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the second largest producer of steel in the United States, fell in the third quarter to their lowest level in four years, the company reported yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 25 (UPI)--About 200 Harvard University students released a job recruiter for the Dow Chemical Company tonight from a campus conference room where they had imprisoned him for more than nine hours.
A DARK cloud called "Where People Gather" moved into the Gramercy Arts Theater last night. Careful examination revealed the following scraps of silver-- or maybe just aluminum-foil --lining.

The Towers Hotel in Brooklyn was converted into a giant toy town yesterday, with 216 toys on display. But they were all of the canine variety. The occasion was the 35th annual Progressive Dog Club show, a fixture limited to toy breeds.
MARCIA DAVENPORT blandly told Charles Scribner she would like to write a book that would be hailed as a work of art--and perhaps sell no more than 1,200 copies.

Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton announced yesterday that he would vote against the proposed state constitution, mainly because of its failure to give more home-rule powers to the cities and its elimination of the ban on aid to church-supported schools.

Dr. Francis P. Kilcoyne, president of Brooklyn College, told his faculty yesterday that established student government was "blitzed" by a small group and made "totally ineffective" last Thursday by a demonstration against Navy recruiters in a school corridor.

Parents angrily protested yesterday at a Brooklyn public school for emotionally disturbed children after the principal had sent 30 pupils home with notes that there were "no classrooms" for their instruction.

A patch of woods is sprouting on an unlikely stretch of East 42d Street near the United Nations. Odder still, the tiny glade is indoors, enclosed by glass walls more than 125 feet high.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- The flow of United States arms to the underdeveloped nations has more than doubled over the last six years, rising to nearly $900-million in the fiscal year that ended June 30.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 25-- The coronation of Iran's Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, and the Empress Farah tomorrow is intended as "a focal point in our history," in the words of Premier Amir Abbas Hoveida.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 25--Dr. Stephen Sargent Visher, a geographer and nationally known authority on weather, died here today after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

Soviet construction of a first aircraft carrier confirms an ominous trend toward investment in military forces capable of intervening at a distance from Russia's borders.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad announced plans yesterday to cut back passenger service to head off an expected rise in its passenger deficit from $2.8-million last year to more than $6-million this year.

PARIS--One of the great men of France, who had spellbound American visitors with his conversation during one of those long, leisurely lunches at which French food and talk excel, was asked what judgment he would make on Charles de Gaulle.

A $6-million center for graduate study and research will be established by the New School for Social Research next September on Fifth Avenue between 13th and 14th Streets, Dr. John R. Everett the president, announced yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Oct. 25 --Zoonoses, the passage of diseases from household pets, laboratory animals, cattle and fowl to humans, are posing an increasing threat to public health, a group of veterinarians said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct 25--A new Federal outdoor playground, stretching from the Canadian border and including a North Cascades national park in tha State of Washington, was approved today by the Senate Interior Committee.

What is a commodity future contract? It is a little like buying (or selling) a claim on tomorrow in terms of a basic, useful product.

JERUSALEM, Oct.25--Smallarms fire early today by Egyptian soldiers north of the area of yesterday's shelling of Suez went unanswered by the Israelis. Antiaircraft fire was also reported, but the Israelis said they had no planes in the air.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25-- A new nonpartisan committee, including former Presidents Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower, several former Cabinet officers and high-ranking World War II commanders, gave strong endorsement today to the Administration's policy in Vietnam.

NORTHEASTERN'S football coach, Joe Zabilski, waits patiently each weekday for some of his players to return from their offices so he can get on with full-scale practice before sundown. Like a wife, he is occasionally impatient, but he tolerates the condition because he's stuck...

Receiving equipment to enable the American merchant marine fleet to navigate by means of the Navy's satellites will be on the market in about two months, according to Glenn Corrington, manager of the satellite production program of Radio Corporation of America.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25--The Senate refused today to require President Johnson, to make sharp cutbacks in Federal spending.

LONDON, Oct. 25--Lieut. Col. Yevgeny V. Runge of the Soviet State Security Committee (K.G.B.), who defected the United States, was described today in the Bonn intelligence community as the most successful Communist agent known to have penetrated secrets of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

ROBERT von RANKE GRAVES got the broken nose that makes him such a rugged looking character by tackling low in a rugby game. That mark of his youth advertises an essential factor of the character of the poet, novelist, essayist and translator.
Arthur H. Taylor Jr. went shopping this week for some new clothing--about $25,000 worth.

YONKERS, Oct. 25--Flamboyant romped home as all 3-10 favorites should--by nine lengths--tonight in the $25,000 Hudson Futurity Trot for 3year-old fillies at Yonkers Raceway. This 11th edition of the Hudson was no contest as Billy Haughton sent the filly to the top just past the seveneighths pole.

WARSAW, Oct. 26 The sentencing of a young Jewish woman to three years in prison today prompted her blind employer to charge that she had been the victim of anti-Semitism, police brutality and torture.
LONDON, Oct. 26 The closing of the Suez Canal has cost Britain an average of $56million a month, Prime Minister Wilson told the House of Commons today.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 94.6 on Wednesday from the downward revised level of 94.5 on Tuesday.
A realignment of its top management was announced yesterday by Mutual of New York, a leading life insurance company.

MACAO, Oct. 25 The antiquated diesel ferryboat from Macao City takes 45 minutes to reach Coloane, the more distant of the two islets that, together with the little peninsula on which the city stands, make up the overseas Portuguese territory of Macao.

For years it has been widely believed that one tends to forget things that are associated with unpleasant experiences, but no one could prove it. Now two researchers at Princeton University report having done so.
The Raytheon Company, a major manufacturer of electronics products, announced yesterday that it would acquire the Badger Company of Cambridge, Mass., through a merger.
A man with a pistol in a shoulder holster invaded a graduate students' dormitory at Pratt Institute last night and robbed one girl and raped another.
Several private schools in the New York area are giving increasing attention to art as part of the day-to-day background.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

SO far the Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center seems to have made such reputation as it has with mediocre productions of magnificent plays. Last night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, it neatly reversed the trend. This was "a special invitational production under the supervision of Saint Subber" of Lillian Hellman's "The Little Foxes."
FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Oct. 26 Maj. Gen. Thomas H. Lipscomb was absolved today of charges that he illegally influenced courts-martial to give soldiers harsh sentences.
Three advocates of repeal of the state ban on aid to churchrelated schools defended as accurate yesterday the current advertisements in the campaign for repeal.

GARY, Ind., Oct. 26 Richard G. Hatcher, a 34-year-old Negro who is the Democratic candidate for Mayor in a municipal election Nov. 7, appealed to Federal officials today to prevent vote frauds and insure a fair contest.

The Public Broadcast Laboratory, which will begin a two-hour Sunday night television news and culture program on Nov. 5 under a $10million grant from the Ford Foundation, plans to present "commercials" attacking the credibility of TV advertisements.

WHEN Notre Dame and Michigan State collided on the gridiron a year ago, enthusiasts dusted off a hoary phrase and described it as "The Game of the Century." They are to meet again at South Bend on the morrow and this one barely qualifies as "The Game of the Day." Unexpected misadventures have deflated both teams and driven them from the high rankings each rated the previous season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The backlash mounted today against proposals in the Senate to restrict imports of many products.

Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller, 59. Governor of New York, has a plain office in an old flatfront house at 22 West 55th Street in Manhattan, and a hideaway in an ancient family mansion nearby. The sidewalks leading to these unmarked doorways are worn down these days by reporters wanting to know what on earth Mr. Rockefeller meant by saying "I don't want to be President."
DETROIT, Oct. 26 Detroit industry is making a major effort to cut unemployment in the Negro ghetto and improve the ability of Negroes to find jobs.

A procedure for borrowing by the state that combines flexibility and fiscal responsibility is a constructive feature of the proposed new Constitution. The change would free the state from the handcuffs imposed by the present requirement that all state borrowing be approved by the voters at a referendum a much more restrictive rule than either Federal or city governments have to observe.

The bond market appeared unflappable yesterday. The volume of new corporate securities for sale over the next two and a half months increased by $247-million, but most recently marketed bonds rose slightly or closed unchanged.
DETROIT, Oct. 26 The National Council of Churches was urged today to make plans for a one-day nationwide general strike if the Administration further escalates the war in Vietnam.

MADRID, Oct. 26 The Spanish Government warned today that its security forces would act with "all energy" to "prevent and repress" nationwide demonstrations planned for tomorrow by underground labor organizations.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange yesterday climbed to new peaks as buying interest quickened.

DAKAR, Senegal Leopold Senghor, the poet of Negritude and President of Senegal, embodies the best in France's colonial legacy. Dutch imperialism stressed commerce and British imperialism stressed leaving behind efficient civil services wherever it withdrew. The French placed emphasis on culture.

LAS VEGAS, Oct. 26 A 64 by any golfer named Spray usually would sound like a paradox. But today Steve Spray scored a seven-under-par 64 in the second round and led the $100,000 Sahara tournament by two strokes.

MONTREAL, Oct. 26 The two great French-Canadian folk heroes of the late nineteen-fifties, Boom Boom Geoffrion and Jean Beliveau, now working for different causes, scored the only goals tonight as the New York Rangers and Montreal Canadiens churned their way to a 1-1 tie.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Oct. 26 Dr. Mitchell Balter, a research psychologist with the National Institute of Mental Health and an authority on drub use, said today he was deeply worried that organized crime might begin producing and marketing synthetic marijuana.

Relatively tight money conditions, which had prevailed in principal financial centers for the two preceding weeks, eased considerably in the week ended Wednesday. This was the interpretation put by banking sources on figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 26 (UPI)--Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, called today for "a quiet resignation" from Secretary of State Dean Rusk.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 The Johnson Administration's decision to begin selling supersonic F-5 jet fighter-bombers to Latin America is arousing considerable opposition in Congress.
Sales and earnings of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation fell sharply in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday in Pittsburgh.
By his own cheerful admission, Alexander Wiley was "just a small-town banker, a businessman, lawyer and operator of a dairy who became a typical American success."
The MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., will benefit from the third annual Harvest of the Arts in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on Nov. 15.
LET me tell you quite bluntly that this king business has given me personally nothing but headaches," Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran said in Washington a few years ago.

A 44-story, $20-million office building will be erected in Columbus Circle as the home of a large industrial corporation that is consolidating its headquarters in New York, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
Consumption of newsprint in the United States decreased in September, but a new high was set for consumption for the first nine months of 1967.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 26 The seven-nation European Free Trade Association showed deep concern today over the danger of widening of the split between Western Europe's two...
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 26 (AP) Straight Deal virtually cinched handicap mare honors today when she won the $61,450 Spinster Stakes at Keeneland.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

The following is a list of 45 cargo thefts and robberies each totaling more than $1,000, at Kennedy International Airport from Dec. 15, 1966 to Oct. 25, 1967 as compiled by the Port of New York Authority.
The stock market made a selective advance yesterday and ended in the plus column for the first time in nine sessions.
