LENINGRAD, Oct. 25 The treasures of the Hermitage Museum seem to be the only glories of this beautiful city not being covered with a new coat of paint, festooned with colored lights or strung with garlands bearing slogans.

ROME, Oct. 26 Pope Paul VI and Ecumenical Patriarch Athenagoras I, senior prelate of Orthodox Christianity, embraced today in St. Peter's Basilica and pledged continuing efforts to end the thousandyear-old schism between their churches.
CARTER LORD, Harvard University's fine pass catching end, has uttered a few words about the Harvard-Dartmouth game that surely will be regarded as treasonable by legions of Harvard and Yale Alumni.

Automobile manufacturers and the buying public are being put on notice that this year, and the next, and the year after, Government safety standards are going to be raised as regularly as models are changed. Possibly even more often.
Senator Robert F. Kennedy turned interrogator last night before an audience of 750 persons to show there are "no easy answers" to the Vietnam question.

The profit squeeze that has been pinching the airlines was overcome in the third quarter by United Air Lines, the nation's largest domestic trunkline, but it diluted the margin of Pan American World Airways, the United States' largest international airline, financial reports showed yesterday.

Rare Americana in two auction sales this week made the phrase "record price" a commonplace. Wednesday night's sale of part of the Thomas W. Streeter collection brought about double the sum expected at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
When Katharine Houghton, a pretty, 22-year-old actress, referred to the handsome woman sitting next to her as simply "my aunt," yesterday afternoon, it seemed somehow inadequate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Three former United States representatives to the United Nations said today that the United Nations ought to intervene in the Vietnam war. But they agreed it was not likely to do so.
THE first reaction of skeptics to a new "unbreakable" propeller called Thrust-O-Matic is to throw it on the floor and jump on it with both feet.
GENEVA, Oct. 26 The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe said today that prospects were favorable for a "timely resumption of rapid economic growth" this autumn in the United States.
"Lizzie Borden," as revived by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater last night, presented a curious paradox.

A State Supreme Court justice granted a divorce yesterday in what is believed to be the first court decision in the state involving the charge of cruel and inhuman treatment under the new divorce law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman announced today that the Government was returning next year to its 196166 policy of paying farmers for taking corn and other feed grain acreage out of production in a move to bolster farm prices further.

The big Brazilian deal that sugar traders have been awaiting was completed yesterday. Brazil sold a New York dealer 50,000 tons at 3 cents a pound for delivery next spring and an additional 120,000 tons to be spaced over all of 1968 at 2.65 cents a pound. Another arrangement involving about the same amount of sugar is pending.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The idea of arbitrating unresolved issues in steel-labor negotiations in 1968 has split the United Steelworkers of America leadership so deeply that many observers believe the proposal will die.
A 26-year-old Bronx man who caused a stir two years ago when he said that a police beating forced him to make a murder confession said in court yesterday that there was no beating at all.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 26--The mood was peaceful coexistence rather than warm friendship as Gov. George Romney and former Senator Barry Goldwater met tonight in a glare of television cameras.
Through the economic smog overhanging the nation, one signal is clearly visible corporate profits are down for the first nine months from the corresponding period of 1966.
Hospitals Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio has moved out of a subsidized dwelling owned by New York Hospital "because it might result in embarrassment" to the hospital.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP) Navy Heroine, with a strong stretch run, won the Kiwanis Club purse at Garden State Park today by a nose and gave her jockey, Walter Blum, a triple for the day.

YONKERS, Oct. 26 Billy Haughton, a harness racing driver for 27 of his 43 years, played the waiting game as he guided Spoiler to an easy victory in the $60,000 New York Sire Stakes one-mile test for 2-year-old racing colts and geldings at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Three scientists at the University of California, Berkeley, have challenged the validity of research purporting to show that LSD damages the genetic material of human beings.

Matthew L. Devine, chairman of the Amphenol Corporation, said yesterday the electronics concern would make "a review of all aspects" of the business of Solitron Devices, Inc., "before considering the advisability of a merger."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Harvey Smith, a square-jawed construction executive, dominated the puissance (high jumping) event so emphatically that he won the first two places tonight at the Washington International Horse Show.

A White House radiogram that fell into the hands of Gov. Ronald Reagan of California during a recent Governors conference aboard the liner Independence was apparently misdirected by mistake, the ship's chief radio operator said yesterday.

THE Pittsburgh International, opening today at the Carnegie Institute, is a venerable 77 years old if you count as its inception the first large exhibition of European paintings subsidized by Andrew Carnegie in 1890. The founder's twofold idea was that these big shows would be good for international relations, and would also give museums and collectors,...

The Zagreb Pro Arte String Quartet, organized in 1960 at the University of Zagreb in Yugoslavia, is already well known in Europe for its performances of contemporary music. So it was not surprising that the ensemble in its American debut last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music included two modern works, one of them American, as well as a Mozart Quartet in G and Schubert's "Death and the Maiden" Quartet.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 The Chrysler Corporation reported today its best third-quarter profit since 1950. Net income rose to $26.8-million, or 58 cents a share, more than four times the $6.5-million, or 14 cents a share, a year ago.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 26 A key member in the campaign staff of the Republican candidate for Nassau County Executive resigned today after he was accused of offering $3,000 to a secretary for confidential information about Eugene H. Nickerson, the incumbent.

The New York Central Railroad lurched into the red in the September quarter. The carrier attributed the period's loss of $3,951,469 to "the continued erosion of passenger and mail revenues." In the third quarter last year the Central had net income of $11,525,353, or $1.67 a share.
ATHENS, Oct. 26 Pavlos Totomis, Minister of Public Order, charged tonight that the leftist composer Mikis Theodorakis had led an anti-Government organization called the Patriotic Front.
Percy E. Sutton, Manhattan Borough President, called yesterday for the relief of garment center congestion through an arcade project.

TANJORE, India, Oct. 25 Farmers here in the leading rice-growing district of the state of Madras have written India's biggest agricultural success story of the year by tripling the size of their early crop.

HOW often has a householder watched a door to-door salesman leave with an order for a big-ticket item and wondered whether he had made a big mistake? Those experienced in door-todoor selling say it happens fairly often. But canceling sales contracts in such circumstances isn't easy.
The three-day smog last Thanksgiving caused 168 deaths in New York City, according to a paper presented here yesterday at a symposium on air pollution and respiratory diseases.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 26 Four holdup men stole two bags of silver and an undetermined amount of tin from a smelting company here today after hitting a policeman over the head, shooting a guard and trading shots with another guard. Three of the alleged robbers were captured 10 minutes later.

After going the 2 miles in the New York Turf Writers Cup hurdle race at Aqueduct yesterday, three horses were almost "wired together." The victory in the 29th running of the stakes went to the Chilean-bred Roublet, owned by Guilford Dudley Jr. A neck back was James Melton's My Chap. Brandon Hill, who finished third, was only a head farther back in the 10-horse field.

There comes a time in the life of every young musician when he suddenly picks up his head and begins playing the music instead of the notes. A few seem to be born with the talent, but all others must work at it.
In active bidding last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, a small portrait of a young girl by Jean Baptiste Camille Corot drew a record price of $310,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Both revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended Oct. 21 fell below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

PARIS, Oct. 26 The editor in chief of Soviet television news appealed today for a greater exchange of programs between his country and Western Europe and the United States. But he amusingly evaded a specific inquiry as to the Russian definition of news.

LORD TAYLOR has been stargazing. After consulting Xavoria Pove, its "astrologer-in-residence," and being assured that today's signs are auspicious, the store is launching a two-week festival of merchandise based on symbols from astrology, palmistry, numerology and the allied arts.
Tacked on the door of Herman Shumlin's bedroom-study, along with sundry clippings, scribbled memos and other items, is the line: "What is life but a series of inspired follies."
At 5:08 yesterday morning a 49-year-old man died of an incurable brain disease at Mount Sinai Hospital not an unusual event in a large metropolitan hospital.
About 150 of the Wall Street crowd showed up for dinner at the Pierre Hotel last night to find out just who did the best advertising in the year ended June 2.

In a move to maintain competitive pricing for its bonded abrasives products, the Carborundum Company announced yesterday that it was revising its price increases announced on Sept. 25.
The American Stock Exchange recorded its busiest session yesterday in 118 years of trading.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UPI)--Chicago's proposed "airport-in-the-lake" came closer to a reality today, as details for the site, 5 miles into Lake Michigan, were released.

ARMONK, N.Y., Oct. 26 Mrs. Gerda Appleby of Great Neck, L.I., and Mrs Dorothy McCarthy, Flushing, Queens, the fifth ranked team, led the way into the quarter-final round of the women's eastern invitation indoors doubles tennis championship at Armonk Tennis Club today by defeating Mrs. Pauline Garredo and Mrs. Lisa Connell, Westport, Conn., 6-4, 6-2.

GILMAN HOT SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 26--Here below the steep, rutted brown foothills of the San Jacinto mountains, in an area known as Massacre Canyon, Floyd Patterson has been preparing for his 12-round bout Saturday with Jerry Quarry in Los Angeles.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 26 (AP) Don Schollander, star of the United States' 1964 Olympics swimming team, captured his second and third first places tonight as the United States won four of the seven events in the Pre-Olympics.
An auction of 144 city-owned properties will be held Nov. 15 at the Roosevelt Hotel by the Department of Real Estate.

"The Brooklyn waterfront can stay closed forever, as far as we are concerned," an executive of a steamship line with pier facilities in Manhattan said yesterday as the Brooklyn waterfront shutdown went into its second week.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that increased efficiency and better garbage trucks expected to go into service in the city late this year would solve some of the Sanitation Department's "very serious problems."
ARCADIA, Fla., Oct. 26 (AP)--The last of Mr. and Mrs. James Richardson's seven children, 3-year-old Diannne, died today of agricultural insecticide poisoning. The others died yesterday.

At least $2,245,868 in cargo has been stolen in 45 major robberies at Kennedy International Airport since Dec. 15, 1966. This figure included $50,295 worth of diamonds taken Wednesday from a truck at the airport shortly after they had arrived from Tokyo.

TRENTON, Oct. 26 Gov. Richard J. Hughes accused Republican leaders today of whipping up a white backlash in New Jersey by trying to inject a racial busing issue into the legislative election campaign.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 per cent in September, the smallest increase since March, the Labor Department reported today.
An E.J. Korvette executive yesterday morning appraisingly eyed a busy salesgirl in a short skirt walking nearby. "We'll have to talk to the girls," he observed. "We don't want them too mini here."
RENO, Nev., Oct. 26 Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama began today the most extensive tour in his unofficial campaign for the Presidency.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 26--Navy pilots bombed a power plant in Hanoi today. It is the largest electrical plant in North Vietnam.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Political and Security Committee--Adopted two resolutions; heard statements on Treaty for Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons in Latin America.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) A Civil Aeronautics Board hearing examiner recommended today a sweeping overhaul of airline service between the United States and the Caribbean area.
ONE evening, in the home of a wellto-do Jewish family outside Mos cow, there was a long discussion about the worldwide campaign over the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union.

FRANK RYAN of the Cleveland Browns twisted an ankle again during practice on Wednesday. Under normal circumstances such a twist would cause a tremor through the ranks of the Browns and their supporters. But Ryan has such a long lead in the mostdamaged-quarterback sweep stakes this year...
The city issued summonses yesterday to six food stores in Spanish Harlem for allegedly overcharging or misrepresenting 51 of 90 advertised items.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP) An escaped convict forced his way into a women's dormitory at St. Bonaventure Univervsity near here today and terroized at least two coeds, a woman dean and a security guard before surrendering in a hail of bullets.
The owner of two East Side restaurants has charged that a State Liquor Authority investigator demanded $25,000 to drop proceedings to revoke his liquor licenses.

NUMEROUS campaign books, partisan and more or less nonpartisan, are already in the works. Among the first such is "The Republican Establishment," a speculative analysis that is nonpartisan enough to seem both reasonable and useful.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 26 A year ago Princeton was beaten decisively by Dartouth early in the season, then finished strong with successive victories over Harvard, Yale and Cornell to share in the Ivy League football championship.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 26 Diplomats pressed today for an early transfer of the Middle East situation from the publicity and passions of the Security Council to on-thespot discussions by a mediator with the Arab and Israeli Governments.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26--The House readily approved a $2.7-billion pay rise for military personnel today but came close to balking at $10-million in rent subsidies for the poor.
Spokesmen for the Dow Chemical Company, a napalm manufacturer, said yesterday that campus demonstrations against the company had not hurt its recruitment drive at universities.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday asked the City Planning Commission for $1.68million to build an enclosure for the Temple of Dendur, a gift from United Arab Republic to the United States.
A century ago "uptown Manhattan," particularly in the area of 66th Street and Lexington Avenue, was a collection of empty lots and fields with goats grazing on some of them.
Indicated third-quarter earnings of Standard Oil Company of Indiana rose to $73,900,000, or $1.04 a share, from $69,500,000, or 98 cents a share, in the year-ago period.

OSLO, Norway As if being beautiful weren't enough, thousands of Norwegian girls each year add to their stock in the marriage market by attending state-run schools to learn such domestic skills as cooking, child-care and even potato farming in order to become model husmoren.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 26 (AP) A former British Open champion, Peter Thomson, increased his lead to six strokes today by firing his second straight 69 in the Australian open golf championship.

THE Greater New York Bridge Association, which controls the tournament activities of nearly 8,000 bridge players in New York and Long Island, held its annual elections during the Metropolitan Championships last weekend.

HOUSTON, Oct. 26 California's Gov. Ronald Reagan pursued a speech-making tour through three stops in Kansas and Texas today, denying that he had any designs on the White House though he was introduced to one audience as "a man who may become President of the United States."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) Staff members of the Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania were warned today to stop advocating civil disobedience or face possible dismissal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) President Johnson welcomed President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz of Mexico to the White House today and declared that "our relations today are closer than they have ever been in the history of our two republics."

NEWARK, Oct. 26 For two days last week, a 16-year-old high school junior passed himself off as a substitute teacher in another high school here.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP) Dean Prentice scored his fourth and fifth goals of the National Hockey League season tonight and assisted on two others to lead the Detroit Red Wings to an easy 8-2 romp over the California Seals.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Oct. 26 More than 100 New York State church leaders representing nine Protestant denominations and two Roman Catholic dioceses began a long-range campaign today to put religion more realistically into the fight against racial discrimination and poverty.
James Thurber's "The Wonderful O," which has heretofore defied conversion to the musical stage, will emerge Feb. 13 in a song-and-dance version for wooden actors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) President Johnson welcomed President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz of Mexico to the White House today and declared that "our relations today are closer than they have ever been in the history of our two republics."

BRUSSELS--The United States and Western Europe are divided over the best way to increase the economic strength of the underdeveloped world.

RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 27-- Morocco today signed accords for $34-million worth of United States economic assistance after the Moroccan Foreign Minister had called in the American Ambassador to chide Washington for its attitude on Israel.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27-- Jerry Quarry hasn't shaved since Sunday. His stubble of brown beard is flecked with red.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 27--The General Assembly's trusteeship committee called on Britain today to use any force necessary to overthrow the white minority Government in Rhodesia.
A Greenwich Village hatcheck girl was charged yesterday in Federal Court with selling LSD and mailing the drug to a Yale student.
Directors of Hiram WalkerGooderham Worts, Ltd., announced yesterday in Walkerville, Ont., the election of Charles T. Fisher 3d to the company's board.

CONCORD, N.H.--Oct. 27 --A private poll of voters in Strafford County, New Hampshire's bellwether county, indicates that only Richard M. Nixon among five Republican possibilities could carry the state against President Johnson. The margin was a single percentage point.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27--A stone and bronze memorial to Theodore Roosevelt was unveiled today on a wild little island in mid-Potomac. The brisk, shining day and the woodsy setting were exactly what any outdoorsman would have ordered.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 27-- Jack Nicklaus was at his best today with a 62, the lowest competitive round he has ever put together, and the Columbus, Ohio, golfer smashed through to the 54-hole lead in the Sahara tournament.

The election of Greorge E. Reedy as president of the Struthers Scientific and International Corporation, an 81-per-cent owned subsidiary of the Struthers Wells Corporation, was announced yes terday. Mr. Reedy succeeds John W. Pike, who was elected vice chairman of the board of directors.
ROME, Oct. 27--Pope Paul VI and Ecumenical Patriarch Athenagoras I spent an hour together today. They were reported to have explored paths to reunion of the Roman Catholic and Orthodox churches.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 27 (AP)--A three-judge Federal Court ruled today that Mississippi may raise its qualifications for political candidates without discriminating against Negroes in violation of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
Operations of the Greyhound Corporation in the third quarter this year resulted in a net income of $18,655,026, equal to 59 cents a common share, the report disclosed yesterday.
ROME, Oct. 27--Pope Paul VI will undergo surgery for the removal of his prostate gland early next month, informed sources said today.
ALBANY, Oct. 27--The State Education Department will request at least $121,453,518 in additional budget funds next year to meet mandated expenses.
TRIPOLI, Libya, Oct. 27 (Reuters)--Libya has a new cabinet today following the resignation on Wednesday of Premier Abdul Kader al-Bedri for health reasons.
A young woman was assaulted yesterday afternoon in the same Pratt Institute graduate students' dormitory where one co-ed was raped and another robbed Thursday night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27--The staff of the Office of Economic opportunity has been ordered to make no more grants, contracts or purchases until Con gress renews the poverty program's spending authority.

ROME, Oct. 27--The Synod of Bishops was reported today to have approved, by an unannounced majority, proposals for clarifying Roman Catholic doctrine through a commission of theologians and a "positive and pastoral" declaration by Pope Paul VI.

The 1,120-seat ANTA Washington Square Theater, 40 West Fourth Street, where "Man of La Mancha" has been running since it opened in November, 1965, is expected to be either dismantled or demolished this winter. The show will be transferred to Broadway, according to a spokesman for the production.
MONTREAL, Oct. 27--The danger of over-praising the Stratford Festival Company of Canada is not inconsiderable. Indeed it is rather understandable.

Debussy's "Children's Corner," a work heard infrequently here, was played with sensitivity and finesse last night by Suzanne Shader in her piano recital at Carnegie Recital Hall. Each member of the St. Louis Cardinals' winning squad will receive $8,314,81 and each Boston Red Sox player as $5,115.23 from the World Series, Commissioner William D. Eckert announced yesterday. They were the smallest shares in recent years.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 31 Allied forces today repulsed the second major attack in 48 hours by Vietcong troops on a town 70 miles north of Saigon. The enemy was believed to be seeking a propaganda victory to counter South Vietnam's presidential inauguration.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 30 Moslems celebrated their holy day Lailat al-Isra today with Jerusalem, the central place of the day's tradition, in what Arabs regard as "enemy hands."

ATHENS, Oct. 30 A special Athens court-martial sentenced six persons to prison tonight in what it said was an attempt by Syria to spy on military installations of Greece and of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 30 (Reuters) Following are excerpts from the speech by Premier Levi Eshkol in the Knesset today:
PARIS, Oct. 30 French negotiatians to develop a nationalized oil field in Iraq have become another source of contention between France and the United States.

"WHEN in doubt punt" is a football axiom of long standing that Tom Cahill, the Army coach, followed by ordering a punt on fourthand-one situation from the cadet's 36-yard line with 4 minutes 15 seconds to go and Army trailing Stanford by 3 points last Saturday. For the ...

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 31--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, South Vietnam's chief of state during two years of military rule, took the oath of office today as the first President of South Vietnam's Second Republic.

If there is one thing about Vietnam on which the Administration and its critics generally agree, it is that a satisfactory political resolution of the conflict is ultimately a job for the Vietnamese themselves. Today's inauguration of General Thieu and Marshal Ky as South Vietnam's President and Vice President ushers in a crucial and perhaps final opportunity for movement in that direction.

June 16, 1904 has come to be known as Bloomsday, so pervasive has been James Joyce's monumental novel, "Ulysses," and his 20th century, Ulysses, the fictional Leopold Bloom, whose Odyssey the day encompasses. And now, with Joyce bustin' out all over, 1967 is well on the way to establishing itself as Joyceyear.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) Farm product prices declined one-third of one per cent during the month ended Oct. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.

INCREASINGLY concerned over multimillion-dollar lawsuits against some of its most important members, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants is making an effort to limit the liability of accountants to their clients.
LENINGRAD, Oct. 25 The Little Opera House on Arts Square is a delicate theater in the Russian classical style of the last century.

ROME, Oct. 30--Maurice Cardinal Roy, Archbishop of Quebec and president of the Vatican's Commission for Justice and Peace, said at a news conference today that the commission would hold a joint session with a similar organization of the World Council of Churches next April 22-28, probably in one of the developing countries.

Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, member of the New York Stock Exchange, announced the appointment as general partners of Van Dyke Burhans Jr., Joseph W. Teeboom, Paul Tobin and George Washburn. The four men are based here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) The cost of sending a telegram by Western Union will go up 3 per cent Wednesday, the Federal Communications Commission said today.
Dark Star, who won the 1953 Kentucky Derby, in which he handed Native Dancer his only defeat, will be sent to Normandy, France, shortly to be place in stud.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin firmly reiterated today the Soviet Union's absolute support for the terms posed by North Vietnam and the Vietcong as preconditions for peace talks.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 30 At the opening session of the 58th annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers here today, the Advertising Council previewed its newest campaign a drive aimed at attracting today's socially oriented student into the business world.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 30 (Reuters) Three United States stars reached the men's singles quarter-finals in the South American tennis championships today.
TOWSON, Md., Oct. 30 Maryland dropped all charges today against two Negro brothers who were once within three weeks of execution in the gas chamber for allegedly raping a white girl.
PARIS, OCT. 30 (Reuters) Marvel Cerdan Jr., the 23-yearold son of the former world middleweight champion, outpointed Ted Whitfield, an American, tonight in a 10-round welterweight match.
A significant break appeared yesterday in the united front savings banks and savings and loan associations have been presenting to Congress in pressing for a new type of Federal savings institution.
The United States Steel Corporation announced plans yesterday to sell $225-million of 30-year debentures through a syndicate managed by Morgan Stanley Co.
A Long Island real estate man was found guilty in United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday of illegally building a bridge across a navigable waterway.
The first tangible, noisy symbol of the $150-million Madison Square Garden Center which once was regarded as Felt's Folly opened yesterday.

Copper futures went their "merry, merry way" yesterday, as one broker commented. All deliveries set new lifetime highs. The nearby contracts were up the daily limit of 2 cents a pound and closed at that level. Trading was the most active in a long time for copper, with 614 contracts changing hands.
Twice a week, Class 1-X flexes its muscles, grunts, groans and gyrates, all on the trail of better theater.
COLOGNE, Germany, Oct. 31 (AP) Two former SS officers were sentenced today for wartime crimes in the Mauthausen concentration camp and several smaller camps.
HONG KONG, Oct. 30 A border incident and a series of bomb investigations ended today the lull in Communist agitation against the Hong Kong Government.
The election of Donald S. Thompson as a vice president of the Continental Can Company was announced here yesterday.
MAJURO, Marshall Islands Many of the natives of Eniwetok and Bikini, evacuated from their homes for the United States atomic tests two decades ago, are now going hungry for weeks at a time.
Dr. Waclaw Lednicki, a leading scholar in Slavic literature, who was widely known as an interpreter of Slavic culture, died Sunday in Berkeley, Calif., where he lived. His age was 76.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The House, riding a wave of protectionist sentiment in Congress, overrode Administration objections today and voted to cut off cotton imports from the United Arab Republic.
Mrs. Phoebe Cary Brisbane widow of Arthur Brisbane, the newspaperman, died Sunday in Beacon (N.Y.) Hospital, after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived at 340 East 72d Street.

Protectionist legislation now before the Congress would "undo" four years of hard negotiations for lower tariffs and reverse in large part 30 years of success in the nation's foreign trade policy, Under Secretary of State Nicholas deB. Katzenbach warned here yesterday.

The New York Civil Liberties Union and two other groups accused the Citizens for Educational Freedom yesterday of waging "a false and scurrilous campaign which is purposefully misleading" in support of the proposed state constitution.
Prices spurted on the London Stock Exchange yesterday under the impetus of strong buying from institutional investors and the general public.

Two men were arrested on charges of assaulting Federal marshals yesterday, shortly after they had been ordered from a Brooklyn courtroom for expressing boisterous support of a defendant accused of refusing to report for induction into the armed forces.
Business leaders last night attended a special showcase performance by units of the City Center of Music and Drama at the New York State Theater.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad have elected Carlos J. Routh to the board to succeed Wayne M. Hoffman, who has resigned to become chairman of Flying Tiger Lines, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 The Administration came out today for a more stringent meat inspection bill than the controversial measure that the House will debate tomorrow.

MIAMI, Oct. 30 (AP) Felipe Rivero, the anti-Castro leader ordered banished from the United State for heading an exile group advocating violence, was released from jail today on $10,000 bail and the condition he behave himself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 It was Halloween, time to pay the annual call upon Dr. Frankelstein, the neighborhood's mad scientist. All summer long he had been hoisting large objects onto his roof during thunderstorms, and rumor had it that he was quite daft on the notion that a good jolt of lightning would create life in the United States Congress.

A special committee of Columbia University trustees appointed last year at the start of a drive to raise $200-million for expansion of the university has found Columbia "wellequipped" to meet future challenges and opportunities.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Cincinnati Publishers Association announced tonight that a photoengravers' strike would prevent publishing tomorrow's editions of The Enquirer, leaving the city without any newspapers.

James M. Roche was elected yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of the General Motors Corporation, while Edward N. Cole was named to succeed Mr. Roche as president of the company, .which is the world's largest manufacturing organization.
A writer for women's magazines said yesterday that she had acted as a spy for an organization advocating approval of the proposed state constitution.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 30 (UPI) The Chicago White Sox, who failed to reach a million attendance, will play nine regular-season games and one pre-season exhibition in baseball-starved Milwaukee next summer, under tentative plans announced today.

Two of the key roles in "Le Nozze di Figaro" were being filled last night by experienced artists relatively new to the Metropolitan Opera's production, but the total performance did not suffer seriously for that.

Because of an astonishing defect in law, the Federal Government has no authority to regulate hold ing companies that control savings and loan associations. For more than three years the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has sought legislation requiring these holding companies to register, file reports and open their books for Federal inspection.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP) Unbeaten Gypsy Joe Harris scored a unanimous decision over Irish Bobby Cassidy of New York tonight for his 22d victory in a 10-round boxing match at the Philadelphia Arena.
Volume of trading on the American Stock Exchange, after setting one-day and one-week record last week, was throttled back to a more normal 5,475,410 shares yesterday.

Uta Hagen, Broadway actress, who teaches acting to six classes with 25 pupils in each at the Herbert Berghof Studio, has been chosen by the A. P .A.-Phoenix repertory troupe to play the leading role of Madame Ranevsky in "The Cherry Orchard."

EL BADRASHEIN, the United Arab Republic, Oct. 30 Ignoring the tumble-down Sakkara pyramid, which loomed serenely on the horizon behind him, Hassan Mohammed Kotb made a savage tearing gesture at his sinewy throat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 A panel of three Federal judges ruled against the Justice Department today in its fight to break up the four-year-old merger of the Crocker-Anglo National Bank and the Citizens National Bank of Los Angeles.
Dr. Randolph A. Wyman, who retires today after 13 years as administrator of Bellevue Hospital, said yesterday his job "was a crisis from the word go."

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Oct. 30 (AP) Jack Nicklaus's victory in the Sahara open golf tournament Saturday has moved him to the top in professional earnings with six victories in 22 tournaments, figures showed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 A trustee of "Americans Building Constitutionally," an organization accused by Congressional investigators of operating a school for tax dodgers, refused today to produce financial and membership records subpoenaed by a House subcommittee.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 Gloom hung over the University of Southern California today. O.J. Simpson the Trojans' and the nation's top rusher, could be lost for the rest of the football season.

THE program called "N. B. T. Journal," which has quietly gone about its reportorial business without either disparaging commercial network efforts or proclaiming itself the ultimate renaissance in electronic journalism, presented last night a calm and sober appraisal of Fidel Castro's revolution in Cuba.
ALBANY, Oct. 30 The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 1,664 of 2,223 applicants had passed the written examination for admission to the bar at the examination held July 13 and 14.

The Sport Page Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday gave the 26,681 fans more than they had anticipated, a stakes record-breaking performance and two winners. Roger W. Wilson's 6-year-old R. Thomas and the Gedney Farms' Sun Gala finished the six-furlong sprint together, in 1:09 3-5, to share the honors in the 15th running of the $28,000 stakes.
Leaders of the Democratic City Council and the Republican Lindsay administration accused each other yesterday of failing to "communicate" on legislative matters.
ROME, Oct. 30 Pope Paul VI was recovering today from a recurrence of fever and beginning a period of rest to prepare him for later surgery, it was announced by the Vatican today.

MENTION Texas and for years what sprang to an outsider's mind was gushing oil and herds of cattle. Then came Neiman-Marcus as another symbol of the Lone Star State's extravagance and for many an Easterner the famed Dallas store began to take on an aura of both dream and legend.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 31 (Reuters) Indonesian diplomats returned from Peking today aboard a plane sent to evacuate the Chinese Embassy staff in Jakarta.
Morton Gould was awarded the Henry Hadley Medal of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors last night at the association's 35th annual awards dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today urged construction of a $70.4-million communications cable to southern Europe by the end of 1970.
Two Soviet Cosmos satellites achieved the first unmanned docking in space yesterday. It was the first docking of any kind for the Soviet Union. [Page 1, Column 8.]
To paraphrase Lincoln, you can please some of the palates all of the time, all of the palates some of the time, but you can't please all of the palates all of the time.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) The Sierra Club parted company today with other national conservation organizations by advocating the land-trade provision of a pending Redwood National Park bill.

CAIRO, Tuesday, Oct. 31 (Reuters) The comander of the Egyptian Air Force during the Arab-Israeli war in June went on trial before a military court yesterday, charged with responsibility for Egyptian military setbacks in the fighting.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30 Mr. and Mrs. William Evan Read have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ellen Read, to William Durfor English Jr., son of Mr. English of Beverly Farms, Mass., and the late Mrs. English, who was the former Judith Kelly.

The engagement of Miss Leah Anne Hammer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gottlieb Hammer of New York and Mahopac, N.Y., to Robert Lewis Rubenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Rubenstein of Perth Amboy, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents.

DALLAS, Oct. 30 (AP) Mrs. Marina N. Oswald Porter, the widow of the man the Warren Commission named as President Kennedy's assassin, has sued the United States Government for $500,000 as compensation for the Government's seizure of Lee Harvey Oswald's personal effects.
MADRID, Oct. 30 A constitutional conference opened tonight to determine the future of Equatorial Guinea, which Spain has ruled for 189 years.

Three ship models that were on display for the last six months in Expo 67's "Little Sea" at the Canadian Pavilion at Montreal will be turned over to the new National Museum of Science and Technology, which is scheduled to open in Ottawa later this year.

Arthur Thompson is a young baritone who has sung with the Juilliard Opera Theater, the Metropolitan Opera Studio and similar groups. Last night in Carnegie Recital Hall he made his New York recital debut on the Young Concert Artists Series, singing a program that had been chosen with a great deal of discrimination.

The Television Bureau of Advertising charged yesterday that a plan by the Public Broadcast Laboratory to challenge the credibility of TV advertisements was a "flagrant violation" of the fairness doctrine.

DETROIT, Oct. 30 (AP) With the Ford Motor Company still on the sidelines awaiting resolution of crippling local issues in its strike settlement, automobile production in the United States during the past week was nearly 2,500 cars off the pace of a week before.
Peter D. Sternlight, Deputy Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, has left his post to return to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
GORTON, England, Oct. 30 The freckle-faced young man darted down a rainswept street, jumped a hedge and stuck a hand out to the stout lady he had seen in a doorway.

The index measuring helpwanted advertising rose in September for the second consecutive month, reaching 185 per cent of the 1957-1959 average, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 30 Nobel science prizes were awarded here today to an American nuclear physicist who explained how stars produce energy and to three Europeans who investigated extremely fast chemical reactions.
Twenty-two city welfare workers, many of them young college graduates and one of them a recent seminary dropout, have quit or been suspended as a result of a kickback investigation.

Operations of the Borden Company in the third quarter resulted in sales and earnings almost equal to the record a year ago. Results for the nine months were the highest in the company's history; Francis R. Elliott, chairman, reported yesterday.

TEANECK, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The Jersey Americans might just have been sneaking a peek at the New York Knickerbockers recently. The new American Basketball Association team blew a substantial lead and ended up losing to the Kentucky Colonels, 107-104, tonight at the Teaneck Armory.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 31 --Seventy-four students at Harvard College were placed on probation today for taking part in the "forcible obstruction" of a job recruiter last week.
City officials and the Port of New York. Authority are studying the feasibility of building two runways on landfill in Jamaica Bay to allow more planes to use Kennedy International Airport.

OF all the great playwrights, Eugene O'Neill is the most banal. Even in his best plays he is likely to drop through into booby traps of cliche, and in his worst plays, melodrama, like poverty, is always with us.
The Pacific Coast Stock Exchange announced yesterday the first sale of a seat by a securities exchange in this country to a European brokerage house.

Stockholders in Pay Less Drug Stores Northwest, Inc., sold 500,000 shares of common stock at $18 a share yesterday and the offering was oversubscribed. The first public offer ing of the West Coast drug chain was managed by underwriters led by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc. Late in the day, the shares were quoted at 18-18 .
DETROIT, Oct. 31--The Ford Motor Company recalled 745,000 of its 1967 and 1966 cars today for inspection of possible safety defects in the steering wheels.

ALBANY, Oct. 31-The Port of New York Authority will have to pay at least $30-million instead of $3.5-million for the Hudson River tunnels and equipment acquired from the old Hudson Manhattan Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- The United States has informed the International Red Cross that if necessary it will contribute aircraft to help evacuate an estimated total of 130 white mercenaries and 1,000 Katangese allied with them from the eastern Congo.

"It's not just the rich matron who is making a day of it in the New York stores," a local merchant said jubilantly yesterday. "Now it's the housewife who is coming into the city for a morning shopping tour," he explained, "for lunch, afternoon at a show or a museum, maybe a late date at the masseuse, and then a night on the town with her husband."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The trend of the young militants in American politics is now clearly moving from peaceful dissent to physical resistance. The large majority of protesting university students may still be satisfied with legal demonstrations, but the minority militants are not, and increasingly the minority is trying to substitute violent defiance for the majority's peaceful disobedience.

A price increase in all copper and copper-alloy mill products except free-cutting brass rod was announced, yesterday by the Bridgeport Brass Company division of the National Distillers, and Chemical Corporation.

CHERRY HILL, N. J. Oct. 31 (AP)--The Gardenia Trial, a one-mile and 70-yard warmup for the Nov. 11 renewal of the $75,000 added Gardenia for 2-year-old fillies, will be run in two sections tomorrow at Garden State Park.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday he would ask the New York Young Republican Club to drop its plans for a nationwide movement to draft him for President. But club officials said they would push ahead with the national effort anyway.

LONDON, Oct. 31--Ministers of the European Common Market took steps at a meeting today that eventually will lead to intensified cooperation by its six members in certain fields of advanced technology.

"I didn't realize she'd developed as much of a range as this," said David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York, last evening as his eye swept the paintings, collages and assemblages that adorned the walls of the Selected Artists Gallery at 903 Madison Avenue. "I'n fact, I'd say that her work is quite acceptable."
Representative John M. Murphy of Richmond was shouted down by "dump Johnson" Democrats last night when he declared that antiwar demonstrations at home were protracting the war in Vietnam.
AN expeditionary force from the House of Givenchy planted its flag in the hallroom of the Plaza Hotel Monday night.
BERLIN, Oct. 31--Thousands attended services today in the East German city of Wittenberg marking the 450th anniversary of the Protestant Reformation.

Tulsa's football team continues to lead major colleges in total offense and passing offense, but the Hurricanes' lead in both is very slim, according to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's weekly statistics issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- President Johnson met tonight at the White House with Democratic Congressional leaders and told them he wanted action on 20 bills in his legislative program before adjournment of the first session of the 90th Congress.

DETROIT, Oct. 31-The Ford Motor Company reported today a strike-caused loss of $73.9million in its third-quarter-the first loss for Ford in any three months since the third-quarter of 1958, a recession year.

MANY early-to-bed citizens turn off their television sets after the late news roundup, shunning Johnny Carson, Joey Bishop and other heroes of insomniacs. But these devotees of slumber found themselves trapped the night before last by a football game that was a scriptwriter's dream. It overflowed with those irresistible TV ingredients of drama, violence and suspense. And it kept them up until almost 1 A. M.

ORANGE, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Firefighters rimmed 125,000 scorched acres in six Southern California counties today, fighting flareups and trying to assess damage from brush blazes believed to be responsible for three deaths and $2-million in damage.
IN the glow of fires lit under the Go-Go funds of late, an advocate of bold, aggressive trading stepped before the microphones yesterday to argue that performance investing is here to stay.
LONDON, Oct. 31--Foreign Secretary George Brown made an unusual attack tonight on Lord Thomson of Fleet, newspaper publisher, at a Savoy Hotel dinner attended by American businessmen.

Students arrested at Brooklyn College during the Oct. 19 demonstration against Navy recruiters will be prosecuted for disorderly conduct and resisting or interfering with the police, District Attorney Aaron E. Koota announced yesterday.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino reported yesterday that the city's budget for the year ended June 30 was balanced at a level just below $4.5billion.

MRS. JOSEPH P. KENNEDY spoke articulately and warmly of the early family life of the late President Kennedy in a half-hour conversation last night with Harry Reasoner on the Columbia Broadcasting System. She easily belied her 70-odd years with her precision of memory.
The 13-day-old Brooklyn waterfront strike yesterday threatened to keep millions of dollars worth of merchandise out of the Christmas market and ruin perishable cargo.

HAMILTON, Scotland, Oct. 31--With her red widebrimmed hat flapping around her ears, Mrs. Winifred Ewing walked through the mud of the brickworks here today, past the kiln and up the steps where the laborers were opening their lunch bags.

"Dollinger's odds-on to win, but I could just back into this thing without half trying," said State Senator John D. Calandra yesterday about his chances of deposing Bronx District Attorney Isidore Dollinger in next Tuesday's election.

Two young members of the United States Equestrian Team, 22-year-old Neal Shapiro, and Mrs. Mary Chapot, 23, were best with their mounts in the international jumping at the opening of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday. They each won trophies for this country.
As New Yorkers button up and brace for winter, 30 Adelie penguins in the Bronx are busily building their nests in anticipation of summer.

The proposed new constitution is a much shorter and clearer document than the one now in force. It is less than half the length of the existing Constitution, which has been amended 162 times since its adoption in 1894. The new draft is also better organized, in fifteen articles instead of the present twenty. These are all positive gains.
The city announced plans yesterday for a $110-million plant to make the first combined attack on the waste and pollution that is now dumped on the city's land and in its air and waters.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 -- Scoring on California time, but operating on New York time, the Rangers strafed a familiar foe, Terry Sawchuk, on unfamiliar ice tonight in a 6-1 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31--The Soviet Government decreed today a sweeping amnesty under which many thousands of persons in prison or labor camps will be released or have their remaining terms cut in half.
The American Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday operating revenues of $428,755,711 for the 12 months ended Sept. 30. This compared with $392,512,041 in the like 1966 period.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Lamar Hunt, owner of the Kansas City Chiefs in the American Football League, has offered to pay more than $52million for a 99-year lease on the proposed twin-stadium Jackson County sports complex.
ROME, Oct. 31--Pope Paul VI called today for an end of violence and racism in Africa and for development there through a world fund instead of by individual "neocolonialist" benefactors.

EBEYE, Marshall Islands-- American antimissile exercise forces in the Marshall Islands have brought with them the squalor of big-city slums, as well as modern electronic luxuries, to the Micronesian residents of this overcrowded island in the strategic, closely guarded Kwajalein atoll.
