SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 31 -The engagement of Miss Karen Huntington Kuhl to Frederick Lindsley Trowbridge has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wolfe Kuhl. Mr. Trowbridge is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Lum Trowbridge of Houston.

In view of the persistent Arab hostility to which Israel has been subjected for the past twenty years and the continuing refusal of the Arabs to move toward recognition of Israel and her right of existence, the tough terms for a Middle East settlement spelled out by Israeli Premier Levi Eshkol in the Knesset are understandable.

ALBANY, Oct. 31--The State Court of Appeals today affirmed the felony murder conviction of a man whose first conviction for the same murder led to a revision of the state's trial treatment of confessions.

YONKERS, Oct. 31 (UPI)-- Walters Gail beat Free Service by three-quarters of a length to win the $60,000 New York Sire Stakes for 2-year-old filly trotters at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The time for the mile was 2:12 1/5.

At the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition held last year, a special award for "Romantic Playing" was given to Blanca Uribe, a performer from Colombia. Last night, at the Hunter College Playhouse, Miss Uribe was presented in her New York debut recital by the Center for Inter-American Relations, and she proved that she does, indeed, have a talent for interpreting music by Romantic composers.

SHORTLY after 10:30 yesterday morning, everybody under 8 years of age in a room on Gimbels' sixth floor was in violent diagonal or horizontal motion and emitting noises that would have made an Indian raid sound like a Trappist prayer meeting.

The season's first two major auctions of paintings, drawings and sculpture at the ParkeBernet Galleries have emphasized at least three recent trends in the art market-the increasing sophistication of collectors, the continuing emergence of wealthy collectors previously unknown to the most experienced auctioneers and dealers and the price rise in American art from the late 19th century to the nineteenforties.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31--American artillerymen fired point blank into charging Vietcong regulars attempting to seize the airfield and town of Locninh 72 miles north of Saigon today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31 (UPI)-Clark Graebner, a Davis Cup player, and Cliff Richey and Marty Riessen, American teammates, scored impressive victories today in the 20th South American international tennis championships.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30-- A witness gave Congressional investigators some tantalizing tips today on how to avoid taxes by operating a business or profession through a personal foundation.

Officially, sponsored British trade missions to the United States have been increasing in frequency and in size over the last few years. There were 13 in 1965, but their number reached 67 this year. The latest group now ready to go back home, is also the largest, with 26 members, including three women.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 --Files on militant organizations, seized in a Kentucky raid that a Federal court later termed unconstitutional, have been turned over to Senate investigators looking into alleged radical incitement of last summer's urban riots.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 31Robert Browning Sosman, a physicist and chemist who was a pioneer in American ceramics and professor of ceramics at Rutgers University from 1947 to 1962, died yesterday in Muhlenberg Hospital.

In an otherwise gray day for commodity futures, the only brightness came in the continued heavy activity in three basic metals--copper, silver and platinum. All showed higher prices at the end of their busy sessions.

NEW HAVEN. Oct. 31 Last Saturday, Dartmouth defeated Harvard, the team that was rated as its most dangerous rival for the Ivy League championship, and Yale played one of its finest football games in years to annihilate a Cornell eleven that had crushed Princeton. The coaches of the two victors now look ahead to their clash here Saturday with trepidation.
TORONTO, Oct. 31-Pickets marched in Montreal again today in front of the Montreal City and District Savings Bank in an attempt to force it to bargain collectively with its employes.
MADRID, Oct. 31--A Soviet naval training ship was in Barcelona today on the first such visit to a Spanish port in 32 years.
Southern California, receiving every first-place vote in one major poll and 33 of 35 in the other, kept the top spot in the weekly national ranking of college football teams issued yesterday.
A crowd of about 300 Negro youths stoned passing cars and threw debris and rocks at police cars in Queens last night in what the police described as a Halloween celebration that got out of hand.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31--Forecasts of high interest rates up to 1975 with less extreme fluctuation than in the recent past as well as higher interest rates in the immediate future were made here today.

WEST TISBURY, Mass., Oct. 31-Mrs. Tom Revere of Seven Gates Farm and Guanajuato, Mexico, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lee Revere, to Henry Washington Hotchkiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hotchkiss of Nannauwiyack Farm.
The president of a union that organized small retail meat markets was indicted and arrested yesterday in connection with an investigation of racketeering in the meat industry.
CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 31-- A court test of Gov. George Romney's legal eligibility to serve as President of the United States is expected early in the 1968 New Hampshire Republican primary campaign.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 31 (AP)--Buyers paid $982,000 for 244 trotters and pacers today during the second day of the 29th annual standardbred sale at the State Farm Show Arena. Although not a second-day record, the average price of $4,025 was strong and above the $3,670 average of 1966.

The narcotics conviction of a 37-year-old defendant was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals because the trial judge allowed the jury to see incriminating writings not received in evidence.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 31 --Gov. Ronald Reagan denied today a published report by Drew Pearson that a homosexual ring had been uncovered in his administration.
The Giants, who play the Minnesota Vikings on Sunday in Bloomington, Minn., are in the unusual situation of not knowing which quarterback they will face, or for how long.

THERE are some lapses in "The Silver Button" at the Martinique Theater, some of them attributable to the rather undashing actor playing the dashing Scottish rebel, Alan Breck. But this musical version of Stevenson's "Kidnapped," substantially revised from last season, has much to recommend it.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 31 (AP)-- The terms agreed upon by five of the six Euratom countries for inspection provisions of a treaty to bar the spread of nuclear weapons were made public today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 1--Vietcong mortarmen lobbed three shells onto the lawns of Independence Palace in downtown Saigon last night at the height of a gala reception for 2,000 guests including Vice President Humphrey.
OTTAWA, Oct. 31 (Canadian Press)-Adam Hartley Zimmerman, who retired in March as chairman of the Defense Research Board, died yesterday at the age of 65.

LAST Sunday while the New York Giants were playing the Cleveland Browns, Barry Hugh, Gottehrer, who has written a history of the football Giants, longed to be at Yankee Stadium but wasn't. Instead he was by choice at a monthly meeting in Harlem of a group of militant

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 31. Before the start of the Canadian -- American Challenge Cup series at Elkhart Lake, Wis., on Sept. 3, Bruce McLaren of New Zealand remarked, " I reckon that any marked, "I reckon that any driver lucky enough to score a sweep of the six races could net around $150,000 in prize money"
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee manuevered today to force a reluctant Secretary of State into an open confrontation on the Administration's Vietnam policy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- Julius Rudel, general director of the New York City Opera Company, has been offered the post of artistic director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.
It was a good morning and a bad afternoon for prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31The concert that took place in the Academy of Music here tonight was more than an artistic event, and less, just as Boris Pasternak's "Doctor Zhivago" and Svetlana Alliluyeva's memoirs were extraliterary, and for the same reasons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -The scheduled airlines and their pilots opposed today plans of the Federal Aviation Administration to set a 288-mile-anhour speed limit for all planes operating below 10,000 feet.
LONDON, Oct. 31--The peers of Britain gathered in the House of Lords today and heard Queen Elizabeth II announce that they would soon lose their ancient legislative power.

Shares moved steadily upwards yesterday on the London Stock Exchange to close at a record high. Broadly based speculative and institutional demand, combined with a short supply of quality stocks, pushed up prices. Traders were influenced by good earnings reports and were apparently unconcerned about the continuing strike on the London docks.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 31--Vice President Humphrey offered some political advice but otherwise dealt gently with the newly inaugurated leaders of the South Vietnamese Government in meetings here today, American officials reported.

American Airlines announced yesterday that it would create an 80-acre university-style campus adjacent to the new airport that is under construction between Dallas and Fort Worth to become "the largest airline personnel training center in the world."

SOUSSE, Tunisia, Oct. 31Bobby Fisher of New York regained first place in the Interzonal Qualifying Tournament here last night after completion of the 11th round by drawing with the former Soviet champion, Viktor Korchnoi, in their eighth-round postponed game. Fischer has amassed 7 points out of a possible 10.

The New York Times unit of the Newspaper Guild announced yesterday the highlights of its new agreement with The Times. The contract raises the top minimum pay for reporters, photographers and advertising salesmen to $250 a week.

ACCRA, Ghana-That brilliant African, St. Augustine, defined time as a threefold present: the present as experienced now, the past as present memory, and the future as present expectation. Measured by each standard, black Africa is tragic.

The Metropolitan Museum's 7-foot marble Perseus, a neoclassic sculpture by Antonio Canova installed under the dome of the Grand Hall last month, was replaced yesterday by a second major sculpture acquisition, a marble Andromeda carved by PierreEtienne Monnot, the French baroque master, between 1699 and 1704.

Dr. Samuel Streicher, who retired last September as a member of the Board of Examiners of the city school system, died of a heart attack Monday in his home, 63-33 98th Place, Rego Park, Queens. His age was 66.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 31 (AP)-- The new owners of Tobin Bronze will gamble $35,000 to charter a special plane to fly the 4year-old from Australia to the Washington, D.C. International on Nov. 11.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 31 (UPI)--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. sent word from his jail cell today that he was confined to bed with a virus infection and under the care of a doctor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- Overriding objections from the White House, a House Appropriations subcommittee wrote new restrictions on the sale of sophisticated weapons to underdeveloped countries into a $2.2-billion foreign aid money bill today.
A tolerance of student demonstrations and an understanding of college life were urged yesterday by Dr. Martha E. Peterson, who becomes president of Barnard College today.

A rise in costs and a slump in shipments cut third-quarter profits of the United States Steel Corporatiqn by 41 per cent from the level of the 1966 third quarter, Roger M. Blough, chairman and chief executive officer, told a news conference here yesterday.
There was all the excitement, fanfare and show of an opening night last evening as Madison Square Garden was taken over by horses and horse lovers.
The bond market yesterday was pretty thoroughly discouraged.

EAST GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 31-Mrs. Joseph David Boland 2d has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Katherine Boland of New York, to Robert William Devine Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Devine of Erie, Pa. The wedding will take place here on Dec. 2.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- The Senate was told today that a California timber company had agreed not to cut trees within the boundaries of a proposed redwood national park for another year.
New York City has leased 29,000 square feet in the new 16-story office building at 110 Church Street. The space will be occupied by the Housing and Development Administration.
IN the early nineteen-twenties, after three years of revolution, bloody civil war, intervention and expropriation of land and industry, Russia was a suffering land.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 31-- The New York Knickerbockers suffered their sixth straight defeat tonight as they lost to the San Francisco Warriors, 108103, before only 2,263 spectators in the Oakland Coliseum.

The controversy on Capitol Hill over the sale of army to underdeveloped countries has developed into a battle of wills that imperils final passage of the foreign-aid program for the current fiscal year.
The Norfolk Western Railway noticed a Federal court here today that it intends to appeal that court's decision of Oct. 19 approving the merger of the Pennsylvania and the New York Central Railroads.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--The House overwhelmingly passed today a controversial bill aimed at assuring that all meat will meet Federal standards of wholesomeness.
The Veterans of Foreign Wars has withdrawn from its traditional participation in the Veterans Day ceremonies at Arlington National Cemetery on Nov. 11.

The City Investing Company, which has undertaken an ambitious diversification program this year, is currently negotiating to acquire the Southern California Financial Corporation and the Z-D Manufacturing Company, both on the West Coast.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31--Cosmos 186, one of the two unmanned satellites that were joined in orbit yesterday, returned to earth in a soft landing today. The other, Cosmos 188, continued circling the earth.
One of these years, Lou De Fichy may be able to light up a $1 cigar and calmly announce, in the first-person vernacular of his new trade, "I'm riding Can't Lose in the Kentucky Derby."
The stock market was hard hit yesterday as many issues suffered losses ranging from one to five points in active trading.

LA PORTE, Ind., Oct. 31 (UPI)--Two suspects hunted for four days in the killings of two policemen in a bank robbery getaway were captured with two woman companions today in a lakeside cottage hideout.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--A constitutional law expert testified with "horror" today that Congress would have no choice but to call a constitutional convention if 34 states asked for one.

The Goldfield Corporation said yesterday that it would proceed with construction of extracting and milling facilities for the tantalite ore deposit of Chemalloy Minerals, Ltd., at Bernic Lake in Manitoba.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 31-- Suffolk County's eastern and western town supervisors differed sharply today over warnings that organized crime stands to gain from a proposed change in county police services.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31-After being dark for more than 20 years, the Auditorium Theater, which Frank Lloyd Wright called "the greatest room for music and opera in the worldbar none," came to life tonight with most of its ornamental glories and all of its acoustical wonders intact.

THE New York bridge scene lost one of its leading players last Saturday when Boris Raymond suffered a fatal heart attack while playing in a sectional tournament at Paramus, N. J. He was 50 years old and an engineer by profession.
Four of the nation's largest insurance companies will invest $15-million to $20-million in Central Harlem housing for low-income families in the next two years, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

TRENTON, Oct. 31--United States Senator Clifford P. Case split with New Jersey Republicans once again today when he deplored their use of the school integration issue in the legislative election campaign.

FORT WORTH, Oct. 31 -- Mrs. Grace Ward Lankford, a founder and twice chairman of the Van Cliburn Quadrennial International Piano Competition, died today at the age of 67. She had been ill since August.
A corporation controlled by Victor Muscat and his business associates is negotiating the sale of its 65 per cent interest in the Gateway National Bank of Chicago.

Clarion Concerts, entering its 11th season last night in Town Hall under the direction of its founder-conductor, Newell Jenkins, departed in two ways from its characteristic repertory. The program included two large standard works, and there wasn't an Italian work in the program, although Mr. Jenkins recently received the decoration of the Knight of the Order of Merit of the Italian Republic for his research in and performance of Italian music.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 31--Borba, one of Yugoslavia's principal newspapers, told its readers today that the United States Central Intelligence Agency was not responsible for the recent drop in the price of imported Scotch whisky.
MINEOLA,. L. I., Oct. 31County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson today proposed a $198.8-million Nassau budget for 1968 that calls for a tax reduction of 12 cents for each $100 of assessed valuation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-- With the ending of the month of October today the United States economy equaled the longest previous recession-free period of expansion in history.
Mike McCormick of the San Francisco Giants, a "retread" from the American League, was voted the Cy Young Award yesterday, as the outstanding pitcher of 1967 in the National League.
Pierre Fournier, cellist, gave his first New York recital in three years at Carnegie Hall last night, and he was his usual, elegant, imperturbable self.

DETROIT, Oct. 31--The United Automobile Workers Union threatened today to keep the General Motors Corporation from stockpiling cars by calling strikes at G.M. plants in which its members are asked to work overtime.
THE American Savoyards have had their ups and downs with Gilbert and Sullivan this season. Last night's "Pinafore," it is nice to report, was one of the ups.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 31Heavyweights from both the client and agency sides offered suggestions to one another here today on how to improve agency output. Happily, there appeared to be areas of agreement.
The Federal Communications Commission declined yesterday to order New York radio and television stations to provide free time for the arguments of groups against the proposed state constitution.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 31--North Vietnam appealed to governments around the world today to "stay the hand" of the United States, which it said had begun "continuous bombing of the capital city of Hanoi."

SCARBOROUGH--ON--HUD-- SON, N. Y., Oct. 31-Mike Higuera of Plandome, Mike Ballo of Woodway and Gene Borek of Pine Hollow each shot a 68 over the 6,328-yard, par-35, 35 -70 Sleepy Hollow Country (Club course today to lead the way in the qualifying round of the annual pro-pro championship of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association.

A privately financed, nonpartisan agency of experts in state government has been formed, and soon will begin sending teams of advisers to interested governors, Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay placed his summer task force, created to help prevent racial violence during the hot months, on a year around basis yesterday.
HONG KONG, Oct. 31--Communist China announced today the withdrawal of its big economic aid mission in Burma and brought its diplomatic staff home from Indonesia.
FOR his devastating allround performance against Cornell last Saturday, Brian Dowling, Yale's quarterback, was named the Ivy League back of the week yesterday.
The Administration's chief trade negotiator joined Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York yesterday in calling for an "emergency coalition" of business and labor to fight protectionism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31-A proposal by some staff lawyers that the Justice Department file an antitrust suit seeking the breakup of General Motors into several competing companies was rejected some months ago by top antitrust officials as inadequately prepared, it was learned today.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy urged last night that the United States shift its priority in South Vietnam from military action to action that will be of "lasting benefit" to the people there.
The American Broadcasting Company yesterday filed unfair labor charges with the National Labor Relations Board against the National Association of Broadcast Employes and Technicians.

Prices declined in relatively slow trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, as a brief early-afternoon rally quickly ran out of momentum However, a few issues in special situations moved against the trend and closed with substantial gains.
City College's Student Council voted 13 to 7 last night to "strongly censure" a predominantly Negro campus organization for allegedly practicing racial discrimination against a white student.

Saul Bernstein, a lawyer who was the last surviving graduate of City College's class of 1889, died Tuesday night in Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had undergone, surgery on Oct. 13. He was 97 years old and lived at 1050 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 President Johnson said today that antiwar demonstrators in the United States were not helping to bring peace in Vietnam closer.
Henry Knippenberg has been named a vice president of the Premier Industrial Corporation Cleveland.

CAIRO, Nov. 1 The United Arab Republic's chief spokesman said today that his Government would offer "resistance and, if it is necessary, a riposte" should Israel not relinquish Arab lands seized in the June war.

In an effort to provide quicker responses to complaints, the Department of Sanitation has established a Community Service Corps of special liaison officers for each of the city's 58 sanitation districts.
YAEL DAYAN writes like a streak. The theory that the more words you pile on a subject, the more profound must be the ideas you display, has no appeal to her at all.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 1 Premier Eshkol said today that he would be willing to travel to Amman, the capital of Jordan, to discuss peace terms with King Hussein.

SACRAMENTO, Nov. 1 Aides to former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama say the segregationist is encountering major difficulty in getting on the California ballot as a thirdparty candidate for President.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 The American Conservatory Theater opened its fall season as San Francisco's permanent professional repertory company last night with its first venture locally into Shakespeare.

At the very moment when a broad counterattack seemed to be making headway against the protectionist tide in Congress, the House has again gone off the track by voting to eliminate cotton imports from the United Arab Republic.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 1 Yugoslavia is marking the 50th anniversary celebrations of the Bokshevik Revolution with one hand dealing out carefully chosen praise for Soviet accomplishments but with the other hand clasped firmly on her ideological wallet.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP) Total sales at the 29th annual standardbred horse sale in the Farm Show Arena set a third-day record today of $1,442550.

AMONG the safest and most energetic staples of sports conversation has always been the Impossible Comparison: Could the Brown Bomber have whipped the Manassa Mauler? Would the Four Horsemen have trampled the Seven Blocks of Granite? Would the Yankee Clipper have had a chance batting against The Big Train? Happily, one could argue for hours without ever worrying about incontrovertible proof.
REDONDO BEACH, Calif., Nov. 1 (AP) Dr. Ludwig Roth, a pioneer in rocket engineering and space sciences, died here yesterday at the age of 58.

Forty-nine City College students were arrested yesterday as they sat in muddy ditches dug for the foundation of a building they say would encroach on one of the few open spaces on their crowded campus.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 1 "These tea bags are simply not good enough," sniffed an official of the tourist agency, commenting on the every-day British brand used in Bulgaria's state-run hotels and restaurants.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (UPI) One thousand New Jersey families will be picked next year to test a controversial approach to fighting poverty a guaranteed income it was announced today.
The musical comedy star Nancy Andrews will entertain at a champagne reception and dinner dance to be held on Sunday evening for the benefit of the Hebrew Arts School for Music and Dance.

American maritime unions and shipowners are increasingly irate at the way laws intended to give preference to American-flag ships in exporting Government-generated cargoes are working out in practice.
Some 19 million children are living in poverty and nearpoverty in this country, according to a report issued yesterday by the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York, a nonprofit organization.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 1--Malta's representative warned the United Nations today that continued indiscriminate dumping of radioactive waste into the ocean might prevent man from utilizing the incalculable food and mineral resources of the sea bottom.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee approved today a bill to prohibit discrimination against employment of any person because of age.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 (Reuters) Drew Pearson, the Washington columnist, challenged Gov. Ronald Reagan of California today to sue him over Mr. Pearson's report that a homosexual ring had been uncovered in the California administration.

Mr. and Mrs. Heinrick OrthPallavicini of 125 East 84th Street and Sheffield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Orth-Pallavicini, to James Earl Akers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Thomas Akers of Indianapolis.

The stock market took its worst beating in almost five months yesterday as prices declined sharply in active trad-' ing. The hardest-hit issues included many of the blue-chip and glamour stocks. Losses on the New York Stock Exchange. ranged from one to five points.

"This is one of those issues where there's no right position you just try to get hurt the least. No one makes any friends no matter which way he comes out on the constitution. The pure political instinct is to come out with a strong 'maybe.'"
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 (AP) The United States command "gave back" seven MIG jets to North Vietnam today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The Department of the Army announced today the cancellation of next year's national rifle and pistol matches at Camp Perry, Ohio, ostensibly on economy grounds.

NORTH AMERICA has more listed Life Masters than most countries have tournament players. The total is now 8,716, and it increases by some 1,300 each year. Some 80 of these are from the New York metropolitan area, which now has about 700 in this top category.

A Glasgow-born executive whose "import" into the United States did not adversely affect the balance of payments, was honored last night for his efforts toward a greater penetration of foreign markets with American goods.
Stock and bond prices dropped sharply yesterday amid further indications of declines in corporate profits, inflationary pressures and higher interest rates.

It is the fashion today among musicians to smile indulgently on the Mozart piano sonatas, or even actively despise them chiefly because they suffer so grieviously in comparison with the piano concertos. But whose music doesn't? There is still a great deal of substance in some of the sonatas, along with those flimsy ones, and few pianists are better qualified to show us the difference than Lili Kraus
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) President Johnson announced today that Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker was returning to Washington from his post at Saigon for consultations.
MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., Nov. 1 Striped bass still circle this resort island, but the fishermen-laden vehicles that churned over the brown dunes for a month have departed.
LONDON, Nov. 1 A report suggesting strong new antidiscrimination legislation for Britain was made public here today. It is likely to serve as the basis for proposals from the Government.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Nov. 1 The Rev. John E. Gersten berg, who was rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Merrick from 1924 to 1954, died today at the Nassau Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived here at 119A 15th Street.

FRANKLIN, N.H., Nov. 1 The politicians who appear to be taking Senator Robert F. Kennedy most seriously as a Presidential contender in next year's New Hampshire primary are the nervous Democratic supporters of President Johnson. Few others are.

Petrus and Ernestine Ramoboa, who until a few months ago were virtually penniless, arrived yesterday at Kennedy International Airport from their home in South Africa, somewhat bewildered but smiling broadly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) President Johnson welcomed King Mahendra of Nepal to Washington today and offered him "the hand of friendship and partnership as you continue your advance" in modernizing his nation, a Himalayan kingdom between India and China.

RUMSON, N. J., Nov. 1--Joseph C. Hoagland, retired real estate broker, died today at Roosevelt Hospital in New York City after a short illness. He was 78 years old and lived here at 104 West River Road.
ALBANY, Nov. 1(UPI) J. Burch McMorran, Commissioner of Transportation, has reported that the New York State canal system showed a slight gain in freight shipments for September.

A two-day sale of Rembrandt etchings from the collection formed by Gordon W. Nowell-Usticke ended yesterday, bringing $472,485 for 211 prints. The auction, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, disposed of the first part of the collection.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1(UPI) Ron Stewart scored two goals in the first period tonight and the St. Louis Blues went on to defeat the Boston Bruins, 5-1, in a National Hockey League game.

YONKERS, Nov. 1 A tiring colt usually will bear out or lug in. The frontgoing Roger Acclaim was tired in the closing stages of tonight's richest race in the seven-year history of the New York Sire stakes. The gross purse for 11 3-yearold trotting colts and geldings was $76,250.
The City Planning Commission approved a zoning change yesterday designed to stimulate the construction of new theaters in the Times Square area.
The taxicab industry said yesterday that it was facing an economic crisis and needed an immediate 15-cent-a-mile fare increase.
INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 1 (AP) The Indiana Pacers spotted the New Jersey Americans an early 3-point lead, then romped to a 123-113 victory tonight in an American Basketball Association game.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 A high official in the Federal Reserve System said today that recent increases in the growth of the money stock might be viewed by some economists as "really something wild."
Few things are more galling to a consumer than paying full price when a discount is available, whether it be for a new car, a television set or a slightly overripe melon. But

DARIEN, Conn., Nov. 1 Mrs. Florence Gunnison Brown, who as head of the Louise Wise Services, an adoption agency in New York City, had urged that childless white couples adopt nonwhite and multiracial children, died yesterday at her home, 7 Edgehill Drive. She was 75 years old.

OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Nov. 1 Sloan Danenhower, a former Navy commander who was the navigator and second in command of Sir Hubert Wilkins's submarine Nautilus on its 1931 Arctic expedition, died today at the Saybrook Convalescent Home. He was 82 years old.
TEANECK, N. J., Nov. 1--Trailing, 2-0, Long Island University's unbeaten soccer team rallied with three goals in the third period to down Fairleigh Dickinson University today on the loser's field.
Allison Danzig of The New York Times received the Grantland Rice Award yesterday at the annual Sportsmanship Brotherhood awards luncheon of the Touchdown Club of New York.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 1 Buoyed by a dedicated fiveminute penalty killing effort, led by Don Marshall, in the final period, the New York Rangers extended their non-losing streak to eight games tonight with a 2-0 victory over the California Seals.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 1 The independent economic experts of the European Economic Community expect the six member states to bound strongly out of their recession next year and "appreciably" increase their imports from countries like the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1(UPI) Lynda Bird Johnson took a leave of absence from her magazine writing job today to concentrate on her White House wedding plans.

EDISON, N.J., Nov 1 Peter Jandrisevits, who retired recently as director of engineering for Merck Co., manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, died today at John F. Kennedy Community Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 96 Buchanan Road.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 Willis Reed scored 53 points, the second-highest one-game total in his team's history, as the New York Knickerbockers snapped their six-game losing streak tonight by beating the Los Angeles Lakers, 129-113.

The Norfolk Western Railway applied yesterday to United States Supreme Court Justice John Marshall Harlan for a stay a temporary delay of the merger plans of the Pennsylvania and New York Central railroads.
The Hertz Corporation announced plans yesterday to buy 100,000 1968 cars and trucks valued at about $375million.
A clerk in a Brooklyn grocery store used a meat cleaver last night to kill a robber who had attacked him and the store owner, the police said.

When the New York Jets worked out at Shea Stadium yesterday, Joe Namath watched in street clothes. When the Jets play the Chiefs at Kansas City Sunday in a game that could make or break their American Football League season, chances are that Joe Namath will be their quarterback, bad ankle or not.

William E. McKenna, a 48year-old former accountant, was named president and chief executive officer yesterday of Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., in the latest management change for the company controlled by financier Norton Simon.

A white marble bust of the Lord Ramakrishna stands between three vases of autumn leaves and yellow pompoms on the altar of a Hindu chapel in an East Side townhouse. Smoke rises from incense sticks planted in a jar of sand and every Sunday morning 125 New Yorkers seated in rows of wooden chairs listen to a Sanskrit prayer.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 2 (AP)--Vietcong guerrillas seized the hamlet of Dailoc in South Vietnam's coastal lowlands early today and burned down more than 300 homes, military spokesmen said.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 1 (UPI) The Bank of the Republic suspended official dollar exchange operations today, a step generally interpreted as preliminary to a devaluation or changes in the exchange situation.
Sokol New York, the local chapter of the Bohemian gymnastic association, celebrated the 100th year of its founding here with a concert last night at Town Hall.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 2--A 28-year-old Buddhist nun committed suicide by fire yesterday as a protest against President Nguyen Van Thieu, Buddhist officials said today.

NOT having seen the first night of "Illya Darling" at the Mark Hellinger Theater last April, I have no idea of its condition on arrival, but having caught up with it about a month after its opening, I felt that it had been a little underestimated. It may not be the greatest musical on Broadway, but by then it was at least a notch or so above the average.

RESOURCEFULNESS of the cosmetics industry in ap pealing to the vanity of women was related last night by National Educational Television on its monthly series, "Your Dollar's Worth." The program, called "On Face Value," was seen on Channel 13.
Widespread profit taking produced a sharp drop in prices yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
CAIRO, Nov. 1 Two rival nationalist organizations that have been struggling for power in South Arabia have agreed to negotiate jointly with British authorities, it was announced here today.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Abner W. Sibal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Wells Sibal, to Ens. Albert V. Nahmias, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Nahmias of Jericho, L.I.
EAST has been meeting West in homes for centuries, but not in the way it happens in Sloane's House of Years, which opens tomorrow on the store's fifth floor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 President Johnson urged Congress today to remain in session this year until it had "faced up" to the nation's most compelling problems, especially the need for a tax increase.
ALGIERS, Nov. 1 President Houari Boumediene announced at a military and youth parade today that compulsory military service would be introduced in Algeria next year.
Leroy Keyes of Purdue has taken over the scoring lead among the nation's major college, football players, the latest statistics showed yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 1 Tradition has it that women always have the last word and that's the way it was as the Association of National Advertisers wound up its 58th annual meeting at the Homestead here.

A young mother, her two children and two children whom she was minding were burned fatally yesterday morning on the third floor of a three-story frame house in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. A flash fire from cleaning fluid on the first floor roared up the stairwell and trapped them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Why, you might reasonably ask, is it easier to pass a driving test than a College Board examination? The answer is that a College Board examination is an exclusion process while a driving test is an inclusion process.
An imitation stone wall topped by imitation green grass rose higher and higher through six jumpoffs until it stood at 7 feet 3 inches at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night.

After an ownership of 84 years, the property at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 48th Street has been sold by the Goelet estate to an investment group for cash over a new first mortgage of $525,000, through Ackman Brothers, Inc.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 1 J. Bentley Squier, formerly associated with the retail advertising department of The New York Times, died this morning at his home, 421 Scotland Street. He was 64 years old.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 Gov. George Romney lifted a borrowed trumpet to his lips, and a crowd of college students chuckled.
Michael S. Harris was elected yesterday as president of Franklin Book Programs at the annual meeting of the board of directors.

GRAND MASTER Pal Benko of New York is a posi tional chess player of rare talent, regarded as equal to the best in this style of play. But in the recent Winnipeg International Tournament he proved also that he could outwit an extraordinary tactician, Bent Larsen of Denmark, at Larsen's own game.
James F. McArdle says he thinks he is going to unseat Thomas J. Mackell as Queens District Attorney in next Tuesday's election, but few politicians in the county would agree with him.

The two chief administrators of the Roman Catholic school system in the city yesterday defended the advertisements being used to promote approval of the proposed state constitution as "absolutely and literally true."
Sharply reduced earnings were reported yesterday by two large copper producers for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, reflecting strikes and high operating costs.

Students at Columbia College and the university's School of Engineering have voted overwhelmingly in favor of open recruiting by any organization. The results of the poll were disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 Demands for George Brown's resignation as Foreign Secretary resounded today in the wake of his outburst against his host, Lord Thomson of Fleet, at a dinner attended by a group of American businessmen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 A once widely supported move in Congress to reassert Congressional prerogatives in the formulation of foreign policy floundered today in dissension within the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 1 The engagement of Miss Deborah Ann Lhamon to Dean Tecumseh Jamison has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. William Taylor Lhamon. Mr. Jamison is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marshall Verdine Jamison of Pacific Palisades, Calif.

Dr. and Mrs. Albert H. Grenade of Targnon and Verviers, Belgium, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Francine Grenade, to Alexander H. ter Weele, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl F. ter Weele of Brookfield, N.H.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Nov. 1 A train named the Silver Streak made its first run here this morning from the Long Island Rail Road's eastern commuter fringe to Hunters Point, Queens, and its 1,000 passengers had little quarrel with its name.
The Crucible Steel Company of America will hold its first stockholder meeting in two years on Dec. 14.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Nov. 1 George Lewis of Leewood and Pat Cici, Cedar Brook, teamed for a fiveunder-par best-ball card of 30, 35 65 at Sleepy Hollow Country Club today to take a twostroke lead after the first round of the annual pro-pro championship of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 Officials of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen served notice on the nation's major railroads today that they would call for wage improvements as high as 15.5 per cent, plus other changes in existing contracts.

Arthur Goldman and Richard V. Bandler have been promoted to associate regional administrators of the New York region of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Manuel F. Cohen, chairman of the S.E.C., announced.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The House-approved Social Security bill was revised by the Senate Finance Committee today to provide more liberal benefit increases and a stiffer tax rise.

ALLEGANY, N.Y., Nov. 1 Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas V. V.F. Munson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Monie Lusk Munson, to Gulden Godfrey Lloyd of Princeton, N.J. He is the son of John Palmer Lloyd of Phoenix, Ariz., and the late Mrs. Lloyd.
Vice President Humphrey will debate the American presence in South Vietnam with a group of high school students over a nationwide radio hookup on Dec. 7, the anniversary of Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations opened hearings into the causes of riots today, announcing that it would first seek to identify any lawless elements that might be responsible.

Frank Garcia Ortega, who as Jorge Hermida, writer of the column "En Nueva York," was well-known to Spanish-speaking residents of New York and in Latin America, died of a heart attack on Sunday in his home at 270 West End Avenue. His age was 78.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 The next summit meeting of the nations allied in the war in Vietnam has been postponed until next year, possibly until late February or early March, authoritative sources said today.
Federal Judge Edward C. McLean ruled yesterday that it was improper, as a matter of ethics, for a lawyer to have posttrial interviews with jurors.
Vincent Wholey, a 43-yearold steel company executive who has been the ringmaster at the National Horse Show since 1958, has a definitive explanation of his duties.

IN 50 years, from nearly a standing start, the Soviet Union has increased sports participation from 50,000 to 50 million and has become a leading athletic power in the world. From the ranks of its organized physical culturists will spring the teams to beat in the 1968 Olympic Games.

In Nassau County, where a million and a half people live, work and commute, voters will be called upon to make an important choice for County Executive Tuesday. Fortunately, they already have an outstanding official on the job.

"WHEN I first gave lessons in Chinese cooking," an authori ty on Chinese food said recently, "everyone wanted to know how to make moo goo gai pan and lobster Cantonese. Now, all of a sudden, they want to make mo-shu-to."
Negotiations between the American Broadcasting Conpany and a striking technicians' union broke off yesterday afternoon after what a union representative termed "a hopeless deadlock."
Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday that it was negotiating with a British shipyard for construction of the oil company's largest vessel, a tanker of 255,000 deadweight tons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1(UPI) The Soviet Union has taken the first steps toward opening a Moscow-to-New York air link that was agreed on six years ago but delayed by cold war tensions, it was learned today.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Thursday Nov. 2 A reserve plane used in Vice President Humphrey's tour of the war zone was struck by four rounds of small-arms fire yesterday en route from Saigon to Phubai, in the northern part of South Vietnam, Mr. Humphrey's news secretary disclosed here today.
The Columbia Pictures Corporation yesterday reorganized its top management.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The Senate approved today the creation of a redwood national park that would be carved out of public and private land in northern California.
ALBANY, Nov. 1 Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia accused Mayor Lindsay today of "doing a hatchet job on the other cities in the state" by opposing the proposed state constitution.
The Brooklyn Bridge, considered one of the world's most attractive bridges since its opening 84 years ago, had a new luster last night a necklace of bright lights.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov.1 The Legal Committee unanimously adopted today a declaration that defines the humanitarian obligations of nations to political refugees. It is expected that the General Assembly will follow suit and approve the declaration at the close of the current session.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 1 (UPI) A court of honor ruled tonight that there were no legitimate reasons for a duel between President Oscar Gestido and Amilcar Vasconcellos, a member of the Uruguayan Senate. The men had agreed in advance to accept the ruling.
Major cast changes will be made in "The Little Foxes" when the revival moves from the Vivian Beaumont Theater to the Ethel Barrymore Theater on Dec. 19.

Westchester's Board of Supervisors, under court mandate to conform to the one-man, one-vote doctrine, is offering the voters a miserable reapportionment plan in an effort to preserve as much as possible of its present antiquated structure. The plan is so bad that it was vetoed by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian, himself a Republican, but repassed over his veto by the Republican-controlled board.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 1 (UPI) Concerned about the safety and health of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the police transferred him today from a suburban branch jail to a cell atop the eight-story Jefferson County Courthouse.

The Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) went on record yesterday as strongly opposed to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's plan to build a new underwater cable to southern, Europe.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1 (UPI) Tom Okker of the Netherlands, one of Europe's best players, knocked Clark Graebner out of the South American tennis championship with a 6-2, 6-3, 6-3 rout of the secondranking United States star in the quarter-final round today.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 The General Motors Corporation shuffled its organization chart today, following the election of new executives of Monday.

Pupils in the city school system are continuing to lose ground in reading and arithmetic, a Board of Education report disclosed yesterday. The report, giving the results of standardized achievement tests conducted during the 1966-67 school year, showed that pupils in the public schools lagged behind national norms or standards in virtually every grade.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) Beginning Jan. 1, all new American automobiles will have to have visible labels or tags saying they conform with national safety standards.

FOR those who wish to teach their dogs to be- have, or to make champions of them, or to find out where they came from, or wish just to read about one veterinarian's fascinating experiences, recent additions to the bookshelf are the very thing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--A Congressional conference committee agreed in principle today to end the Defense Department's worldwide arms sales program next June 30.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov. 1 Vice President Humphrey ended a tour of South Vietnam today and asserted that the war was being won.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that a private poll showed the transportation bond issue had the support of a little more than half the state's voters. He said a little less than 25 per cent were opposed and the same number undecided.
Mr. and Mrs. John James McGuire have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Agnes McGuire, to John Charles Green Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Green. Both families are of Brooklyn.
Mayor Lindsay urged "an overriding priority" yesterday for city construction projects that "directly serve the city's inhabitants," leading off with neighborhood family medical centers.
A bail jumper from Manhattan now held in Hamburg, Germany, was indicted yesterday by a local grand jury for the shotgun murder of a marine sergeant in Greenwich Village last April.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 By midafternoon today, Saigon was exhausted. South Viet namese flags hung limply from windows in the tropical heat.
A ball on Nov. 15 aboard the Italian liner Michelangelo at Pier 90, 50th Street and the Hudson River will benefit the Police Athletic League.
DALLAS, Nov. 1 A national group of Negro clergymen began organizing today to make "black power" a force in American Protestant church policies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1(UPI) The House passed a multimillion-dollar program of flood insurance today for home owners and small businesses.

A group of 64 law students from 30 schools will assemble in Jackson, Miss., today under the auspices of the Law Students Civil Rights Research Council, 156 Fifth Avenue, to guide about 200,000 "first-time" Negro voters in exercising their rights of franchise in next Tuesday's elections.
ARCADIA, Fla., Nov. 1 (AP) A father's plan to collect $14,000 in life insurance led to the fatal poisonings of seven young children, Sheriff Frank Cline of DeSoto County said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 The United States hopes to flight test next week its first Saturn 5 moon rocket a 36-story giant that can put into space 93,000 times the three-pound weight of the Vanguard 1.

Marlene Dietrich is not the only chic sexagenarian who can put on a one-woman show and win cheers from a sophisticated audience. Jeanne-Marie Darr did just that last night at Carnegie Hall where she played a recital of Liszt piano pieces that glittered from start to finish.

Pope Paul VI's gift to the United Nations to "alleviate human suffering" a jeweled cross and ring was auctioned here yesterday to a Chicago jeweler for $64,000. Four United Nations organizations will share the proceeds.
THE WOMAN who once termed Jesus Christ elegant has won a journalism award.

THE CALIFORNIA savings and loan association stocks, favored by traders through two years of adversity, have just been recommended for the long term by one of Wall Street's more conservative brokerage houses.
LAUREL, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) John W. Haines's Sikkim won for the first time since last New Year's Day when he took the Early Autumn Purse at Laurel today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1--The chairman of the House Agriculture Committee stopped the solicitation of Congressional campaign funds for 1968 by the president of a major meat packers' association that supported a meat inspection bill approved by the House yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Negroes protesting the appointment of a white educator from Michigan as the new superintendent of Washington's nearly all-Negro public school system filed two lawsuits today seeking to block his acceptance of the bitterly contested post.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 1 (AP) Patrice Jacobs's Pleasantness, an 18-1 shot, and Mrs. Ben Cohen's Good Game, won the split divisions of The Gardenia Trial at Garden State Park today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee approved today a $589-million public health services extension bill containing $40-million its sponsors said could be used for rat-control projects.
The city's $6-million Science Museum in Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, was criticized yesterday by the City Planning Commission as "unworkable" and as having "only limited salvage value."

New Yorkers will vote next Tuesday on a $2.5billion transportation bond issue the biggest in the history of the state. Despite misgivings about some of its aspects, we have endorsed it as helpful to the economic growth of the state and an essential step toward solving the transportation problems of the metropolitan area.

The National Foreign Trade Council ended its 54th annual convention here yesterday expressing sharp opposition to protectionist moves in Congress. The moves are designed to impose import quotas on a large number of foreign products.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 Spencer Ervin, a lawyer here and author of several books, died here today. He was 81 years old and a resident of Bala, Pa.

BEARSVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 1 Joseph Kissam Inness, a member of the admiralty bar and the New York bar, died today at the Benedictine Hospital in Kingston. He was 74 years old and had homes here and in Delray Beach, Fla.

CAIRO, Nov. 1--The United States Congress's vote to ban imports of Egyptian cotton was called unwise and provocative yesterday by senior officials of the Egyptian Government, which has been sounding an increasingly stern and anti-American note in recent days.

Phillip Morris, Inc., realized a 24.8 per cent increase in third-quarter earnings on a sales gain of 15.9 per cent, lifting earnings for the nine months to 26.7 per cent and sales to 18.2 per cent over the corresponding year-ago period. Joseph F. Cullman 3rd, chairman and chief executive officer, in reporting the results yesterday, noted that all figures set new records.

WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 1 Three teen-agers were arrested on narcotics charges here yesterday amid disclosures that two young girls had suffered drug-induced hysteria in their high school classrooms last week.
BERLIN, Nov. 1 West Berlin's radical left-wing students set up today their own "critical university," a school designed to analyze and possibly change existing political structures in the West.

WINDSOR, Conn., Nov. 1 A long-range plan to move the Chaffee School to the grounds of the Loomis School was announced here today as part of an intensive campaign for capital gifts to finance a large-scale development program for the two 50-year-old schools.

The bond market spent another day at new lows yesterday before the Treasury, in the early evening, announced the surprising results of last Monday's $12.2-billion financing. Demand for the Government's new 5 per cent seven-year notes was heavier than Wall Street expected, and dealers last night predicted the long-term bond market would rally today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 Thirty-five local poverty programs serving 500,000 poor people will have to shut down within the next three weeks unless Congress agrees to fund them, the antipoverty agency said today.

Grain traders, who had edged up prices of grains on Tuesday, jumped back yesterday as prices fell sharply. Early yesterday, the news was that a House of Representatives agriculture subcommittee had voted against it, 8 to 6.
A 38-year-old blind man on trial in Criminal Court said yesterday that he had been harboring draft evaders and runaway soldiers in his midtown apartment.

The Great Performers series at Philharmonic Hall presented Alexis Weissenberg, the pianist, last night. The Bulgarian-born performer, once a Leventritt contest winner, now a 38-yearold Paris resident, returned here last year after a long absence as soloist with the New York Philharmonic. Last night's recital was his first locally in 15 years.

The withdrawal of China's aid mission from Burma and of her diplomatic mission from Indonesia are merely the latest incidents in a growing list of setbacks for Peking in its foreign relations. ROME, Nov. 1 The physicians of Pope Paul VI said tonight that he would undergo surgery in the next few days for correction of a urinary tract infection.

Heeding the outcries of Staten Island ferry riders, who still enjoy one of the world's cheapest boat rides, Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a restoration of half-hourly service between 10 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.

New Jersey is about to elect its first Legislature under the apportionment plan proposed by its Constitutional Convention and approved by its voters last November. It will enlarge the Senate from 29 to 40 members, and the Assembly from 60 to 80.

Hord W. Hardin, a St. Louis banker, athlete and golf executive, has been nominated to be the next president of the United States Golf Association.
