THE crisp autumn weather is delightful for watching a football game or taking a country walk, but outdoor activities on a cold day do increase the appetite. Starting luncheon or dinner with a bowl of homemade soup is a pleasant way to satisfy the hungry. Here are recipes for two unusual soups.
BOSTON, Nov. 7--Kevin H. White, the Massachusetts Secretary of State, was elected Mayor of Boston today over Mrs. Louise Day Hicks in a municipal election with racial overtones.

PRINCETON N.J. Nov. 7-- Confronted by the most exacting assignment facing any Ivy League team in the final three weeks of the campaign, Princeton hopes to muster its greatest strength of a football season in which it has been afflicted with an endless succession of injuries.
The Synagogue Council of America charged yesterday that Christian leaders had been morally lax in failing to condemn Arab threats of "genocide" against Israel.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 7 --The distinctive sound of Ford racing engines at high speed has been echoing over the desert from the Stardust International Raceway since early yesterday morning.
HARTFORD, Nov. 7--Miss Antonina P. Uccello scored an upset victory today to become Hartford's first Republican Mayor in 20 years.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 7--An atmosphere of excitement and nostalgia spread here today as preparations on the Saturn 5 moon rocket progressed flawlessly for its scheduled test launching Thursday morning.

SOUSSE, Tunisia, Nov. 7-- Grand Master Bent Larsen of Denmark increased his firstplace lead after completion of the 16th round of the Interzonal Chess Tournament when he defeated Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia here last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--President Johnson signed into law today a bill creating a nonprofit public corporation to accelerate the growth and improve the quality of noncommercial television.
LONDON, Nov. 7--A Foreign Office spokesman asserted emphatically today that there had been "no change" in the British position in the Middle East.

Jim Schindler of Archbishop Stepinac, who had built up endurance while pacing through the Swiss Alps last summer, won the 44th annual Private Schools Athletic Association cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday.

Robert Graves, the English poet, topped off a sociable lunch in New York yesterday with an erudite "proof" that there is a connection between the Lord's Prayer and LSD. Afterward, he dropped one eyelid in a suggestion of a wink and said: "That's why they say I'm unscholarly."

BANGKOK, Thailand-- "If we did things the same way as the existing corn merchants, we would be run out of Thailand," said Charles Cogliandro. "As Americans, we have a certain political responsibility. We must upgrade farming here."
The draft report of the Mayor's Advisory Panel on Decentralization of the New York City. Schools listed among the powers and duties of community districts the following:

John Nance Garner was a true son of the House of Representatives. He was "a thirty-year man," as House veterans call themselves. He knew and loved the House and its unique ways, and was a keen judge of its moods. When he was elected Speaker in 1931, his career reached its peak--or so he always thought, and few members of the House would disagree.
New York City Democrats won seven of the eight judgeships under contest in yesterday's election.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7--Following is the text of a declaration on discrimination against women, as adopted today in the General Assembly:

Greylock Airways, Inc., and a pilot and co-pilot of the company brought suit yesterday charging negligence in maintaining the air traffic control pattern at La Guardia. The case involves a collision between an airliner and a small private plane last May.

Saw Dr. James Killian, chairman of the board of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; signed public television bill; saw Attorney General Clark; issued statement of eulogy on the death of former Vice President Garner; sent telegram of congratulations to the chairman of the Soviet Presidium on the 50th anniversary of the establishment of the Soviet Government; met with Democratic Congressional leaders.

Dr. Rufus Early Clement, president of Atlanta University and one of the nation's leading Negro educators, died yesterday in his room at the Roosevelt Hotel. The cause of his death was not immediately determined.
WINNIPEG, Man.--The winds of the prairie winter and the effects of the Government's credit squeeze arrived here this week, creating a rather frosty atmosphere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- King Hussein of Jordan called on Israel today to match what he termed "the new and positive approach of the Arabs" toward a Middle East settlement by "offering some terms for us to consider."
BLUE POINT, L.I., Nov. 7 --Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison, who won his first election eight years ago by 486 votes, was elected for a third term today by 30,000.
John Kenneth Galbraith notwithstanding, business seems determined to involve itself in the problems of the cities.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7--The United Arab Republic called today for a Security Council meeting to discuss what it termed the dangerous situation arising from the refusal of Israel to withdraw her forces from Arab territories conquered in June.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- The Senate, without one word of debate, passed a bill today that would permit commercial banks to underwrite and sell revenue bonds of state and local governments.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Nov. 7 (AP)--Mrs. John F. Kennedy toured the ornate royal palace of Cambodia today, then, standing under a gilded parasol in the tropical sun, fed bananas and sugar cane to two royal elephants.

Brooklyn Tech, the only undefeated and untied team in the Public Schools Athletic League football ranks, routed Lafayette, 35-16, yesterday in a Division II game at Madison Field in Brooklyn. It was the sixth victory for the Engineers.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 7--Seven Arab infiltrators were killed by Israeli soldiers today in a fight three miles northeast of Hebron. There were no Israeli casualties.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--A House Republican leader put a label of "bossism and boll weevil" today on an important provision of the antipoverty bill.
CAIRO, Nov. 7--The United Arab Republic was reported today to have decided to accept conditionally President Johnson's five-point formula for a Middle Eastern peace settlement.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Director of the Selective Service, Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, said tonight that his agency had doclded to "live up to the letter" of the draft laws and to induct or aid in the prosecution of persons who violated them.
The Democratic district attorneys in the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island won easy victories yesterday in their contests for re-election.

MAS A TIERRA, Chile, Oct. 25--The anniversary was forgotten by the people who lived here, but it was 263 years ago that the British galley Cinque Ports landed a young Scotsman named Alexander Selkirk somewhere on this rocky shore.
"America Hurrah," Jean Claude van Itallie's successful satire on American life, has been unable to find a Chicago theater for a Christmas opening.

The Negro is remaking the politics of the nation's cities. In Cleveland and in Gary, Negro candidates ran for Mayor in yesterday's elections. Elsewhere, as in Boston and Philadelphia and New Haven, the pressure of Negroes to achieve a better life for themselves was forcing the entire community to re-examine its own priorities and take a fresh look at its own problems.
The Government is expected to announce within a few days a new rate structure for cargoes moving abroad under any of the foreign aid programs.

A Federal judge here issued a permanent injunction yesterday enjoining a Toronto corporation and nine Ontario residents from selling unregistered stock of North American Research Development, Inc., a Salt Lake City, Utah, concern.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7--Two companies of the United States First Infantry Division, searching for remnants of the Vietcong regiments reported to have been eliminated in fighting last week near the Cambodian border, were apparently ambushed today.

LAS CRUCES, N. M., Nov. 7 (AP)--A defense attorney told a jury in a Federal court today that it was arrogance on the part of two Forest Service rangers that excited a land grant group in a confrontation with the rangers.
The New York Rangers and Boston Bruins, off to their best starts in the National Hockey League in many years, will meet tonight at Madison Square Garden for the first time this season.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7--The Soviet Union's 50th anniversary was observed here today with a flood of tributes, a stinging attack from Albania and a short-lived demonstration from White Russian emigres.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7--The ranking minority member of the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy asserted here today that the time had come to decide just what role the Atomic Energy Commission's laboratories should play in the nation's over-all scientific effort.

Modifying their long-standing, belligerent policy of uncompromising intransigence, the Arab states have now launched a diplomatic offensive aimed, in the words of Jordan's King Hussein, at "a just and lasting peace" in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- The Senate ethics committee announced today it would "fully consider" the latest allegation of misconduct made against senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri, by Life magazine.
GARY, Ind., Nov. 7--Richard G. Hatcher, a Democrat, became the first Negro Mayor of Gary today by a margin of 1,389 votes over Joseph B. Radigan, a white Republican.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 (AP)-- Thomas J. D'Alesandro 3d, 38year-old son of a three-term Democratic Mayor of Baltimore, won the mayoral election today by a landslide.

YONKERS, Nov. 7--See Lucky, the 1-10 favorite, moved from third at the three-quartermile mark to first 40 yards from the finish tonight to beat Meditation and Yankee Shadow in the $35,000, one-mile New York Sire Stakes pace for 4year-olds at Yonkers Raceway.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 7--Israeli officials have reacted sourly to King Hussein's comments indicating that the Arabs would end the state of war with Israel under certain unspecified conditions.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7-- Mayor James H. J. Tate won reelection tonight over his Republican opponent, District Attorney Arlen Specter, in the city's closest mayoral election in 32 years.
Orlando Cepeda, the "Baby Bull" of the St. Louis Cardinals, was unanimously elected the most valuable player in the National League yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 7 (AP) --Damascus of the United States was installed today as the 4-5 favorite for Saturday's $150,000 Washington D. C. International as his chief challenger, Engalnd's Ribocco, arrived at Laurel Race Course.
PETER USTINOV'S "Halfway Up the Tree," which opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater last night, is another generation-gap comedy, but a generation-gap comedy with a slight difference.
Eustace Tilley, the salesman, seems to be popping up all over the place lately.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7-- San Franciscans rejected today a proposal for an immediate cease-fire and withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam.
"The United Seivice Organizations, with 26 years of service to those in the armed forces, answers the prayers of many mothers by 'providing a wholesome

The marathon legal battle between Rodney Jenkins and the American Horse Shows Association took a new twist yesterday when the 22-year-old professional rider instructed his attorney to bring suit against the group.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 7 (UPI) --At least three Negroes won election to county office in Mississippi's general elections today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 7--Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, the retired paratroop officer who has been one of the most persistent critics of American policy in Vietnam, ended a six-day familiarization visit to the war zone today without having significantly changed his views.
CLEVELAND, Wednesday, Nov. 8--State Representative Carl B. Stokes, a Negro Democrat, apparently defeated Seth B. Taft, a white Republican, yesterday in a tight contest for Mayor.

KINSHASA, Congo--The illusion that the Congo can be chopped up and recolonized by white men belongs with those other famous illusions of our time: "I can do business with the Chinese" and. "Martinis don't affect me." Progress in Africa can't be repealed, and decolonialism is here to stay.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7--A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the abandonment piovision of the state's new divorce law is retroactive, making an offense before en-- actment of the law a ground for divorce.

EXCEPT for the little old lady from Dubuque, women should be pretty pleased with the spring fashion hap penings on Seventh Avenue. Though designers have generally ignored very old ladies, they have taken care of practically everybody else, including the woman of 60-plus who has kept her figure and her outlook brisk.
William Sumner Appleton Pott, former president of Elmira College, died yesterday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 74 years old.

Before the House passed the conference report on the Congressional redistricting bill, Representative Emanuel Celler of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, acknowledged that its intent was to keep the courts from ordering a state either to be redistricted before the 1970 census, or to elect its representatives at large before then.

Two-thirds of New York City's 57,000 teachers and supervisory personnel have elected to participate in a new variable annuity investment program that will generate $100-million a year for investment in common stocks, it was disclosed yesterday.
New Jersey Republicans recaptured both houses of the Legislature yesterday in a powerful display of strength, winning 3-to-1 majorities in the Senate and Assembly.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 7 --George William Burpee, a consulting engineer who was perhaps best known as an expert on railroad valuation, died today of a heart attack in Lawrence Hospital. He would have been 84 years old Thursday. His home was at Southgate, Alger Court.

DESPITE the fact that Duarte Pinto-Coelho has decorated his own apartment with a baroque l7thcentury organ, he has different ideas when it comes to furnishing the homes of his high-born and wealthy clients. For them he prescribes cotton and a considerable amount of fantasy.

BOBBY CRUICKSHANK will be inducted next week into the Hall of Fame of the Professional Golfers' Association find every old-timer will glow with happy satisfaction. The little fellow has long since faded from the competitive links, but the 27 living members of the Hall have seen fit to honor his exploits by electing him to their group. They could not have picked a more delightful companion to join their lodge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Soviet Union is deliberately challenging the nuclear superiority of the United States, thus introducing a dangerous turbulence into foreign relations, a Congressional subcommittee was told today.

DENVER, Nov. 7--Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that the Defense Department had become a powerful force for social betterment while maintaining the nation's extensive military commitments abroad.
New York University upset the previously unbeaten Long Island University soccer team, 3-1, yesterday at the winners' Ohio Field in the Bronx.

SECAUCUS, N.J., Nov. 7-- Voters here gave the Democratic organization in Hudson County a stunning defeat today when they rejected a proposal to build a $20-million track in their community for night harness racing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- Dr. John Regan Overman, associate director for collaborative research at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, died today at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 45 years old and apparently had suffered a heart attack.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7.-- Unemployment increased significantly in October for the second straight month and reached its highest level in two years, the Labor Department reported today.

The British equestrian team, which had not been at its best most of the time, ended the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night with a grand flourish. Two of its members rode their mounts the fastest of all, and flawlessly, too, and took first and second places for the Grand Prix of New York.

MINEOLA, L. I., Wednesday, Nov. 8--County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson won re-election yesterday over Sol Wachtler, his Republican opponent, by 845 votes, complete but unofficial returns showed this morning. It was the closest race for County Executive in Nassau's history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- President Johnson is now working on what he calls an electronic "network of knowledge" for the United States, and on a world university that will store and eventually transmit information by satellite over large areas of the world's surface.
Prices moved down in slow trading on the London stock market yesterday.
At 9:55 last night, Edward Burnham and Jan Williams walked out, one the stage of Carnegie Recital Hall and began tapping the inside of a grand piano with mallets.
SARAH Duchess of Marlborough was one of those people who can hardly believe they are truly disliked for themselves alone.

The reorganization of the city school system into a federation of 30 to 60 largely autonomous; locally governed community school districts will be recommended by Mayor Lindsay's special panel on school decentralization.

The Insurance Exchange Building, Chicago's largest office structure, will be purchased by a partnership of Lawrence A. Wien, owner of the Empire State Building, and Harry B. Helmsley, president of the New York real estate firm of Helmsley-Spear, Inc.
Louis M. Walger, director of mutuels for the New York Racing Association, died of cancer yesterday morning at his home, 204 Mill Spring Road; Manhasset, L. I. He was 71 years old.
Facsimiles of 35 volumes by participants in the American Revolution, most of the 30 works represented long out of print, will, be published this winter by The New York Times and Arno Press, Inc.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 8--Louie B. Nunn, a small-town Republican lawyer, won the Governorship of nominally Democratic Kentucky today. It was an upset that Mr. Nunn said in a victory statement would be "noted" portentously at the White House in Washington.
New Yorkers voted by a margin of nearly 3-to-1 yesterday to reject a controversial new state constitution in an election dominated by an emotional fight over the church-state issue.

Accepting the advice of virtually every good-government organization and the vast majority of newspapers in this state, New York's voters have rejected the proposed new Constitution. The people of New York will now have to continue for a while with the same old Constitution that has been the state's basic law--with numerous amendments--since 1894.
THE Giants' football team assembled at Yankee Stadium yesterday and took up the matter of the next opponent, the Chicago Bears, which largely means Gale Sayers.
The Rev. Dr: Hugo Hahn, a rabbi who founded Congregation Habonim, 44 West 66th Street, died yesterday at the Madison Avenue Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 10 West 74th Street.
A motorist's guide on how to avoid a Queens bottleneck was issued yesterday by Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes.

A powerful and well-balanced New York University crosscountry team captured the Metropolitan Intercollegiate team championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. The result was not a surprise.
UVALDE, Tex., Nov. 7--John Nance Garner, Vice President of the United States under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died in his home here this morning. He would have been 99 years old on Nov. 22.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7--Five new types of Soviet missiles rumbled across the cobblestones of Red Square today in a military review celebrating a half-century of Soviet rule.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The State Department relayed an authoritative report today that Gustav C. Hertz, a senior American aid official is Vietnam, died of malaria while he was held prisoner by the Vietcong.
The Government of Newfoundland sharply raised its take in the oil business yeserday when Premier Joseph R. Smallwood announced plans to build a $100-million, 100,000-barrel-a-day refinery.

As a choreographer, Richard Wagner obviously doesn't subscribe to the notion that youths have all the fun. In his moving ballet, "Youth,' which was given its premiere last night by the Harkness. Ballet at the Broadway Theater, a young couple danced by Lone Isaksen and Lawrence Rhodes, exquisitely missed connections.
In the paddock before yesterday's $57,400 Vosburgh Handicap at Aqueduct, Dr. Fager pawed the ground impatiently, as if to say, "Don't fool with me, take me out there and let me run."
New York City held an elegant, but discreet and abstemious, luncheon yesterday for the royal party of Nepal on the upper-level grand promenade in Philharmonic Hall in Lincoln Center.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (UPI)--A civil suit seeking $10-million from 18 book publishers filed last Wednesday by Illinois Attorney General William G. Clark has been joined by eight other states and four cities, it was announced today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 7-- Ahmed Mohammed Noman, one of the three members of the Yemeni Presidential Council, which heads the regime established by a military coup Sunday, indicated today that he thought the people should decide tHe form of government for the small nation in the Red Sea.
MOST players know that a 4-4 fit is sometimes more productive than a 5-3 fit, although there are occasional hands on which the converse is true.

William Inge, winner of the Pulitzer Prize and the Critics Circle award for "Picnic" and an Oscar for the original story and screenplay of "Splendor in the Grass," said yesterday in Hollywood that he was working on a cycle of seven or eight short plays with the over-all title of "Complex."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--Roman Catholic schools are being financed by "regressive" techniques that place a disproportionate burden on the church's poorer members, according to an expert on the fiscal policies of Catholic education.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 7-- Representative John Bell Williams, a segregationist Democrat who backed the Republicans in 1964, easily won election tonight as Governor of Mississippi.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 7--The United Nations unanimously adopted today a declaration that seeks to eliminate discrimination against women throughout the world.
GENEVA, Nov. 7--Eric Wyndham White said today that he would not reconsider his decision to abandon the post of director general of the General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade.

The immobilization of 10 Sea-Land Service, Inc., containerships, the last vestige of the 16-day Brooklyn waterfront strike, ended yesterday as the steamship company came to terms with the Seafarers International Union.
THE bulldog is a squat, barrel-chested, canine whose ferocious scowl masks one of the most amiable dispositions in dogdom. The bulldog also is the mascot of Yale University. His breed also serves...

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7-- The American Conservatory Theater, which recently decided upon San Francisco as a permanent home, today announced receipt of a $350,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Senate Appropriations Committee sought today to head off payless paydays for thousands of Federal employes next week.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 7--A Yale fraternity accused by the student newspaper of burning its initiates with a brand will have its fate decided Friday by student fraternity leaders.

Imperial Oil, Ltd., a Torontobased concern controlled by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced plans yesterday to sell $50-million of debentures--$10-million of serial securities maturing from 1972 to 1976 and $40-million of a 20-year sinking fund issue. The debentures are expected to be priced late this month and dated Jan. 1. The proceeds would be used for general corporate purposes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee and Secretary of State Dean Rusk today went over and over and around and around the vexing question of whether Mr. Rusk should testify in public session on the Administration's Vietnam policy.
President Johnson's signing of the bill creating the Corporation for Public Broadcasting is a crucial forward step in the evolution of television and radio.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 7-- Democrats won 3-to-2 control of the five-man Rockland County Board of Supervisors today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- Stewart L. Udall, the Secretary of the Interior, is not just an administrator of Natiorial Park Service programs. He proved today, that he was an active participant in those programs by jogging two miles along the Potomac Rivei on one of four new jogging trails opened by the National Park Service.
New York City's antipoverty program faces "disastrous consequences" from potential cuts in appropriations pending in the House of Representatives, two key city officials asserted yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard Sturgis Perkins of 141 East 72d Street and Islip, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Havemeyer Perkins, to Frederick William Moir, son of Mrs. John Aspin of Henley-onThames, England and James Tweed Moir of Edinburgh, Scotlard.
An early Picasso, 12 recent paintings by Mirb and 10 other art works were stolen from a delivery truck on Manhattan's East Side over the weekend, the police disclosed yesterday.
A proposed amendment to the present New York constitution that would have quadrupled the lending capacity of the State Job Development Authority was rejected yesterday by a slim margin.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7-- Republicans retained control of the Westchester County government today and won a majority of local offices in the 18 towns and six cities.

THE extensive dislocation of South Vietnam's so ciety under wartime conditions was detailed last night in the second and final part of the Columbia Broadcasting System's study of "Where We Stand in Vietnam."

The rejection of the proposed constitution by the voters yesterday immediately raised the question of how many of the charter's provisions would be salvaged by the Legislature and put on the ballot later as amendments to the present constitution.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that the current rate of increase in wages and prices -- including the 6 per cent raise in wages and benefits just negotiated at the Ford Motor Company--was "clearly excessive" and "gaining momentum."

The proposals disclosed yesterday for the decentralization of the city school system resulted from two originally unrelated pressures--widespread demands to make the schools more responsive to local needs, and Mayor Lindsay's search for more state aid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- One chic Washingtonian, a keen observer of fashions along the diplomatic circuit, gazed across several hundred guests in the rich ballrooms of the Soviet Embassy tonight, and shook her head.
A representative of 20,000 unionized taxi drivers here said yesterday that there was a possibility of a drivers' strike when the union's contract with the major taxi fleets expires Nov. 16.
The Soviet Union's delegation to the United Nations threw a 50th anniversary party last night, inviting 1,600 guests who would be unlikely to celebrate together on any other occasion.

Heated controversy about the proposed state constitution, rather than any last-minute drive by political organizations, brought large numbers of New Yorkers to the polls in the closing hours of yesterday's election.
Savings institutions in New York State should be given greater freedom to compete for the savings dollar, a blueribbon committee of bankers and lawyers said yesterday.

EMERGING on top in the political upheavals of the Red Sea state of Yemen has become habitual for Ahmed Mohammed Noman.
"Tobruk" and "World Without Sun" at St. Marks Theater.
With most commodities markets in this country closed, interest centered yesterday on the activities taking place on the Chicago Board of Trade and the foreign exchanges.
MOSCOW, Nov. 7--Cuba today slighted the Soviet Union's celebration of a half century of its existence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) --The amount of credit outstanding at national banks under credit card and other revolving credit plans jumped 27.9 per cent between last April 25 and Oct. 4, the Controller of the Currency reported today. The total outstanding Oct. 4 was $837.7-million at 4,772 national banks.

Combined net profit of Unilever, N.V., and its sister company, Unilever, Ltd., the Dutch and British partners in the worldwide soap, margarine and foodstuffs producer, set records in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, according to the results announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7-- The Supreme Court was told today that racial strife might erupt in Alabama's jail if the state was forced to desegregate its prison system.

At 85, Leopold Stokowski remains the most enigmatical of our great recreative musicians. Consider his concert at Philharmonic Hall last night, when he conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra in a seraphic and ultimately hair-raising Mahler Symphony No. 2 along with what the program contended was the Bach Magnificat.
New York State voters approved yesterday a $2.5-billion bond issue for highways, masstransit facilities, and airports. The margin appeared to be 3 to 2.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7--The Senate Finance Committee will reconsider a $6.1-billion increase in Social Security taxes that it approved last week and probably scale it down, members said today.

Deliberate or not, the top executive suite in every major store has a hallowed, almost remote look. It is as if those who sit there do not want the hurly-burly on the lower floors to interfere with the calm reasoning and objective planning that retailers like to feel they bring to their job.

PORTLAND,Ore., Nov. 8 An admitted Communist, Donald Hamerquist, was ousted as the Democratic precinct committee in a special election yesterday. The vote was 60 to 9 in a precinct with 212 registered Democrats.

MIQUON, Pa., Nov. 8--Mr. and Mrs. Lane Taylor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Sharpe Taylor, to Robert Alan Lukens. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis N. Lukens of Lafayette Hill.

Miss Mary Mills Morrison of Darien, Conn., was married, yesterday at noon to Dr. Edward J. Becker of New York, a dentist. The Rev. Ralph E. Peterson, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church.

MOSCOW, Nov. 8 Some leaders of European Communist parties are remaining briefly in Moscow, though not for any important meeting on such preoccupations as the calling of a world conference of Communist parties, according to informed sources.
Directors of Audio Devices, Inc., and Capitol Records, Inc., reached an agreement in principle yesterday for their merger, subject to approval of stockholders of both companies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) President Johnson will undertake on Saturday what may be his widest ranging United States tour of the year when he visits military bases in observance of Veterans Day.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire manufacturer, achieved record sales and earnings in the third quarter and first nine months, it was announced yesterday in Akron, Ohio.
THE entire chess world was startled when Bobby Fischer of New York, the United States chess champion, was dropped from the Interzonal qualifying Tournament at Sousse, Tunisia.
BONN, Nov. 8 Like a wellcrafted work of fiction, reports that the West German Government was planning to revalue the Deutsche-mark turned out to have been plausible but untrue.
The City Planning Commission closed its hearings on next year's capital budget yesterday after receiving requests from city agencies totaling $1.8-billion.

SECAUCUS, N. J., Nov. 8--Racing fans and business here today blamed the emphasis on "undesirable elements" and "the immoralityy of gambling" for the defeat of the harness racing track in yesterday's countywide referendum.
BONN, Nov. 8 Adolf Heinz Beckerle, once Hitler's envoy to Sofia, went on trial in Frankfurt today charged with aiding in the deportation of 11,343 Bulgarian Jews to death camps in wartime Poland.

TEANECK, N. J., Nov. 8 With Tony Jackson and Jim Caldwell generating a streak of 18 consecutive points early in the final quarter, the New Jersey Americans routed the Pittsburgh Pipers, 120-97, tonight for the rather exclusive edification of 503 customers.
Plans for a "new town" of 23,500 people on the bucolic south shore of Staten Island were recommended yesterday by consultants to the City Planning Commission.

There is scant comfort in the House Appropriations Committee's promise to oppose any further cuts in the foreign-aid bill it has sent to the House floor. The bill has been butchered enough within the committee. A minimal Administration request of $3.2 billion in new funds has been hacked down by a record 31 per cent to $2.2 billion, the lowest figure in the program's history.
The nation's voters appeared yesterday to have approved more than 90 per cent of the $3.46-billion of bond issues on their ballots Tuesday.
A bridge era ended here last night when Wingate Bixby, a retired banker now associated with a stock exchange firm, resigned as president of the Regency Whist Club.

The results in Tuesday's elections indicated, in the view of some key politicans yesterday, that people had voted for or against the proposed constitution in line with their income class. Lower-income areas showed votes in favor; middleand, higher-income sections voted against and crushedthe proposal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (UPI) President Johnson signed an international agreement today to raise the world food pride for wheat and enlist other developed countries in the United States' Food for peace plan.

THERE are 1,555 bloodhounds used by police de partments in the United States. Only 10 per cent of the work they do is tracking criminals. Lost children account for 80 per cent and lost adults the remainder.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 The Senate moved today to ease the plight of thousands of Fed eral employes threatened with payless paydays next week.

Jeffry and Ronald Marlowe, identical twins, are a formidable two-piano team. They were heard, last night at Town Hall, and no matter what the technical challenge fast unison passages, tricky rhythms, minute shadings the two Marlowes played as one. But only in the second half-of their program did they produce, what, is the deepest sense, can be called music.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 A Senate subcommittee approved today a plan that would make substantial Federal funds available for the first time to help lower-income families buy their own homes.
The city-owned Flatlands Industrial Park has got its second prospective tenant, a manufacturer of electronic equipment:

George A. Murphy, chairman of the Irving Trust Company, said yesterday that "things are moving" in the direction of an increase in the prime, or minimum interest, rate on bank loans to business. The prime rate has been at 5 per cent since March 27, when it was reduced from 5 per cent.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 8--Albert Da Costa, an American tenor who sang at the Metropolitan Opera from 1955 until 1962, was killed early today when the car he was driving went out of control on a highway near Kolding, Jutland, about 150 miles west of Copenhagen.

"IF you want quality, go to the farm," John Enders, a turkey breeder and grower in Cranbury, N. J., since 1929, said as he readied a fresh-killed 36-pound bird "enough to serve 50 people" for the cooler.

Early dental treatment starting at age 2 or younger can save most children from the unhappy consequences of bad teeth and cut future dental bills by hundreds of dollars, according to an authority on children's dentistry.

BOB MITTEN, West Chester State's football coach, has said he was surprised when the Rams were invited to the Tangerine Bowl last year after losing a close decision to Clarion in the Pennsylvania State College championship game.
Industrial issues finished lower after erratic trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia Nov. 8. Prince Norodom Sihanouk renewed attacks on United States policy today minutes after ceremonially marking the end of Mrs. John F. Kennedy's six-day visit to Cambodia.

Handy Harman's spot silver price rose yesterday to the highest level in this dramatic year for silver. The concern, a leading dealer and fabricator of silver, quoted a price of $1.93 2-10, a rise of 27-10 of a cent above the Monday price. Silver futures also showed strength, setting some new lifetime highs.

HORROR movies of the "Frankenstein" variety in varlably end with a solemn warning not to fool around with the supernatural a warning one wishes Paddy Chayevsky had heeded when he composed. "The Tenth Man" nearly a decade ago.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 8 "Who likes October?" asks the current issue of the Yugoslav humor magazine Jez in an article on the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 8 Sharp ground action was reported today in the northern provinces and in the Central Highlands. Three planes were shot down in raids against North Vietnam.

The Amigo Ball, a dinner dance for the benefit of the North Shore Hospital, will be held on Saturday in the Imperial Ballroom at the Americana. Mrs. Garry M. Ketcham is chairman. The event is fully subscribed, and 1,050 guests are expected.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 8 The Rockland vote ran according to form yesterday. The two Republican county officials were re-elected and the Democrats retained control of the Board of Supervisors, although they lost one seat.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., Nov. 8--Volkswagen of America, Inc., announced today that it was recalling 1,764 of its 1968 model station wagons and trucks to check front door locks that might be defective.

WASHINGTON, Nov.2 Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey said today he had "talked with somebody" at the White House before issuing a letter on Oct. 26 recommending speedy conscription of persons who interfere with draft procedures or military recruitment.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 8 A Nigerian playwright has smuggled a letter out of his prison cell here denying "most emphatically" that he confessed to aiding, the secessionist regime of the former Eastern Region.

The school decentralization proposal that has been submitted to Mayor Lindsay aims at taking the nation's largest school system and transforming it into three or four dozen versions of suburban school districts.
CUCHI, South Vietnam, Nov. 7--Gripping a flashlight in one hand and a pistol in the other, a "tunnel rat" crawls through the darkness and waits for a sound, a movement, a rustle.

ATHENS, Nov. 8 Commercially, the Greek press is doing fine under censorship and this, according to the ultracynics in this city of cynics, is one of the main reasons for the continuation of the censorship here.
More than 400 people are expected to attend the first New York Assembly of the season tonight in the Grand Ballroom of the Biltmore. The second assembly is scheduled for Jan. 5 at the Plaza.

MONTREAL, Nov. 8 (UPI)--A power blackout hit Montreal and several south shore communities this morning. About a million people were affected. Officials said a break had occurred in a high-tension power line.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that both administrators and those being aided by antipoverty programs were "being penalized by this uncertain and demoralizing situation," in which Federal funds have been suspended.

ADEN, Nov. 8 The National Liberation Front, the apparent victor in last week's armed struggle with the rival nationalist group, the Front for the Liberation of Occupied South Yemen, demanded today that Britain recognize it as the sole representative of the people' of South Arabia when the area becomes independent later this month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) James R. Lawson, president of Fisk University, Negro institution in Nashville, testified today that these were indications that an incident that preceded a riot near the campus last April 8 was prearranged.

The head of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority, Dr. William J. Ronan, said yesterday that any new subways financed by the bond issue approved in Tuesday's election would take at least five years to build.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) The Agriculture Department accused railroads today of making exaggerated estimates of increased labor costs to obtain freight rate increases of around $300-million a year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Republicans and Democrats professed today to draw encouragement for 1968 from the scattered, often contradictory results of yesterday's election.
The municipal and state elections this week in scattered parts of the country have produced the usual crosscurrents due to local and personal factors. A slight rightward drift, however, is visible,

Norman Taylor, a botanist associated with the New York Botanical Garden and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, an explorer and an author, died in Washington Hospital Center Sunday, after, a month's illness. His age was 84.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 James E. Day, president of the Midwest Stock Exchange since its creation in 1949, died today in Grant Hospital at the age of 62. He had entered the hospital. Sunday after having suffered a heart attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) President Johnson signed today a bill he said assured equal opportunity for women in the armed forces and pointed to the day when there might be some female generals or admirals.
Rumrill-Hoyt is the latest American ad agency to take the big step abroad. It has joined up with the group of London agencies headed by H. T. Parker and they have divided up the world.
John P. Callahan, a member of the news staff of The New York Times for 22 years, died at Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday of complications following a cerebral hemorrhage and surgery for ulcers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Vice President Humphrey gave an optimistic report on Vietnam to President Johnson and Congressional leaders today.

The Taxi Industry News Service announced last night that by the end of the year one out of every four taxi drivers working at night, would be an off-duty policeman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 Gardner Ackley, chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the steep rise in defense spending appeared to be flattening out.
Harry Clark Bentley, the founder and president emeritus of the Bentley College of Accounting and Finance, Waltham, Mass., died Sunday in Lenoir Hospital, Kinston, H. G. He was 90 years old.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (UPI) Stan Mikita scored twice and Pit Martin once tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens, their first home triumph in five National Hockey League games this season.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 8 (AP) If Kentucky Southern College dies on schedule Nov. 30, Winston Parker, 18 years old, can show a personal telephone bill of $150 to prove he tried to save it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 The Senate rejected today the conference committee bill that was intended to delay court enforcement of Congressional redistricting until 1972.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 8 Republicans in Westchester County today celebrated their biggest election victory since the Eisenhower sweeps in the nineteen-fifties.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 The Israeli Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, today criticized United States and Indian draft resolutions submitted to the Security Council on the ground that they did not sufficiently support Israel's demand for direct negotiations toward a Middle Eastern settlement.
RICHMOND, Nov. 8 Modest Republican gains and the selection of the first Negro to serve in Virginia's General Assembly since 1891 marked the state's Legislative election yesterday.
The New York Central Railorad announced yesterday that it would submit a major plan for cleaner and faster through service in the state to the Public Service Commission in Albany.

LUBUMBASHI, the Congo, Nov. 8 The armed force that had invaded the Congo's copper-rich Iiatanga Province seemed today to have vanished as quietly and mysteriously as it entered the country last Wednesday.
PASADENA, Calif., Nov. 8 (UPI) America's Surveyor 6 spacecraft sailed smoothly today toward a rendezvous with the moon after scoring an initial navigation triumph on its quarter-million-mile flight.
JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 8 A Negro won a seat in the allwhite Mississippi Legislature for the first time in decades in yesterday's general election.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Nov. 9--President Nguyen Van Thieu named a Cabinet today composed mainly of persons associated with the military government he headed as chief of state until his inauguration 10 days ago.
BOSTON, Nov. 8-Boston voters yesterday, elected a Negro and a Beacon Hill Yankee to the nine-man City Council.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 8 "Wasn't that nice?" County Executive H. Lee Dennison asked quietly, sounding as if he were reading a bread-andbutter note rather than the tabulation of the strongest endorsement he had even received from Suffolk County voters.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 Gen. Lauris Norstad urged today that the United States "give serious consideration" to taking steps as far as a complete unilateral cease-fire if necessary to help bring the Vietnam conflict to the negotiation table. He mentioned unconditional cessation of United States bombing as one possible course of action.
Dr. Courtney C. Brown, dean of the Graduate School of Business at Columbia University, was elected yesterday to the board of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.

BOSTON, Nov. 8 (AP) A pilot for Northeast Airlines identified Mrs. Patricia Diaferio today in Federal District Court as one of two persons he saw standing by two parked cars on Route 3 in Plymouth a short time before the $1.5-million Plymouth mail truck robbery in August, 1962.
BONN, Nov. 8 Stateless victims of Nazi persecution scattered by the thousands throughout the world are still awaiting financial reparations more than 22 years after the end of World War II.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 A leading spokesman for shipping interests urged Congress today not to pass legislation dealing with the size of cargo containers and the design of containerships.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 Two Czechoslovak amateur golfers there are no professionals in their country form one of 39 teams here to challenge Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus of the United States in the fourday World Cup tournament beginning tomorrow at the Club de Golf Mexico.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., Nov. 8--A Somerville man was fatally injured here at 4 A. M. today when a car he was driving was struck by a Port Reading freight train at the South Avenue rail crossing. He was identified by the police as Nathaniel Green, 36 years old, of 21 Central Avenue, Somerville.

NINE weeks ago next Sunday, when the New York Jets opened their American Football League season at Buffalo, Matt Snell suffered torn cartilage in the left knee. Three weeks later, he underwent surgery.
CAIRO, Nov. 8-The chief spokesman for the Government, Dr. Mohammed H. el-Zayyat, asserted today at his weekly news conference that the United Arab Republic guaranteed the "right of Israel to exist."

RENO, Nov. 8 Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr., an author and member of one of the wealthiest families in the nation, married for the seventh time here on Saturday, it was learned today. Mr. Vanderbilt, 69 years old, wed Mrs. Mary Lou Bristol, 41, of Terrell, Tex. The couple met several years ago in Miami Beach.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange sagged lower yesterday under the weight of a late selling wave that erased some strong gains recorded early in the session.

Mr. and Mrs. Julian E. Gordon of 201 East 62d Street have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Nan Gordon, to James D. Oestreich of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Oestreich of Lawrence, L. I.

A five-member State Supreme Court appeals panel heard arguments in Brooklyn yesterday on a lower court ruling that had enjoined a striking supervisor union from picketing in the 16-day pier strike and held that stevedore employers need not bargain with their supervisors.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 8 Clyde C. Seney, a management consultant here since 1955, died today of a heart attack in his home at 15 The Court. He was 54 years old.
National,Association of Securities Dealers, with changed leadership, has backed away from a compromise proposal for the regulation of mutual fund sales charges that it endorsed last summer.
Beginning next fall, report cards will be used to build better understanding between teachers and Spanish-speaking parents of thousands of pupils in the city's public schools.

Leonard Bernstein's post of music director of the New York Philharmonic will stand vacant "for an interim period" after he leaves the orchestra at the end of next season. Mr. Bernstein, who will take the title of laureate conductor of the Philharmonic after 10 years as music director, will conduct 12 weeks of the 1968-69 season, his final one, and five weeks in 1969-70.
UNION CITY, N. J., Nov. 8 Philip E. Gregg, lawyer for the metals division of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation in New York, died today at his home, 380 Mountain Avenue. He was 55 years old.

BOB HOPE'S comedy special last night had the services of a company of 24 comedians, cowboys and actors and Bobbie Gentry, the distaff recording star. The result was rather like a telecast of the Beverly Hills telephone book: interest tended to subside as more pages were turned.
TOKYO, Thursday, Nov, 9 (UPI)-The official North Vietnamese Government newspaper, Nhan Dan, published photographs yesterday of 15 recently captured American pilots, the Hanoi radio said today.

HAVANA, Nov. 8 (AP) Led by Premier Fidel Castro, Cuba's leaders turned out last night for a vodka-and-red-caviar reception at the Soviet Embassy to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., Nov. 8(AP) C. V. Whitney's Bugged and Thomas LaClair's Subpet won the split divisions of the Garden State Trial at Garden State Park today. The profits of Loew's Theatres, Inc., in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31 almost tripled the earnings of the preceding fiscal year and were the highest in the company's history, according to annual figures issued yesterday by Laurence A. Tisch, chairman and president.

SELMA, Ala., Nov. 8 (UPI) Three white men were jailed without bond on murder charges today in connection with the shooting death of a Negro tenant farmer.

DETROIT, Nov. 8 The United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation reached a tentative agreement this evening on a contract covering most Chrysler employes.

HONG KONG, Nov. 8 Thirty-nine persons were injured in a bomb explosion here tonight shortly after policemen killed two persons who were part of a mob. The bomb struck down members of the police patrol and of the mob confronting them.

Isidor Bieber's Wish Well beat A. Pleasant Sort by a neck in the feature race at Aqueduct' yesterday. The victory was unexpected by the crowd of 21,210, as indicated by the straight payoff of $36.60 for 32.

BERWYN, Pa., Nov. 8 Dr. John Alden Mason, a pioneer in the study of American Indian anthropology, died yesterday in Bryn Mawr Hospital at the age of 82. He lived here, and was curator emeritus of the section of American archeology and ethnology of University Museum, Philadelphia.
OAK PARK, Ill., Nov. 8 (AP) Sammy Mandell, the light weight boxing champion from 1926 until 1930, died last night at his home. He was 63 years old.
Gore Vidal, novelist, playwright ahd frequent critic of commercial television, has agreed to write an original play for the Columbia Broadcasting System's "C.B.S. Playhouse" series.

A team of two surgeons and a psychiatrist told a meeting of plastic surgeons yesterday of "insatiable" cosmetic surgery patients who seek repeated operations to correct imagined deformities.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 8 Arthur J. Goldberg, speaking before the Political committee today, urged members not to consider "a hasty approach" to resolving the question of resources on the sea bottom.

ALBANY, Nov. 8 If yesterday's off-year elections suggested anything, it was not so much a Democratic or Republican trend as that Americans are clinging tenaciously to some traditional ways of thinking, even while acquiescing in a remarkable change.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8--Dr. Alberto Franco Nogueira, Foreign Minister of Portugal, today described the policy pursued by the Western powers in Africa since the mid-nineteen-fifties as a "failure." He urged "other approaches" but did not define them.

On the sidewalk outside Minton's Playhouse on West 118th Street, men in shabby woolen coats ignored the night chill and loitered in the light of the blinking neon signs. The women's division of the Anti-Defamation League Appeal will give a luncheon honoring Betty Furness, chairman of the President's Committee on Consumer Interests, and Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin M. Reeves, philanthropists, on Monday at the New York Hilton.

RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 8 President. Hamani Diori of Niger whose country has diplomatic relations with Israel, joined with King Hassan II of Morocco today in supporting Arab demand for the return of Israel occupied terriroties.

George E, Baldwin, for many years a leading commercial orchid grower in Mamaroneck, N.Y., died Wednesday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Colin Shill, in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 93 years old.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 9--The United States golf team of Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus took the opening-round lead of the World Cup matches today by one stroke.

ALBANY, Nov. 9 (AP)--Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia shows "arrogance and contempt for the public," in his attitude toward salvaging provisions of the rejected new state constitution, a prominent Repulican declared today.

OTTAWA, Nov. 9 (Canadian Press)--Informed sources said tonight that Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson had ordered Cabinet members who are seeking the Liberal party leadership to stop their campaigning.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP)--Roy Edwards made his National Hockey League debut a winning one tonight, beating the team that rejected him while backstopping a 5-1 victory for the Detroit Red Wings over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

The 24th annual Brick Church Christmas Fair will be held in Watson Hall, Park Avenue at 91st Street, next Thursday and Friday. Mrs. Herbert E. Sharp is chairman for the event, which benefits the work of the Women's Association of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

The Republican substitute for the antipoverty authorization bill now pending in the House of Representatives would transfer several of the more successful and less controversial programs from the Office of Economic Opportunity to various regular departments. This reorganization would leave O.E.O. with nothing but the much-disputed community action program.

Mr. and Mrs. Fred Zubritsky of Richmond Hill North, queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arlene Mary Britt Zubritsky, to Erasmo La Marca, son of Mr. ahd Mrs. Gaspare La Marca of Nola, Italy.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 9-- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said tonight that "there is still the possibility of invasion of North Vietnam."
SALERNO, Italy, Nov. 9 (AP)--A Milan-to-Palermo express train tore through a herd of buffalo and then into a derailed commuter train today. At least 14 passengers were killed and 70 were injured.

ACONJECTURE: An art form develops in two ways, which are at once antithetical and complementary--by knowing experimentation, and by the assured, perfecting practice of the familiar. These two works of fiction are cases in point.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 (UPI) --Al Massey, a lightweight, scored one of the quickest knockouts in boxing history tonight, stopping Mike (Golden Boy) Cortez in 11 seconds of the first round. The bout was the highlight of a card that featured four 10-round fights at the Philadelphia Arena.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 9 --Miss Margaret Mary Elliott and Peter J. Flatow will be married here on Dec. 23.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 (AP) --Eddie Joyal scored two goals and the Los Angeles Kings received outstanding goaltending from Wayne Rutledge to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-1 tonight in a National Hockey League game.

WAWA, Pa., Nov. 9--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Townsend Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Richards Townsend, to Samuel M. Hamill Jr. of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hamill of Princeton. N.J.

An odd feature of the post-election scene in Saigon is that Truong Dinh Dzu, the "white dove" peace candidate who ran a strong second in the presidential balloting, has been under house arrest for a month.

DETROIT, Nov. 9--The General Motors Corporation announced today that it had joined other Detroit companies in trying to put more Negroes to work, particularly those who have been jobless for a long time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9-- Bowing to an insistent House, the Senate reluctantly agreed today to drop its four-month fight for a controversial public power project in Maine.

Bond prices declined sharply yesterday under the impact of the increase in the Bank of England's lending rate and the announcement of more new corporate issues for sale shortly.

For commodities it was a lively day yesterday, with noteworthy activity in several markets. Sugar traders entertained the Brazilian ambassador to the United States, Vasco Leitao da Cunha, at a luncheon in the Downtown Athletic Club, at a time when Brazil has been a price pace setter in the world sugar market.

WHTTE PLAINS, Nov. 9-- The White Plains Committee on Schools, a citizens' organization, today disputed findings by the Board of Education that the complete integration of pupils here for the last three years had improved the academic achievement of Negro children.
Industrial issues were a shade easier on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. News of the increase in Britain's bank rate produced some erratic movements.

OMAHA, Nov. 9 (UPI)--An Omaha real estate company has announced what might be the largest single sale of irrigated land ever made in Nebraska.

The rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church has withdrawn an invitation to the Right Rev. James A. Pike to preach there next Holy. Week because his involvement with spiritualism has "damaged his effectiveness."

ATLANTA, Nov. 9--A group of prominent Southern moderates and liberals, many with close ties to the Johnson Administration, have organized a committee aimed at making the region's politics "more ethical, more dynamic, and more just."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. (AP)--President Johnson, proclaiming Nov. 23 as Thanksgiving Day, offered a prayer today that God would bless the nation with wisdom and perseverance.

He was 55 years old and lived at 7 Cheltenham Street.

The New York financial press last night presented its annual appraisal of life in the business world. As usual, business lost. Further rises in products using copper were posted yesterday. Copper supplies are short and getting shorter as a consequence of a marathon strike at mines in this country and abroad.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Saturday, Nov. 12 (AP)--The National Liberation Front, political arm of the Vietcong, handed three captive over a representative of an American peace committee today. ABOARD U.S.S. ENTERPRISE, off San Diego, Calif., Nov. 10--President Johnson swept across the continent today delivering an emotional tribute to the fighting men in Vietnam, a plea for national unity, and an oblique but unmistakable criticism of those "who debate [the war] from the comfort of some distant sidelines."

SOUSSE, Tunisia, Nov. 10-- Grand Master Bent Larsen of Denmark won again in the 19th round of the International Qualifying Chess Tournament. THE birds flocking together these days are of many a feather. Ostrich, turkey, goose, and maribou ... the flutter of feathers in fashion has become an avalanche. Women have rediscovered the joys of femininity.

Local communities will have a veto over Mayor Lindsay's selections for the job of director in each of the city's three proposed Model Cities areas-- Harlem-East Harlem, South Bronx and Central Brooklyn. WASHINGTON, Nov. 10-- Wedding invitations will go out this weekend to some 500 friends and relatives of the President's daughter, Miss. Lynda Bird Johnson, and her fiance, Marine Capt. Charles Spittal Robb, who will be married Saturday, Dec. 9, in the White House East Room.

In restoring his hope of some day being a contender, James J. Woody exposed Dante Cane of Italy as a flabby and futile, although brave, heavyweight last night in a three-ring boxing card that attracted 5,500 spectators to Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10-- Mike Mansfield, the Senate's soft spoken philosopher in residence, gently excused a balky House today for trimming social programs and barring a tax increase. The House, the Senate majority leader said is merely reflecting "the mood of America."

A nationwide scheme was disclosed yesterday in which members of the Mafia and other organized crime groups allegedly spent $350,000 for travel and living expenses with stolen credit cards while they engaged in criminal activities. The disclosure came in Federal Court with the unsealing of a mail fraud indictment against four men.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., Nov. 10--Three Ku Klux Klansmen who are under Federal charges in the firebomb slaying of a Negro civil rights leader in 1966 were jailed here today after being indicted by a county grand jury for kidnapping.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 (AP)-- Governor Rockefeller has commuted the death sentence of Nathan Jackson of Brooklyn, whose fight to escape a murder conviction led to a far-reaching United States Supreme Court decision on confessions.

NEWARK, Nov. 10--Weequahic High clinched its first City League football championship today despite playing a 12-12 tie with Newark South Side at Untermann Field. It was the Indians' first title in six years.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 12--A group of Democrats who oppose the war in Vietnam today announced the formation of an organization called Dissenting Democrats of Long Island.
HONG KONG, Nov. 12--A display advertisement in a Hong Kong newspaper last week announced: "Lindy's is open! Pastrami! Corned beef! Cheescake! Bagels!"
Kinney National Service, Inc. reached an agreement in principle over the weekend to acquire Ashley-Famous Agency, Inc., the nation's second largest talent agency.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 (UPI)-- The Kansas City Chiefs built a 20-point first-half lead on two touchdown passes by Len jDawson today and coasted to a 33-10 victory over the Boston Patriots in an American Football League game.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12--A large group of union leaders, who disagree with the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s official support of President Johnson's Vietnam policy, declared today that the war was "immoral" and that continued involvement by the United States was "contrary to the best interests of our country."

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12 (UPI)--A majority of voters for the first time since 1957 would prefer to see Republicans rather than Democrats handle the nation's most serious problem, the Gallup poll reported today.

WITH the endearing modesty that has already made him the toast of one continent, David Merrick, the impresario, has himself described in all his programs as "the most vital force in the theater today."
PARIS, Nov. 12--French negotiators return to Baghdad this week to resume highly controversial negotiations for huge stakes: the undeveloped oil fields of Iraq.
"SANTA'S little elves, that's us," a burly six-footer said wryly as he worked on a float full of bouncing, twirling, jiggling papier-mache figures.

HELSINKI, Finland, Nov. 12 --When President Urho Kekkonen returned from the Moscow celebrations of the 50th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution last week he quipped at the airport that he had heard about the coup in Yemen and had immediately telephoned home to ask what his own situation was.

Mayor Lindsay, dapper, cool and relaxed, made his debut last night as the host of a commercially sponsored television program that featured discussions of welfare, schools, traffic problems, the police and an exchange with members of the studio audience.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12--Israel's Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, raised the possibility today of the economic integration of Israel, Jordan and Lebanon following a peace settlement in the Middle East.
STE. AGATHE, Manitoba-- Paul Lemoine put his whole body into pushing the granary door open on its rusted rails. heaped almost to the roof.
The money and capital markets, already groggy from the relentless climb in interest rates and disappointing sales of new issues, face a crucial week.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that "it would be a good thing for my party and for the country" if Governor Rockefeller decided to seek the Republican nomination for President in 1968.

The battle lines were more sharply defined yesterday in a maritime dispute that has been submitted to George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Nov. 12-- John Surtees of England won the 210-mile Stardust Prix today when Mark Donohue, the leader from the 15th lap of the 170-lap race, ran out of gas while 18 seconds ahead and less than a quarter-mile to go on the three-mile course.
LONDON, Nov. 12--Britain's Labor Government is taking a businesslike approach in overhauling the financial and management structure of the deficit-ridden nationalized railway system.
Mayor Lindsay said last night that "stability in our city is now threatened" by projected Congressional cuts in Federal antipoverty programs.
The death last Wednesday of James E. Day, president of the Midwest Stock Exchange since its formation in 1949, has swung the securities spotlight to the hunt for his successor.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 12-- Five Federal officials, singled out as symbolizing the "ability, dedication and achievement" of those in government service, were named winners of the 1967 Rockefeller Public Service Awards today.

The engagement of Miss Liza Jane Pearson to Malcolm MacNaughton Jr. of San Francisco has been announced here by her parents, Viscount Cowdray of Cowdray Park, Midhurst, England, and Anne Viscountess Cowdray of Broadleas, Devizes, Wiltshire, England. The future bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. MacNaughton of Honolulu.

The New York Civil Liberties Union charged yesterday that the state law providing compulsory treatment for narcotic addicts was totally inadequate and that compulsory confinement was nothing more than imprisonment.

Monday nights along Bleecker Street tend to be quiet recuperations. Last night, however, the Main Street of Greenwich Village was enlivened by a complex and frequently brilliant concert by Tim Buckley at the Garrick Theater.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13-- Southern California's Rose Bowl hopes were dealt another blow today when Jimmy Lawrence, the star flankerback, was declared out of Saturday's showdown game with the University of California, Los Angeles.
Harry Salpeter, an art dealer and critic for many years, died yesterday in his sleep at his home, 360 Central Park West. His age was 72.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- The Treasury bill rate declined slightly from last week's levels at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 13--By all standards of Western logic, the civil war in Nigeria should be over.

CLAYTON, Mo., Nov. 13--A major national study is being organized to show whether the use of a clot-dissolving substance can reduce the death toll from blood clots that lodge in the lungs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13-- John E. Horne, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, urged today a speedup in passage of legislation enlarging the credit areas in which savings and loan associations may invest.
American folk art has gained a new star in the roster of usually anonymous artisans and amateurs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- After hearing the odds and the morality of the New York State lottery denounced, the Senate voted today to prohibit all Federally insured banks from selling lottery tickets.
ATHENS, Nov. 10--The overriding question in Greece no longer is whether the colonels can stay in power but how long they will want to. No one, not even the colonels, pretends to know.
Members of the Transit Authority said yesterday that granting the contract demands of the Transport Workers Union would require a 60-cent fare--an increase of 40 cents.
Dr. Yale J. Laitin, founder of a concern that conducts surveys to find out what employes really think of their employers, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 50 years old.
MANILA, Nov. 13--To one prominent Filipino politician, the hotly contested Senate election tororrow is a matter of secondary importance.
Clementine Paddleford, one of the nation's best-known food writers, died of cancer yesterday at the New York Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived at 222 East 61st Street.

At the American Legion's 34th annual convention in New York in 1952, the red cap of the national commander was placed on the head of Lewis Ketcham Gough, who had just been elected unanimously to head the veterans organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- This is one of those years when the whole country seems to have got up on the wrong side of the bed. Churlishness is the fashion in behavior, meanness is the prevailing spirit, and insult is the currency of discourse.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 13--Sixty-three persons-- most of them teen-agers-- jammed into a tiny courtroom here today to be arraigned on charges growing out of what police called "a wild marijuana party" in neighboring Naugatuck on Friday night.
SAIGON, South Vietnam Nov. 13--A former Viet Cong agent said today that for two years he interrogated, indoctrinated and guarded two of the three American war prisoners who were released Saturday.

One City College student was arrested yesterday and about 15 face possible expulsion after demonstrations against on-campus job recruiting by the Dow Chemical Company, which manufactures napalm for use in the Vietnam war.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (UPI)-- National League club owners criticized the American League today for a sudden decision to expand, then deferred a vote on whether to expand their league at least until December, when both major baseball leagues meet in Mexico City.

SOUSSE, Tunisia, Nov. 13-- Grand Master Bent Larsen of Denmark eased into first place last night after completion of the 21st round of the Interzonal Qualifying Chess Tournament when he, played a short draw with the many-time Yugoslav champion, Svetozar Gligoric. Larsen has posted 14 points out of a possible 19.

ONLY a few minutes of the game remained and the Dallas Cowboys had a 31-20 lead over the Washington Redskins a couple of seasons ago. Clint Murchison, owner of the Cowboys, decided it was safe enough to make the sporting gesture. So he wended his way to the box of Edward Bennett Williams, president of the Redskins.
The stock market failed to sustain a strong early advance yesterday and weakened in the afternoon to finish with a loss for the session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- The Supreme Court refused today, over a vigorous dissent by Chief Justice Earl Warren, to consider charges that the New York Stock Exchange was violating the antitrust laws by imposing minimum commission rates on its members.

NEWARK, Nov. 13--The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the State of New Jersey and the City of Newark were represented today at a ground breaking for a $4.5million middle-income cooperative housing project.
The United States Steel Corporation decided late yesterday to postpone its scheduled sale today of $225-million of debentures, taking a second burden off the floundering bond market.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The National Academy of Sciences named a Board of Medicine today to find ways of speeding the benefits of medical research and practice to the public.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- The House defeated by a 10vote margin today a Republican amendment to cut President Johnson's antipoverty bill by more than $600-million.

The story line of "Hair," the musical with which the New York Shakespeare Festival has inaugurated its indoor home on Lafayette Street, is so attenuated that it would be merciful to label the piece a revue.
The New York City Opera will open its winter season on Feb. 22 at the New York State Theater with a twin bill of Stravinsky's "Oedipus Rex" and Orff's "Carmina Burana."

Wheat futures tumbled sharply yesterday to establish new lows, with trading described as quite slow. Perhaps one reason for the slow volume was that Canadian markets were closed in observance of Remembrance Day.

PARIS--Paris's first computerized grocery store--the second in France--is proving it is easier to shop without handling any food.

IN just one season Manhattan Festival Ballet has developed from a novelty to an institution. Every Monday at the home of Peanuts, Theater 80 St. Marks Place, while Charlie Brown and the gang take a rest, Manhattan Festival Ballet is patiently building an off-Broadway audience for classic ballet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- The Federal Reserve's open market committee expressed growing concern in mid-August at the rate of expansion of credit and money in the economy but took no overt action to reduce it.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Nov. 14--American paratroopers evacuated their dead and wounded today after a sharp fight last night near Dakto in the Central Highlands. The United States command reported nine paratroopers of the 173d Airborne Brigade had been killed and 21 wounded. Enemy casualties were not disclosed, but sweeps in the area this morning by the airborne soldiers were expected to find numbers of enemy dead.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange followed yesterday a pattern that has been getting familiar--selling pressure in the last 90 minutes of the session more than wiped out the gains of early trading.
NEW DELHI, Nov. 13 (AP) --Richard Sanders of Portland, Ore., scored two victories today and remained in strong contention for the flyweight title in the world free-style wrestling championships.
Earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., for all of 1967 should be 21 per cent to 24 per cent below the 1966 level, the company predicted yesterday.

The States Urban Action Center, an organization formed to assist governors in coping with urban problems, met yesterday for the first time and put crime control at the top of its program agenda.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) The White House said today that President Johnson had averaged better than two news conferences a month since he had been in office and that about half of these had been open to radio and television coverage.

THE new series of Paris Review Interviews continues to be as fresh as those encountered not only in the original collection but also in the magazine itself.

The research submarine Alvin, which located the missing hydrogen bomb at the bottom of the Mediterranean off Spain last year, has scored another success--closer to home in more than one sense.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13-- A campaign to persuade home buyers to make larger down payments as a means of conserving the supply of available credit was urged today by the Government's chief operative in the secondary mortgage market.

Irwin Gross came up from Pennsylvania yesterday with some bold new ideas for the advertising business. Two Marblehead, Mass., racing yachts, Robin and Tioga, were named last night as winners of special prizes during last summer's New York Yacht Club cruise. More than 70 trophies were presented to owners ...

The National Repertory Theater will give a 14-week season, starting Lincoln's Birthday, at the reconstructed Ford's Theater in Washington, where Lincoln was assassinated in 1865. Three plays will be performed, "John Brown's Body" on Feb. 12; "The Comedy of Errors," Feb. 26, and "She Stoops to Conquer," March 26.

An organization of symphony and opera musicians whose members have been rating their conductors on talent and temperament by means of a detailed questionnaire has decided to stop for fear of libel action by maestros whose careers might be injured.

LONDON, Nov. 14 Lieut. Gen. Sir Archibald Nye, wartime Deputy Chief of the Imperial General Staff, died last night at the age of 72. The cause of death was not disclosed.

Attorney General Ramsey Clark said yesterday that the use of a "task force" against organized crime had proved "highly effective" during a nine-month test in Buffalo and would be used in other cities.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, Nov. 14 (Reuters)--A judge, ruling that the American peace campaigner Ralph Schoenmann had been cruel to his British wife, granted her a divorce today. The court cited sexual aberrations and a persistent refusal to wash.
