LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14--Andre Courreges, who revolutionized women's fashions, manufactured a brilliant fashion show in a factory last night, and Los Angeles loved it.

It was growing dark outside as 10 students in a classroom in Julia Richman High School took notes. Their teacher, Robert Marin, was explaining that, according to Avogadro's law, equal volumes of different gases at the same temperature and pressure contain the same number of molecules.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Nov. 14 (AP) That Guy and Heap O Trouble raced as a team throughout most of the Brass Horn Purse at Garden State Park today, but they finished in a second-place dead heat at the conclusion of six furlongs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (UPI) Wilt Chamberlain scored 27 points for his top offensive performance of the season tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers coasted to a 122-102 victory over Cincinnati in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at the Spectrum.
First Prudential Corporation announced yesterday a new company policy that would reduce its role as a stock broker to small investors.

CONCEPCION, the Philippines, Nov. 14--"Everybody says I'm the front-runner, but if I wind up No. 5, I'll be lucky," said Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition Liberals' leading contender for one of eight at-large Senate seats in the election today.

TEANECK, N.J., Nov. 14 Three leading retailers, attempting to describe the merits of retailing as a career to a large audience of college students here, today found themselves defending stores' ethics, treatment of consumers and social consciousness.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 14 Britain's friends in the European Common Market today viewed as highly constructive and potentially far reaching Prime Minister Wilson's declared willingness yesterday to discuss much closer European technological collaboration, even before Britain enters the market.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The House voted tonight to permit city halls or county courthouses to take charge of community-action programs under the Federal antipoverty effort.

Bergdorf Goodman, the Fifth Avenue specialty store, is planning a $2.5-million expansion, reconstruction and modernization program for the area it is taking over from the Tailored Woman on Fifth Avenue and 57th Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 Alan S. Boyd, Secretary of the Department of Transportation, told the nation's top petroleum industry executives today that it would be unwise to put tight restrictions on oil imports.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) Officials of an organization that helps set up tax-exempt foundations invoked the Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination today before a congressional investigation of their operations.
WILBERFORCE, Ohio, Nov. 14--Central State University, a predominantly Negro state school, was closed today after a clash between students and policemen last night.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 14 (UPI)--A Federal judge today denied a request for an injunction to prevent the Kaneb Pipeline Company from buying stock in the Kansas-Nebraska Natural Gas Company.
The Parks Department yesterday announced increases, as of Jan. 1, in fees for its revenue-producing facilities.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 14--As delegates assembled today for the annual meeting of the Professional Golfers' Association, which opens tomorrow, steps were being taken to bring harmony between the players on the multimillion-dollar tour and the stay-at-home club pros.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The mutual fund industry has been attempting, so far without success, to work out a deal with the banking industry to kill the pending mutual fund reform bill. In exchange the fund industry would support legislation that would permit banks to enter the mutual fund business.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 The Coast Guard asked the Navy today to search for Francis Brenton, a 40-year-old Englishman who left Chicago June 6 in a 26-foot canoe en route to Senegal on the west coast of Africa.
A high-level evaluation of the military situation in Vietnam is being prepared for the President by an interagency group. It coincides with a visit to Washington by ...
The Transit Authority will post notices at its change booths today announcing that $5 bills will not be changed until further notice because of a large number of counterfeits.

The Playboy Club was ordered by the State Liquor Au thority yesterday to halt all liquor sales for 10 days, beginning Jan. 8, because an assistant manager had blackened the eye of a patron who was pinned against a wall by two other employes.
LONDON, Nov. 14 Britain and the National Liberation Front of South Arabia will begin negotiations in Geneva next week.

CLAYTON, Mo., Nov. 14--Situations like Vietnam could be popping up all over the world unless the United States moves wisely and fast, two experts on world food and population problems said here today.
Mr. and Mrs. William John Quayle of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nora Coleman Quayle, to John Joseph Bird Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bird of Short Hills, N.J.

Alvin E. Coleman, a senior partner of the factoring firm of Coleman Co., has been nominated to be president of Temple Emanu-El (Reform), regarded as one of the largest and most influential Jewish congregations in the world.

A New York lawyer who has been a personal friend of Gov. George Romney for many years declares that contrary to some legal opinion the Michigan Governor is eligible to be President of the United States despite his birth in Mexico.

In the sealed corridors and workshops of the American Museum of Natural History, away from the shuffle of small feet and the laughter of excited schoolchildren, scientists and artists are at work on seven new exhibition halls for the museum's centennial in 1969.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 14 In the spring of 1964, George Corley Wallace sat puffing a cigar in the back of a rented automobile as it hurtled through a heavy Wisconsin rainstorm.
ROME, Nov. 14 The American novelist John Dos Passos received today the $32,000 Antonio Feltrinelli Prize for fiction.

An Argentine biochemist has been awarded a newly created $25,000 award for his discovery of a previously unknown group of compounds that play an important role in body metabolism, Columbia University announced yesterday.

In the face of rising costs and diminishing returns in Vietnam, a rational debate over United States policy is, as Ambassador Arthur Goldberg recently observed, "inevitable, desirable and indeed essential."

The Old Testament according to Ernest Bloch and Zoltan Kodaly was read last night at Philharmonic Hall, where Milan Horvat led the Little Orchestra Society as deputy for the society's music director, Thomas Scherman.

THE National League overlords reacted at a Chicago meeting the other day in pretty much the same fashion as a fighter who has just been knocked down and falls into a clinch until his head clears and he can figure out what he should do next.

The University of California, Los Angeles, moved into first place in both wire service polls for the top college football teams in the land. But the same city had the No. 1 spot as the Bruins replaced their neighbor, the University of Southern California.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 14 A few months ago, the Cunard people called in Charles Horner to tell him about his last job. "You're going to see the old girl out " they said.

The setting last night for one of Broadway's favorite rituals, the opening night party, was not Sardi's or Luchow's, the traditional spots, but the 37room, five-story house of Benjamin Sonnenberg, retired public relations consultant, on Gramercy Park South.
The Reliance Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Queens County Federal Savings and Loan Association announced yesterday that a merger of the two associations had been completed.

Lloyd Goodrich will resign as director of the Whitney Museum, of American Art on Jan. 1 and will be named to the newly created post of advisory director. He will be succeeded by John I.H. Baur, the museum's associate director.
BOSTON, Nov. 14 (AP) Hancock Raceway, a judge ruled today, is entitled to a $100,000 Government bond claimed by four persons, including the father of former Gov. Foster Furcolo.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14--The high cost of money, particularly for home mortgages, will continue to rise even if the supply of money in the economy is expanded, real estate brokers agreed today.

Marianne Moore, the poet, is 80 years old today and she's going to have the sort of birthday party she likes. Monroe Wheeler, counselor to the trustees of the Museum of Modern Art, will take her out with Glenway Wescott, the novelist, and with her brother, Capt. John Warner Moore, U.S.N., retired, and his wife.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk renewed his offer to the North Vietnamese Government last night to "negotiate today without condition" toward a settlement of the war in Vietnam.

Riotous bands of antiwar demonstrators, frustrated by heavy police reinforcements from any effective harassment of a speech by Secretary of State Dean Rusk at the New York Hilton, milled through the Times Square area last night, pelting policemen with stones, bottles and eggs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) Prospects for early approval of nationwide pay television were dealt a blow today when a House Commerce subcommittee told the Federal Communications Commission to hold off until Congress grants it the power.

The bays, estuaries and coastal wetlands where the fresh waters of a river meet the tides of the sea were once crucial in the evolution of man. For other species, they are still the survival zone. Here nearly two-thirds of the nation's commercially valuable finfish and shellfish spawn. Here are found cysters, shrimp, clams and crabs. And here water birds live and migratory birds rest on their journeys.

Clusters of large pink and purple balloons bobbed above the pink-covered tables in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza last night where about 500 guests gathered for the annual dinner dance of The Lighthouse, The New York Association for the Blind.
Despite last minute attacks by spokesmen for local gun clubs and firearms dealers, Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday a bill to license all rifles and shotguns sold or owned in the city.

A motion by the Securities and Exchange Commission to have Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., placed in receivership was stalled temporarily in Federal court here yesterday when Judge Sylvester J. Ryan said he had "serious questions" about whether to disqualify himself from hearing the case.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 There are many mysteries and tragedies in Vietnam, but the greatest of these is the Hanoi Government's continuing refusal to talk about a negotiated settlement.
Several changes in organization at Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., were announced yesterday by John H. Eikenberg, chairman, and Fritz C. Hyde Jr., president.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Nov. 14 Mrs. Shirley Temple Black's ambition to sit in Congress was blocked by a fellow Republican Paul N. McCloskey Jr., in a special election today in California's 11th District.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 14 Maj. Gen. Bruno A. Hochmuth, the commander of the Third Marine Division, was killed today in a helicopter crash near Hue, in the northern part of South Vietnam.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 15 Harold Philby said in an interview published here today that he had no regrets over his 30-year career of spying for the Soviet Union and would do it all over "if I were young again in Britain today."

YONKERS, Nov. 14 Herve Filion, the ace Canadian reinsman who will drive Meadow Paige in the $150,000 Cane Futurity Pace at Yorkers Raceway on Saturday night, is confident his pacer, who finished second to Romulus Hanover last week, will reverse that order this time.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 15 (UPI) A North Vietnamese mortar attack on the base camp of the United States Fourth Infantry Division at Dakto today destroyed two C-130 transport planes and damaged a third, Saigon headquarters reported. The assault opened the third week of fighting in the Central Highlands.
Justice Albert H. Bosch declared a mistrial yesterday in the case of John (Sonny) Franzese and three others charged in State Supreme Court with murder.
BRASILIA, Nov. 14 Joan Lowell, an American writer and adventure seeker, was found dead today at her country home near here.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 (AP) The State Supreme Court stayed all executions in California today.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 A selfstyled former agent of the United States Central Intelligence Agency who has defected to the Soviet Union charged today that Americans sought to organize a military overthrow of the nonaligned government of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

JOHN IRELAND HOWE BAUR has had only two jobs in his working life. "That's almost unheard of in museum circles," the 58-yearold museum administrator said almost diffidently yesterday as it was made known that his second job has worked out rather nicely ...

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 14 Dr. Jacques Piccard, the oceanographer, said here today that he was "seriously doubtful" that man would still exist in the 21st century because of the dangers of technological progress and nuclear destruction.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The United States mission in Saigon has asked the International Voluntary Services to continue its programs of hamlet-level social work, despite the criticism of the Administration's Vietnam policy voiced by several of its former field workers.

The New York-New Jersey Region of the Brandeis University National Women's Conmmittee has arranged a tour of four private art collections in Manhattan for Nov. 28. Proceeds will go to the Learned Journal program for the university's library.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations scorned a Houseapproved meat inspection bill today as "a snare, a delusion and a hoax on the American people."
Meyer Davis, the 72-year-old society band leader, was mugged and robbed of $700 as he walked on 46th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of Americas at 9:30 P.M. on Monday.
Samuel J. Kearing Jr., one of John V. Lindsay's stalwarts during the mayoral campaign of 1965, resigned yesterday as Commissioner of Sanitation.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 (AP) The Soviet Union swept three championships and four second places today in the completion of the world freestyle wrestling tournament. The United States collected three medals, one for second and two for third.
The city announced new and stringent safety rules yesterday for construction cranes on streets and said it would add regulations for off-street cranes later.
Once again wheat futures received little support and moved sharply lower yesterday to set another string of life of contract lows.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 The Central Intelligence Agency said today it had transferred scheduled campus recruiting conferences from the grounds of about six colleges and universities to nearby off-campus locations to avoid the "embarrassment" of anti-C.I.A. student demonstrations.
WITH one month to go in the pro football races, the New York Giants are still contenders in the Century Division of the National Football League, 1 games behind the pace-setting St. Louis Cardinals.
Representatives of the taxi fleet industry and the taxi union here, seeking to meet a contest deadline of midnight tomorrow, were reported far apart on several important issues yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 The 75th annual conventions of the United States Savings and Loan League was in an uproar today over an attack yesterday on savings and loan holding companies by John E. Horne, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.
ALBANY, Nov. 14 A bill to assure school districts their "guaranteed" minimum revenues from the state lottery, whose sales have been far below predictions, will be prefiled in the Assembly tomorrow.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday its "full-scale entry" into the digital communications business with the introduction of a new line of data transmission products.
An increase of 10 cents a pound was posted yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., on all types of bulked filament nylon carpet yarn, effective at once.
Angel Tomas Cordero Jr., the riding sensation from Puerto Rico, came rushing into Aqueduct's big jockey room after yesterday's fifth race, bubbling.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 15 Premier Nguyen Van Loc unveiled the new Government's first "program of action" today. It emphasized social reforms and muted the prospects of peace.
Bearish economic news weakened the stock market yesterday as the list declined in active trading.

Joseph L. Rauh Jr., national president of Americans for Democratic Action, comes to New York tomorrow night to urge that dissent on the Administration's policies in Vietnam stop short of a "dump Johnson" move.

John E. McKeen, chairman of the board of Chas. Pfizer Co., testified yesterday in the Government's criminal conspiracy case involving alleged price-fixing from 1953 to 1961 against Pfizer and two other major drug manufacturers that "the tendency is to try and bring these prices closer to the same [level.]"
CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 (AP) Seth C. Taft said today he would ask the Cuyahoga County Board of Elections for a recount of last Tuesday's mayoral election.

News of Britain's huge trade deficit for October had little impact on the London Stock Exchange yesterday and leading issues even improved after the announcement. Government bonds took a turn for the better, although closing prices were mixed.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., Nov. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Ewing have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Mason Ewing, to Charles Wright Shabica, son of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Charles Shabica Jr. of Livingston, N.J.
The Rumanian Government and Inter-Continental Hotel Corporation, a subsidiary of Pan American World Airways, agreed yesterday to build a hotel in Bucharest.

Government concern about the size of retail food chains is causing the latter to look in different directions rather than merely adding stores when contemplating growth, the head of a leading chain said yesterday.
A group of the city's top union leaders and businessmen organized a Labor-Management Council yesterday to promote better labor relations and to improve the economic climate here.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 14 Harold E. Stassen announced his candidacy for President today, and said that he would enter the Wisconsin Republican primary next April 2 as "the peace candidate."
ALBANY, Nov. 13 (AP) Morris B. Abram said tonight he probably would declare his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in February.

ADLAI E. STEVENSON died in London on July 14, 1965. These are the first two major studies of his life since then. There will be others; an "official" biography, based on the Stevenson family papers, is currently being prepared by John Bartlow Martin for publication (by Doubleday) in 1969 or 1970.
A three-man mediation panel to try to settle the transit contract dispute without a strike on Jan. 1 will be announced by Mayor Lindsay next week.
Prices took their steepest dive in more than five months on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The number of issues that declined also was the largest in more than five months.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) The Senate Post Office and Civil Service Committee approved today a pay raise of 6 per cent for postal workers and 4 per cent for other Federal employes.
A father who paid $1,500 to get a draft exemption for his son was found not guilty yesterday of having tried to buy immunity from military service for the youth.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 In an attempt to put teeth into its economic reform, the Soviet Government published a decree today imposing fines up to 20 per cent of the values of goods for the delivery of defective merchandise or incomplete sets of equipment.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 14 The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad's last two Hudson River ferryboats, the Elmira and the Lackawanna, will end their service between Hoboken and lower Manhattan on Thanksgiving Eve, Nov. 22.
TRENTON, Nov. 14 Feuding Republicans in Essex County were on the way tonight to becoming the first victims of the struggle for leadership of their party's new majorities in the next Legislature.

The Infants Home of Brooklyn will mark its 48th anniversary, at a dinner on Sunday at the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 Congress passed and sent to President Johnson today a bill that empowers the Federal Government virtually to immobilize a city if air pollution causes a serious health hazard.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov.14 (AP) Ten ticket printing companies and 12 executives were fined a total of $246,050 today in United States District Court after pleading no defense to charges of price fixing and bid rigging.

TOKYO, Nov. 14 At the request of the United States Navy, the Japanese police have started a nation-wide search for four young enlisted men who deserted from the aircraft carrier Intrepid in protest against the war in Vietnam.

The Alard Quartet, which made its New York debut in September, 1965, returned last night for the first time since then, to give a program in Carnegie Recital Hall. The Gulf American Corporation, the Florida land development company, announced yesterday the appointment of Bernard H. Herzfeld as vice chairma nof the board of directors and executive vice president.

Army will consider and possibly accept a football bowl bid before the Army-Navy game, Dec. 2, if the Black Knights beat Pittsburgh Saturday at Pitt Stadium. The Sugar and Cotton Bowls are ready to offer bids to Army if the cadets win Saturday.

A Harvard team won a narrow victory in an inter collegiate knockout team tournament organized at Brandeis University ten days ago. Unionized taxxi drivers broke off contract negotiations with the industry last night, but postponed a strike at least until next Tuesday night.

The credit markets showed a mixed pattern in the week ended Wednesday, but on balance it appeared that the Federal Reserve was continuing to be generous in supplying funds to the economy.

The prospect of professionals playing against amateurs, once such a bete noire that the United States Lawn Tennis Association officially forbade its mention at meetings, was discussed calmly for five hours here yesterday by the association's executive committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) --The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that Pan American World Airways, Inc., could now fly passengers directly from New York across the United States to the Far East.

Europe sends to this country a steady stream of impressive chamber ensembles. The latest to cross the Atlantic is from France, the Orchestre JeanFrancois Paillard.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Nov. 17 --Charles N. Stoddard Jr., a member of the law firm of Stoddard, Ball, Barlett Trudel, died today in Wesson Memorial Hospital, Springfield, at the age of 57. He had suffered a fractured skull in a fall Sunday at his home.

After seventeen wary years a person in Maryland may once again be hired as a fireman or sanitation worker or schoolteacher without solemnly swearing not to overthrow the Government. The state's loyalty oath for public employes has been struck down by the Supreme Court as unconstitutional, as have similar provisions in recent years in New York, Arizona, Washington and Florida.
